questions.text: Which of the following should not be prescribed with theophylline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Erythromycin

Explanation:

  • Erythromycin should not be prescribed with theophylline as ﻿﻿erythromycin inhibits the metabolism of theophylline by blocking the activity of an enzyme called cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) which can lead to theophylline toxicity.
  • Symptoms of theophylline toxicity:
    • Nausea, vomiting,
    • Tachycardia
    • Tremors
    • Seizures
  • Factors affecting the clearance of theophylline are:
    • ﻿﻿Drugs: Erythromycin, Cimetidine, Ciprofloxacin, Allopurinol, Zafirlukast
    • ﻿﻿Congestive heart failure
    • ﻿﻿Liver disease
    • ﻿﻿Pneumonia
    • ﻿﻿Viral infection and vaccination
    • ﻿﻿High-carbohydrate diet
    • ﻿﻿Old age

Cefotaxime (Option B), Cotrimoxazole (Option C) and Amoxicillin (Option D) do not have significant interactions with theophylline and can be prescribed concurrently without causing toxicity or reduced efficacy of each other.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chloroquine

Explanation:

Prolonged or high-dose use of chloroquine can lead to a condition known as chloroquine keratopathy, characterised by the drug's deposition in the cornea, specifically in the corneal epithelium and endothelium.

 

Chloroquine

MOA

Chloroquine accumulates in acidic compartments of parasite-infected cells, disrupting heme polymerisation and inhibiting parasite growth and replication.

Resistance

Due to mutations in genes encoding transporters involved in chloroquine uptake and efflux, reducing chloroquine accumulation within parasites.

Uses
  • Malaria Treatment and Prophylaxis
  • Amebiasis
  • Leprae reaction
  • Giardiasis
  • Autoimmune Diseases (RA, SLE)

S/E
  • Ophthalmic: Bull's eye maculopathy, anterior subcapsular cataract, vortex keratopathy, corneal deposits
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Skin: Itching, rash, photosensitivity
  • Neuropsychiatric: Agitation, confusion, hallucinations
  • Cardiac: QT prolongation, cardiomyopathy (rare)

 

 

Leflunomide (Option A) is an immunomodulatory drug used in rheumatoid arthritis. Its side effects are mainly hepatotoxicity, teratogenicity, and immunosuppression; it does not typically cause corneal deposits.

Methotrexate (Option C) is an antimetabolite that primarily affects rapidly dividing cells. Its ocular side effects include conjunctivitis and rare cases of scleritis, but it does not cause corneal deposition.

Sulfasalazine (Option D) is used for inflammatory bowel diseases, and rheumatoid arthritis may cause reversible yellow-orange discolouration of skin or urine, but it is not associated with corneal deposition.

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mucormycosis

Explanation:

Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Treatment of choice for Mucormycosis is amphotericin B, either alone or combined with surgical debridement to remove infected tissue.

 

 

Voriconazole

It is a triazole antifungal known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds.

MOA

Inhibits fungal sterol 14α-demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

Spectrum

Broad spectrum against various fungi

  • Candida albicans (Option A)
  • Candida tropicalis (Option B)
  • Aspergillosis (Option D)

Adverse Effects

Common: Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness.

Rare: Anaemia, neutropenia, cardiac arrhythmias, visual disturbances.

questions.text: A patient with gout develops hypertension. The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following antihypertensives should not be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydrochlorothiazide

Explanation:

  • Thiazide diuretics such as Hydrochlorothiazide should not be used in patients with gout as thiazide can increase uric acid levels by reducing its excretion from the kidneys.
  • MOA: Thiazide diuretics block the sodium-chloride (Na/Cl) channel in the proximal segment of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT).
    • Blocking the Na/Cl channel reduces sodium uptake into the cells
    • Decreases Na/K pump activity
    • Increases sodium and water retention in the tubule lumen.
    • Enhances calcium reabsorption via the Na/Ca channel in exchange for sodium returning to the DCT.
  • Thiazide increases direct uric acid reabsorption in the proximal renal tubule, which increases the serum urate levels, and it may precipitate gout.
  • Increased sodium delivery to the distal DCT and collecting tubule stimulates the aldosterone-sensitive Na/K pump.’

 

Atenolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker that is commonly used in the management of hypertension. It does not directly affect uric acid levels and is generally considered safe in patients with gout.

Enalapril (Option C) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that is commonly used for the treatment of hypertension. It does not have a direct impact on uric acid levels and is generally considered safe in patients with gout.

Prazosin (Option D) is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker primarily used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and hypertension. It does not directly influence uric acid levels, but it is not typically used as a first-line antihypertensive medication but can be used.

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic to the ER. The intern administered an analgesic, which worsened the pain. Which of the following drugs could be responsible for aggravation of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Morphine

Explanation:

The drug which is likely to have aggravated the patient’s symptoms is Morphine.

Morphine/opioids are generally not advised for colicky pain due to the following reasons:

  • Morphine constricts the sphincter of Oddi, leading to increased pressure in the common bile duct.
  • Pressure can increase more than tenfold within 15 minutes of morphine administration.
  • Increased pressure may worsen biliary colic symptoms, causing epigastric distress and severe pain.
  • Pethidine can be used as it causes lesser spasms of the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Diclofenac (Option B), which is a non-opioid analgesic such as may be considered an alternative option for pain relief in these patients as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi and can provide adequate pain relief.

Nefopam (Option C) is a centrally acting analgesic with muscle relaxant properties and is not known to cause sphincter Oddi contraction. However, it is not typically the first choice for managing biliary colic.

Etoricoxib (Option D) is a selective COX-2 inhibitor that can be considered as an alternative option for pain relief as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Promethazine

Explanation:

Promethazine is an antihistamine drug with antiemetic properties; thus, it can be used for motion sickness.

Mechanism of action of Promethazine:

  • M1 receptor and H1 receptors are present in the inner ear labyrinth, and they get activated when there is movement (during journeys) in the semi-circular canal ➞ activate the vestibular nerve ➞ stimulate CTZ in the brain ➞ nausea and vomiting.
  • M1 and H1 receptor blockers block this effect ➞ ⬇ stimulation of the CTZ ➞ Anti-emetic action.

 

Drug

MOA

Side effects

Promethazine

Antihistamine with antiemetic action

Drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Dimenhydrinate

An antihistamine with anticholinergic properties

Drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation

Meclizine

Scopolamine

Anticholinergic with antiemetic action

Drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

 

 

Cetirizine (Option A) is a second-generation antihistamine mainly used for allergies (e.g., rhinitis, urticaria). It does not have significant antiemetic or vestibular suppressant activity and is not used for motion sickness.

Mizolastine (Option C) is second-generation antihistamine for allergies like rhinitis and urticaria. It lacks central nervous system effects, and it is not used to treat motion sickness.

Loratadine (Option D) is a non-sedating antihistamine for treating allergic conditions. It does not effectively block vestibular pathways and is not indicated for motion sickness.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases to Beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Degradation of antibiotics

Explanation:

Resistance by lactamases against beta-lactam antibiotics is via degradation of the beta-lactam antibiotic.

ß-lactam antibiotics

MOA

ß-lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the transpeptidase via cleavage of the -CO-N-bond of the ß-lactam ring, thus inhibiting cell wall synthesis

Drug groups

1. Penicillin

2. Cephalosporin

3. Carbapenems

4. Monobactam (Aztreonam)

Resistance

It occurs through one of the four mechanisms:

  1. Modification of target PBPs (Option A)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Impaired penetration of drugs to target PBPs
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Antibiotic efflux (Option C)
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases (Option B)

ß-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivate ß-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the ß-lactam ring in their structure.

 

Alteration in the 50s ribosome structure (Option D) is seen with protein synthesis inhibitor resistance.

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the management of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chronic gout

Explanation:

  • Pegloticase is used in the management of Chronic gout.
  • It is specifically indicated for patients with severe gout who have not responded well to other treatments or who cannot tolerate other treatment options.

MOA: Metabolizes uric acid ,converts it into allantoin and excreted in urine, which helps to reduce the build-up of uric acid crystals in the joints and alleviate symptoms of gout

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine

  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) is not an indicated use for pegloticase. Rheumatoid arthritis is a different autoimmune condition that requires different treatment approaches using NSAIDs and DMARDs

Psoriatic arthritis (Option C) is also not an indicated use for pegloticase. Psoriatic arthritis is a type of arthritis associated with psoriasis and requires specific treatments targeting both joint inflammation and skin manifestation.

Paralytic ileus (Option D) is a condition characterised by the impairment of intestinal motility, and pegloticase is not indicated for its treatment. Paralytic ileus usually requires supportive care and addressing the underlying cause of the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rifampicin

Explanation:

  • Rifampicin is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis.
  • It binds to the beta subunit of DNA-dependent RNA-polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex that suppresses the RNA chain formation in RNA synthesis.

Name of drug

Rifampin
 

Mechanism of action

Interrupts RNA synthesis by binding to mycobacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Route

Oral

Cellularity

Intracellular and extracellular

Action

Bactericidal

 

RNA synthesis inhibitors

Drugs

MOA

Uses

Rifampicin

Inhibition of bacterial RNA polymerase

Antibiotic against Tuberculosis and Leprosy

Actinomycin

Inhibition of DNA and RNA polymerase

Anticancer agent

Alpha Amanitin

 

Inhibition of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II

 

Found in mushrooms, no therapeutic use

Triptolide

Traditional Chinese medicine

Amatoxin

Found in mushrooms, no therapeutic use

 

5-Fluorouracil (Option A) inhibits thymidylate synthesis, which interferes with DNA synthesis.

Nitrofurantoin (Option C) produces highly reactive intermediates that cause DNA damage.

Novobiocin (Option D) is a potent inhibitor of bacterial DNA gyrase, which is involved in DNA replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6-Mercaptopurine

Explanation:

  • 6-mercaptopurine, also known as 6-MP, is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis.
  • 6-MP is an antimetabolite that interferes with the synthesis of DNA by inhibiting the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is involved in the synthesis of DNA and RNA.
  • Mechanism of action:

 

 

Uses:

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) maintenance
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (off-label)

 

Mitomycin (Option B) is an alkylating agent that inhibits DNA synthesis by binding to DNA and cross-linking the DNA, preventing its replication.

Actinomycin (Option C) inhibits DNA synthesis by causing single-stranded breaks in DNA, and it prevents its replication.

Asparaginase (Option D) is an enzyme that depletes the amino acid asparagine. It does not directly inhibit DNA synthesis but affects protein synthesis by depleting asparagine, an essential amino acid for the growth of some cancer cells.

questions.text: Theophylline causes diuresis due to which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Adenosine antagonism

Explanation:

Adenosine antagonism because theophylline causes diuresis by blocking adenosine receptors in the kidney, which reduces sodium reabsorption and increases urine output.

Mechanism of Action of Theophylline:

  • PDE Inhibition: Nonselective inhibition of PDEs including PDE3, PDE4, and PDE5 increases intracellular cAMP and cGMP, leading to bronchodilation; PDE3 inhibition is a main mechanism of smooth muscle relaxation. (Option B & D)
  • Adenosine Receptor Antagonism: Blocks A1 and A2 receptors, reducing bronchoconstriction (via inhibition of histamine and leukotriene release). Also responsible for side effects like cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and diuresis.
  • Increased IL-10 Release: Enhances anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10, possibly via PDE inhibition.
  • Inhibits NF-κB Translocation: Reduces inflammatory gene expression, especially at high concentrations.
  • Promotes Apoptosis: Induces apoptosis in eosinophils, neutrophils, and T lymphocytes through A2 receptor antagonism and PDE inhibition.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) Activation: Enhances corticosteroid response by increasing HDAC2 activity via PI3K-δ inhibition at low therapeutic concentrations.

Beta 2 agonism (Option C) is not seen with theophylline, and it does not act as a beta 2 agonist.

questions.text: A female patient has been on first-line pharmacological therapy for bipolar disorder for the past 6 months. She has been fasting for the past few days due to religious reasons, and she was presented with seizures, coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs. Which of the following investigations should be done to aid in her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum lithium levels

Explanation:

Based on her medical history of bipolar disorder and her current presentation and fast condition, she is most likely suffering from Lithium toxicity.

  • Lithium is used as first-line treatment for bipolar disorder.
  • Fasting can significantly affect the lithium levels in the blood, as decreased food intake and altered electrolyte balance can lead to changes in lithium absorption and excretion.
  • Lithium toxicity symptoms:
    • Seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and weakness of limbs

Grade

Serum lithium (mEq/L)

Symptoms

Mild

1.5 - 2.5

Nausea, vomiting, tremor, fatigue

Moderate

2.5 - 3.5

Confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, hypertonia

Severe

> 3.5

Seizures, hyperthermia, hypotension, Coma
  • Causes:
    • Dose-related toxicity: Taking a higher dose of lithium than prescribed or recommended can increase the risk of toxicity.
    • ﻿﻿Impaired renal function: Lithium is primarily excreted by the kidneys, so any impairment in renal function can lead to reduced clearance of lithium from the body
    • Dehydration or electrolyte imbalances, seen in prolonged fasting, excessive sweating, or gastrointestinal disturbances, can disrupt the balance of lithium in the body and increase the risk of toxicity.
    • ﻿﻿Age and individual factors: Older adults and individuals with certain
    • medical conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, may be more susceptible to lithium

Serum potassium levels (Option A) can help detect hypokalemia or hyperkalemia, which can cause muscle weakness and arrhythmias but are not directly linked to lithium toxicity or fasting-induced seizures.

ECG (Option C) can help evaluate arrhythmias caused by hyperkalemia or other metabolic disturbances, but it does not directly confirm lithium toxicity.

MRI (Option D) could assess structural or neurological causes of seizures but is not a first-line investigation in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in first-line management of post-menopausal osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bisphosphonate

Explanation: ﻿﻿

Postmenopausal osteoporosis is a condition characterised by a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of fractures that occurs after menopause, and the first line of management is Bisphosphonates.

 

Bisphosphonates.

 

Bisphosphonates

1st generation

2nd generation

3rd generation
  • Etidronate
  • Clodronate
  • Alendronate
  • Risedronate
  • Ibandronate
  • Zoledronate
  • Pamidronate

Mechanism of Action

Direct inhibition of osteoclast activity and bone resorption.

Frequency of Administration

More potent drugs require less frequent administration

  • Alendronate: Given once a week.
  • Risedronate: Given once a week.
  • Ibandronate: Given once a month.
  • Zoledronate: Given once a year.

 

Uses of Bisphosphonates

Condition

Role of Bisphosphonates

Osteoporosis

Effective in preventing and treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, age-related, idiopathic, and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Paget's Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain, and improve secondary symptoms.

Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

Lower serum calcium levels, especially in severe cases.

Metastatic Bone Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions and reduce bone pain.

 

Adverse effects of Bisphosphonates

Bisphosphonates

Adverse effects

Etidronate

Interference with bone mineralisation, potential osteomalacia

Pamidronate

Thrombophlebitis, bone pain, fever, leukopenia, flu-like symptoms.

Alendronate

Esophagitis, gastric erosion, retrosternal pain, flatulence.

Ibandronate

Risk of flu-like symptoms with intravenous infusion.

Risedronate

Generally well-tolerated, potential for gastrointestinal upset.

Zoledronate

Severe hypocalcemia, nephrotoxicity, flu-like symptoms, osteonecrosis of the jaw.
  • Oral Bisphosphonates causes esophagitis: Should be administered on an empty stomach with plenty of distilled water. Patient should not eat anything and should not lie down for 30 minutes - To avoid reflux esophagitis.
  • Bisphosphonates are associated with an increased risk of Subtrochanteric femur fracture.
  • Bisphosphonates are C/I in renal failure.
  • Regular dental check-ups are advised to monitor for osteonecrosis of the jaw.

 

Estrogen (Option A) replacement therapy can prevent bone loss but is generally not first-line due to the risk of side effects like venous thromboembolism, stroke, and breast cancer. It is considered in select cases where additional menopausal symptoms (e.g., hot flashes) are present.

Raloxifene (Option C), a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), is used for vertebral fracture prevention but is less effective than bisphosphonates for non-vertebral or hip fractures. It is typically used as a second-line therapy or in patients who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates.

Combined oral contraception (Option D) is not indicated for the treatment of osteoporosis. They are primarily used for contraception and managing other hormonal conditions.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes developed postoperative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bethanechol

Explanation:

Bethanechol can be used for short-term treatment of postoperative urinary retention in a patient with diabetes.

Bethanechol

Bethanechol is a cholinergic agonist that stimulates muscarinic receptors, which are found primarily in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts.

MOA
  • Mimics the effects of acetylcholine, which plays a crucial role in the parasympathetic nervous system, at muscarinic receptors.
  • Upon stimulating muscarinic receptors, it promotes bladder muscle contraction, aiding in urine expulsion and reducing urinary retention.

Clinical Usage
  • Postoperative and Postpartum urinary retention with no actual obstruction.
  • Neurogenic bladder.
  • Symptomatic relief in congenital megacolon.
  • Gastroesophageal reflux

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Belching, involuntary defecation.
  • Urinary: Involuntary urination.
  • Other: Flushing, sweating, hypotension.

Contraindications
  • Mechanical obstruction of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract.
  • Asthma.
  • Hypotension.

 

Tamsulosin and terazosin (Option A and C) are alpha-1 adrenergic blockers primarily used to treat symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), such as urinary hesitancy, urgency, and weak urinary flow. They relax smooth muscles in the prostate and bladder neck to facilitate urine flow. While these medications may be beneficial for BPH-related urinary symptoms, they may not be as effective in treating postoperative urinary retention.

Methacholine (Option D) is not used for urinary retention. It is a cholinergic agonist primarily used in diagnostic tests to assess airway hyperreactivity, such as in the diagnosis of asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ranolazine

Explanation:

Ranolazine acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart.

Ranolazine

MOA
  • Inhibits the late sodium current in cardiomyocytes, which helps to reduce intracellular sodium accumulation during ischemic conditions
  • Indirectly reduces calcium overload in cardiac cells and improves myocardial relaxation, leading to an anti-ischemic effect.
  • It decreases ventricular diastolic tension, reduces myocardial oxygen consumption, and improves myocardial perfusion

Uses

  • Used as add-on therapy as an Antianginal agent for Chronic stable angina.
  • Reduces the frequency of angina pectoris and improves exercise tolerance.
  • Ventricular tachycardia.
  • Improves glycemic control (lower HbA1c and increase insulin)

Adverse effect

  • Dizziness, headache, nausea and asthenia
  • Constipation and Liver failure
  • QT-prolongation and rarely Ventricular arrhythmia such as Torsades de pointes.

 

Ivabradine (Option A) acts as a selective inhibitor of the pacemaker if it is current in the sinoatrial node, leading to heart rate reduction. It is primarily used for the treatment of stable angina and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

Trimetazidine (Option C) is a metabolic agent that improves myocardial energy metabolism by enhancing glucose oxidation and reducing fatty acid oxidation. It does not directly inhibit the late sodium current.

Fasudil (Option D) is a calcium channel blocker that primarily acts by inhibiting Rho-kinase, an enzyme involved in regulating smooth muscle contraction. It is mainly used for the treatment of cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid haemorrhage and is not directly related to inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) Insulin

Explanation:

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs)

  • Enzyme-linked receptors located on cell membranes.
  • Pass through the membrane once; the hormone-binding site is extracellular, and the catalytic site is intracellular.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Hormone Binding: Hormone binds to the extracellular part of the RTK.
  • Enzyme Activation: Binding activates or inactivates an intracellular enzyme. Some RTKs have intrinsic enzymatic activity, while others depend on associated enzymes.

Example: Leptin Receptor

  • Family: Cytokine receptors.
  • Hormone: Leptin (regulates appetite and energy balance).
  • Associated Enzyme: JAK2 (Janus kinase family).

Signaling Process:

  • Dimerization: Leptin binding causes receptor dimerization.
  • Phosphorylation & Conformation Change: Leptin binding alters receptor conformation, phosphorylating the intracellular part of the JAK receptor.

Intracellular Signaling:

  • Activated JAK2 phosphorylates tyrosine residues within the receptor-JAK2 complex, activating STAT proteins, which leads to target gene activation and protein synthesis.
  • JAK2 also activates additional pathways, including MAPK and PI3K.

Effects:

  • Rapid: Due to activation of the above-said intracellular enzymes.
  • Slower: Requires new protein synthesis.

Hormones Utilising Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling:

  • Fibroblast Growth Factor
  • Growth Hormone
  • Hepatocyte Growth Factor
  • Insulin (Option A)
  • Insulin-like Growth Factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

TSH (Option B), TRH (Option C), and MSH (Option D):

  • Belong to the family of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) and signal through G-protein-mediated pathways.
  • TSH acts on the thyroid gland to stimulate the production and release of thyroid hormones, while TRH regulates TSH release from the pituitary gland.
  • It is a peptide hormone that regulates pigmentation and is primarily involved in the activation of melanocortin receptors, which are also GPCRs.

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior to ACD for blood storage, except:

choices.text: The fall in 2,3 DPG is less
B) Improved Viability of Red Blood Cells

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) Increased Potassium Load

Explanation: CPDA (Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine) is best for blood storage for the following reasons:

  1. Ensures effective oxygen delivery: Higher 2,3-BPG concentration in CPDA-1 ensures that more deoxygenated haemoglobin is bound to 2,3-BPG, which is crucial for effective oxygen delivery to tissues.
  2. Facilitates oxygen release: The increased 2,3-BPG concentration decreases haemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, making it release oxygen more readily to the tissues.
  3. Optimises and promotes better oxygen delivery: The higher P50 levels in CPDA-1 indicate a rightward shift of the hemoglobin-oxygen dissociation curve, enhancing oxygen release to tissues.

 

Preservation Properties:

  • CPDA-1 is commonly used to store whole blood and red blood cells due to its superior preservation properties:
    1. Citrate: Acts as an anticoagulant by binding calcium and preventing clotting.
    2. Phosphate: Helps maintain pH balance and provides a source of cell energy.
    3. Dextrose: Is a nutrient that the red blood cells can metabolize for energy.
    4. Adenine: Is crucial for maintaining ATP levels, essential for cell energy and longevity.

 

Benefits:

  • The combination of these components in CPDA-1 allows it to preserve blood for up to 35 days, which is longer than other anticoagulants and preservative solutions like ACD, EDTA, and CPD. This makes CPDA-1 an ideal solution for storing blood for medical use.

questions.text: Sharp waste is disposed of in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) White bag

Colour

Type of waste

Example of waste

Treatment and disposal

Yellow (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste.
  • Soiled waste.
  • Discarded or expired medicine.
  • Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Chemical waste.
  • Chemical liquid waste.

 
  • Placenta.
  • Post-operative body parts.
  • Plaster of Paris (POP).
  • Pathological waste.
  • Cotton waste.
  • Dressing materials.
  • Beddings.
  • Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth.
  • Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover.
  • Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines.
  • Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste.
  • Blood bag
  • Vacutainers with blood

 
  • Incineration.
  • Plasma pyrolysis.
  • Deep burial.

 

Red (Option B ruled out)

 

Contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • Syringe without needles.
  • Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut.
  • IVset.
  • Catheters.
  • Gloves (soiled or unsoiled).
  • Urine bag.
  • Dialysis kit.
  • IVbottles.
  • Tubing's.
  • Bottles.
  • Vacutainers with needle cut.
  • Vacutainers without blood.
  • ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making.
  • Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites.

 

White (Option D)

 

Waste Sharps
  • Needles
  • Syringes with fixed needles
  • Blades
  • Scalpers
  • Trocar cannula
  • Insulin pen needle

 
  • Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers
  • Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete
  • Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit

 

Blue

(Option C ruled out)

 

Glassware or metallic body implants.
  • Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated.
  • Glass:
    • Broken glass.
    • Ampoules.
    • Lab slide
  • Metals:
    • Nails.
    • Metallic body implants.
    • Scissors.
    • Artificial pacemakers.

 
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured marking or blue coloured puncture- proof and tamper-proof containers.
  • Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling.

questions.text: Among the given options, which condition is expected to exhibit the greatest levels of ACTH and cortisol?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option D) Cushing's disease

Explanation:

Cushing’s disease:

  • It is a condition characterized by the overproduction of ACTH by a pituitary tumor (adenoma).
  • This excessive ACTH production leads to increased stimulation of the adrenal glands, causing them to produce and release excessive amounts of cortisol, a stress hormone.
  • Therefore, both ACTH and cortisol levels are elevated in Cushing's disease.

 

Corticosteroid feedback mechanism

 

  • Circadian rhythm: Diurnal pattern with peak in morning and low in evening, independent of external factors (Option A ruled out)
  • The adrenal cortex atrophies and becomes unresponsive to the ACTH for about six months after a prolonged treatment with steroids. (Option B ruled out)
  • Adrenal insufficiency is precipitated as a result.

 

Addison's disease (Option C): It is characterized by a deficiency of cortisol production due to adrenal insufficiency. In this condition, both ACTH and cortisol levels are decreased. ACTH levels are elevated as a compensatory mechanism to stimulate the adrenal glands, but the adrenal glands are unable to produce sufficient cortisol.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act 1948, what is the maximum number of work hours allowed per week, including any hours worked as overtime?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C) 60 hours

Maximum work hours per week including overtime work hours is 60 hours.

  • Hours of work:
    • 48 hours per week or 9 hours per day.
    • 60 hours per week including overtime.
    • 4 and ½ hours per day for adolescents.
    • Women and adolescents can only be employed between 6 am and 7 pm.

questions.text: Prolactin level is highest during?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option B) 24 hours after delivery

Explanation:

  • Prolactin is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland
  • its concentration in blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby (10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level)
  • Prolactin levels fall after delivery and the basal levels are low in postpartum period
  • Episodic rise is required for subsequent lactation and maintenance in the postpartum period, which happens during each act of suckling.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis

  • Screening immigrants for diseases like tuberculosis ensures the health of both immigrant and host populations and is an example of prospective screening.

Prescriptive Screening

Prospective Screening

  • Done for their own benefit.
  • Secondary level of prevention.
  • Early diagnosis.
  • Done for other's benefit.
  • The primary level of prevention.
  • Control/ prevention of disease.

E.g.

  • Screening neonates for neonatal hypothyroidism (Option B ruled out)
  • Deafness in children
  • Blood glucose testing for diabetes mellitus and gestational diabetes
  • Mammography for breast cancer
  • Pap smear for cervical cancer (Option A ruled out)
  • Visual acuity for refractive errors.
  • Urine sugar screening for diabetes (Option D ruled out)

E.g.

  • Screening of immigrants for diseases like TB and COVID (Option C)
  • HIV screening for blood donation
  • HIV screening in ANC cases
  • Health checkups for workers in the food industry.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 is primarily absorbed in the ileum of the small intestine and requires an intrinsic factor for its absorption.

 

Absorption of Vitamins:

Type

Vitamin

Primary Absorption Site

Mechanism of Absorption

Fat-Soluble

A

D

E

K

Small intestine (Duodenum, mainly jejunum).
  • Require bile salts for emulsification.
  • Incorporated into mixed micelles.
  • Absorbed by passive diffusion into enterocytes.
  • Packaged into chylomicrons for transport.

Water-Soluble

B Vitamins

 

Jejunum and Ileum.

(B12 specifically in ileum)

 

 

Various mechanisms include:

  • Active transport
  • Passive diffusion
  • Carrier-mediated transport
  • Sodium-dependent transport
  • B12 requires an intrinsic factor

C
  • Sodium-dependent active transport at low concentrations.
  • Passive diffusion at high concentrations.

 

Absorption of Iron:

  • Most dietary iron is ferric (Fe³⁺), and the absorbed form is ferrous (Fe²⁺).
  • Fe³⁺ is reduced to Fe²⁺ by gastric secretions and reductase activity in enterocytes.
  • Iron absorption occurs mainly in the duodenum via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1

Absorption of carbohydrates:

  • Maximum absorption occurs in jejunum > duodenum = ileum. No absorption in the colon

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused due to defective?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Type 2 pneumocytes

Explanation:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS):

  • It is primarily caused by a deficiency in surfactant, a substance crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli and preventing their collapse during exhalation.
  • Surfactant is produced by Type II pneumocytes.
  • Surfactant production begins by 20-24 weeks and matures by 35-37 weeks.

Type I pneumocytes (Option A): Thin, flat cells that cover the majority of the alveolar surface and are involved in gas exchange. This option is incorrect.

Alveolar capillary endothelial cells (Option C): Endothelial cells line the capillaries surrounding the alveoli and are involved in the exchange of gases between the alveoli and blood.

Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells (Option D): These are organized as a pseudostratified epithelium and contain several cell types (ciliated and secretory cells - goblet cells and glandular acini). It provides airway innate immunity and progenitor cells for repair during injury. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following a rapid ascent to over 3000 meters above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) IV digoxin

Explanation:

  • IV digoxin is not used in the treatment of the condition described. Digoxin is a medication commonly used for heart conditions such as heart failure and atrial fibrillation.
  • The symptoms point to Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS).

 

Acute Mountain Sickness

Symptoms
  • Headache
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia
  • Appear hours to days after rapid ascent

Pathophysiology
  • Associated with cerebral oedema, caused by increased capillary pressure in the brain due to dilation of blood vessels in response to low oxygen levels.
  • The increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier contributes to fluid leakage into brain tissue.

Treatment
  • Descending to a lower altitude (Option B ruled out)
  • Supplemental oxygen (Option C ruled out)
  • Acetazolamide to facilitate acclimatization (Option D ruled out)
  • In severe cases, corticosteroids may be used to reduce cerebral oedema.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option D) Enterogastric

Explanation:

Factors Inhibiting Gastric Emptying:

 

Factor

Mechanism

Acid in the duodenum

Releases secretin, inhibiting antral contraction and stimulating pyloric sphincter contraction

Products of fat digestion

Releases CCK and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Hypertonic solutions in the duodenum

Releases hormones inhibiting gastric emptying

Products of protein digestion

Releases gastrin, CCK, and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Large meal volume (solids)

Prolongs gastric emptying time

Stretching of duodenum

Initiates enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric emptying (Option D)

Sympathetic stimulation

Decreased gastric motility (by norepinephrine) and increased pyloric sphincter tone.

Hormones (CCK, GIP, secretin)

-

 

Gastrocolic (Option A): The Gastrocolic reflex is a reflex that stimulates colonic motility and promotes the movement of feces from the colon to the rectum when food enters in the stomach leading to distension.

Intestino intestinal (Option B): When a part of the intestine is over-distended, the rest of the intestine relaxes. This is called intestine intestinal reflex.

Gastroilea (Option C): The Gastroileal reflex is a reflex that stimulates the emptying of the ileum, the final portion of the small intestine, by relaxing the ileocecal valve. It is not directly related to gastric emptying or the entry of acidic content into the duodenum.

questions.text: What is the next course of action in managing a 24-month-old child weighing 11 kg who was presented to the pediatric OPD with a respiratory rate of 38/min and chest indrawing observed during examination?

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Oral amoxicillin for five days

  • A clinical scenario of a 24-month-old child having a respiratory rate of 38/min and chest indrawing is suggestive of pneumonia.
  • The management for pneumonia recommended is oral antibiotics for five days (Amoxicillin/ cotrimoxazole syrup) and home care advice.

WHO Classification of Pneumonia (IMNCI Guidelines)

Clinical Signs Classification Treatment / Action
No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no danger No pneumonia Home care, fluids, continued feeding, follow-up
Fast breathing and/or chest indrawing Pneumonia Oral amoxicillin, home care, follow-up
Any general danger sign* or stridor in calm child Severe pneumonia Injectable antibiotics, urgent referral to hospital 

*General danger signs: Not able to drink/breastfeed, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy/unconsciousness, stridor in calm child, severe malnutrition.

  • Revised WHO classification (and updated IMNCI guidelines) now include only two categories for pneumonia in children 2–59 months:
    • Pneumonia: Fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, without general danger signs- managed with oral amoxicillin at home.
    • Severe pneumonia: Any general danger sign or stridor in a calm child- managed with injectable antibiotics and urgent referral.
  • Oral amoxicillin has replaced cotrimoxazole as the first-line antibiotic for pneumonia.
  • Chest indrawing without danger signs is no longer classified as severe pneumonia; it is managed at home with oral antibiotics

Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately (Option B): Is recommended in case of severe pneumonia.

Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours (Option C): Is not a considerable option in case of pneumonia.

Start antipyretics urgently (Option D): Is not recommended in case of any pneumonia.

questions.text: Which functional area is most likely to be impacted by the vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus in this female patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Motor speech area

Explanation:

Brodmann’s numbers

Function

Location

BA 1, 2, 3

 
  • Primary Somatosensory Cortex
  • Processes tactile information from the body.

Postcentral gyrus.

BA 4
  • Primary Motor Cortex
  • Controls voluntary movements via corticospinal and cortico-nuclear tracts.

Precentral gyrus.

BA 8

  • Prefrontal Cortex
  • Involved in planning and decision-making.

The anterior part of the frontal lobe.

 

BA 17

 
  • Primary Visual Cortex (V1)
  • Processes visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus. (Option D ruled out)

Occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus, cuneus, and lingual gyrus).

BA 22
  • Language comprehension (Wernicke’s area) (Option B ruled out)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 41
  • Primary auditory cortex (Option C ruled out)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 42
  • Secondary auditory cortex

Adjacent to BA 41

 

BA 44 and 45
  • Broca’s area
  • Speech production. (Motor speech) (Option A )
  • BA 44 (Opercular part): Syntactic processing (grammar).
  • BA 45 (Triangular part): Semantic processing (meaning).
  • Left BA 44 is typically larger, reflecting language dominance.

Inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A maid is playing with a child by spinning him while holding his hands. A few hours later, the child starts crying, does not use his arm, and does not let anybody touch him. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pulled elbow

Explanation:

  • The condition indicates a pulled elbow (nursemaid’s elbow) caused by a sudden pull on the arm, leading to radial head subluxation. The classic arm position is slightly flexed and pronated.

Pulled Elbow (also known as Nursemaid’s Elbow)

Age group

1-5 years (most common)

Mechanism of injury

A sudden jerk or pull on the arm when it is extended and pronated causes the radial head to slip out of the annular ligament (radial head subluxation).

Clinical presentation

The child holds the affected arm close to the body in a slightly flexed and pronated position, resisting movement, particularly supination.

X-ray

  • Diagnosis is usually clinical.
  • X-ray is unnecessary unless there is suspicion of other injuries.
    • It may appear normal
    • If visible, they can show subtle displacement of the radial head, with the possible elevation of the anterior fat pad or visibility of the posterior fat pad, indicating joint effusion.

Treatment

Reduction of the subluxation by supination and flexion or hyperpronation of the forearm typically results in immediate relief.

 

Incorrect options:

Olecranon fracture (Option B): Caused due to fall on an outstretched hand or as a result of direct blow to elbow. May be transverse or comminuted fracture. Associated ulnar nerve injury can be seen.

Fracture head of radius (Option C): Common in adults, caused due to fall on an outstretched hand or fall over the elbow. CT/MRI may be required if X-ray is inconclusive.

Elbow dislocation (Option D): Common dislocation in children, caused by fall on an outstretched hand. The median nerve is most commonly injured.

questions.text: What is the duration of the extended sickness benefit provided to an employee who has been diagnosed with TB?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B) 2 years

  • The extended sickness benefit according to the ESI act of 1948 is for a period of 2 years at 80 % of daily wages.
  • It is provided for 34 Diseases including TB, leprosy, HIV and mental illness etc.

Benefits of ESI(Employees State Insurance) Act.

Medical Benefit
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit

Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.

Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilisation procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, eligible until age 18 or earlier for married daughters.

Funeral Expenses
  • Offers a cash payment up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment even after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month to avail this benefit.
  • Rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: A patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. A biopsy reveals Orphan Annie's eye nuclei, as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The above features and HPE showing psammoma bodies, nuclear grooves, and "Orphan Annie eye" nuclei indicate papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common type of thyroid cancer & characterised by lymphatic spread.
  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion.
  • Histopathological Features:
    • True papillae- Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core.
    • Orphan Annie eye nuclei - Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
    • Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
    • Presence of psammoma bodies- dystrophic calcifications
  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.

questions.text: In order to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in rural and urban areas, a research study was conducted. The study revealed that out of the total sample, comprising 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas, a significant proportion were found to be malnourished. Based on this information, which of the following statistical significance tests would be the most suitable in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Chi-Square Test

Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables. In this scenario, in comparing malnutrition rates among children in rural and urban areas, it analyzes if there's a significant difference in proportions between the two groups.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's T-test (Option B)

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's T-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option D)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Standard error of the mean (Option C): is a measure of the variability of sample means and is not directly applicable for comparing categorical variables or assessing differences between groups.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the following does not meet the criteria for metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) High LDL

According to the National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) criteria, the criterion that is not included in the definition of metabolic syndrome is: High LDL (Low-density lipoprotein)

  • NCEP-ATP III criteria include:
    • Central obesity (Option C)
    • Hypertriglyceridemia (Option A)
    • Hypertension (Option D)
    • Impaired fasting glucose or type 2 diabetes

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents with complaints of hematuria. On examination, he is normotensive and has pedal edema. Investigations reveal that the patient has no glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. His renal biopsy finding is given below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-GBM antibodies

Explanation:

  • The presence of crescents on the renal biopsy & clinical presentation suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
  • This condition can be caused by an anti-glomerular basement membrane (Anti-GBM). Anti-GBM antibodies are used to confirm the diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome, a form of RPGN.

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

Type I RPGN

(Anti-GBM Ab-mediated)

Type II RPGN

(Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)
 

 

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

 

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

 


Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) (Option A) are typically associated with systemic autoimmune diseases such as SLE. While SLE can cause glomerulonephritis and affect the kidneys, the presence of crescents on the renal biopsy suggests a more acute and rapidly progressive disease, making SLE a less likely diagnosis in this case.

HIV RNA (Option C): HIV infection can cause renal complications, including HIV-associated nephropathy, which is typically characterised by collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) on renal biopsy. However, the patient’s presentation with hematuria, pedal oedema, and crescent formation on the renal biopsy makes Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease) a more likely diagnosis than HIV-associated nephropathy in this case.

Urine immunoelectrophoresis (Option D) detects monoclonal immunoglobulins in conditions like multiple myeloma and amyloidosis. However, the biopsy findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which is better diagnosed with tests such as anti-GBM antibodies.

questions.text: The patient presents with a clean-cut injury that is not torn. He mentions receiving a tetanus vaccination approximately 10 years ago. What is the appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Single dose tetanus toxoid

  • According to the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, if a patient has received a complete primary vaccination series (usually consists of three doses) and has had a booster dose within the past 10 years, a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid is recommended for clean, minor wounds or injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Full course of tetanus vaccination & Tetanus toxoid + immunoglobulin (Option A and C): Since the patient's injury is clean-cut and not lacerated, a full course of tetanus vaccination or tetanus toxoid with immunoglobulin is not necessary.

Non vaccination needed (Option D): Non-vaccination is also not recommended as the patient's last dose was received 10 years ago, and a booster dose is required in this situation.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetation on heart valves is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infective endocarditis

Explanation:

  • Infective endocarditis is characterised by the presence of large, friable, and irregular vegetations on heart valves.
  • These vegetations are composed of a mixture of microorganisms, fibrin, and inflammatory cells.

 

Condition

Vegetations and site

Rheumatic heart disease

(Option B)

Small, warty, sterile vegetations along the line of closure of valve leaflets.

 

Infective Endocarditis

Large, bulky, infected, friable, irregular mass along the line of closure or on valvular cusps, more on the atrial side.

Non-bacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis

(Option D)

Small, bland, sterile vegetation along the line of closure.

 

Libman-Sacks Endocarditis

(Option C)

Small or medium-sized sterile vegetations on either or both sides of valvular leaflets, most commonly on the lower side.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit 48 hours after fracturing their femur, with a saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit at 100%, but their SpO2 remained at 60%? The patient is also experiencing confusion, and a chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism due to the combination of confusion, petechial rash, tachycardia, tachypnea, and low oxygen saturation following a femur fracture.

Fat Embolism
  • Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures.

Classic Triad
  • Hypoxia
  • Petechiae
  • Altered mental status

Other Symptoms

  • Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis).

Etiology
  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Pathogenesis

  • Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Investigation
  • Chest X-ray: Commonly clear lung fields, occasionally Snowstorm appearance is seen (pathognomonic)
  • PaO₂ <60 mm Hg
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO₂
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

Incorrect Options:

Pulmonary Embolism (Option B): typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and tachycardia, but lacks the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in this case. Additionally, the patient's history of femur fracture points more strongly to fat embolism rather than pulmonary embolism.

ARDS (Option C): typically presents with sudden onset breathlessness associated with hypoxemia and diffuse alveolar infiltrates on x-ray.

Occult Pneumothorax (Option D): presents with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds, which differs from the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in fat embolism, especially after femur fractures.

questions.text: What is the method of scoliosis measurement portrayed in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cobb’s angle

Explanation:

  • The method of measurement of scoliosis given in the image is Cobb’s angle used to measure the degree of deviation and severity.

Management of Scoliosis: (depending on Cobb’s angle)

Cobb’s angle

Management

< 20°

Observation

20-60°

Bracing (Milwaukee brace)

>60°

Surgical management

Various angles in Orthopaedics:

Cobb angle (Option A)

Scoliosis

Bohler angle (Option B)

Calcaneum

Ferguson angle (Option C)

Kyphosis

Baumann angle (Option D)

Elbow fracture

Q angle

Patella

Kite angle

CTEV (Congenital talipus equino varus)

Southwick angle

SCFE (Slipped capital femoral epiphysis)

questions.text: In a population study, if the mean value is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, what percentage of the population will fall within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 180-220

  • In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
  • Given that the mean is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, we can calculate the range within which 68% of the population will lie.
  • One standard deviation below the mean is 200 - 20 = 180. One standard deviation above the mean is 200 + 20 = 220.
  • Therefore, approximately 68% of the population will lie between 180 and 220.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. A duodenal biopsy shows crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in the lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Celiac disease

Explanation:

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • The immune response leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite.
  • On histopathological examination, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased CD8+ T lymphocytes in the lamina propria are classic features of celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

Synonym
  • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
  • Celiac sprue

Diagnosis

  • Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum

Serum markers
  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-most sensitive
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)-most specific

Histology
  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis),
  • Crypt hyperplasia (increased mitosis)
  • Villous atrophy (reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption)
  • Inflammatory cells infiltration

 

 

 

Environmental enteropathy (Option A) is a condition marked by chronic inflammation and structural changes in the small intestine. It is commonly seen in individuals from regions with poor sanitation and hygiene.

Whipple's disease (Option C) is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily affects the small intestine but can also involve other organs. The biopsy findings in Whipple's disease are different and typically show PAS-positive macrophages.

Chronic pancreatitis (Option D) is characterised by persistent inflammation and fibrosis of the pancreas, leading to impaired pancreatic function. It can cause malabsorption, but the biopsy would not show the characteristic findings of celiac disease, such as villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia.

questions.text: The variation in a data set is compared with that of another data set using?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Coefficient of Variation

  • The coefficient of variation (CV) is a statistical measure used to compare the variability of two or more data sets relative to their mean.
  • It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of a data set by its mean and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.
  • It's beneficial for comparing data sets with different units, indicating which has more or less variability relative to the mean.

 

Variance (Option A): Variance is a measure of the spread or dispersion of a single data set, not a comparison between two data sets.

Standard error of mean (Option C): The standard error of the mean (SEM) measures the precision of the estimated mean of a data set, not for comparing variation between different sets.

Standard deviation (Option D): The standard deviation measures the spread within a single data set without directly comparing variation between different sets

questions.text: A 3-year-old child has been brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash, and swelling of her hands and feet for the past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kawasaki disease

Explanation:

  • The classic features of this disease are the swelling of hands and feet, rash, and the other symptoms described in the case, making Kawasaki disease the most likely diagnosis.
  • It is an acute, febrile, usually self-limited illness of infancy and childhood associated with large- to medium-sized vessel arteritis.
  • 80% of the patients are younger than 4 years of age.
  • It presents with fever, conjunctival injection, desquamative rash, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema (strawberry tongue), and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Coronary arteritis can result in aneurysms that rupture or thrombose, causing myocardial infarction.
  • In genetically susceptible persons, a variety of infectious agents (mostly viral) have been posited to trigger the disease.
  • The vasculitis may result from a delayed-type hypersensitivity response directed against cross-reactive or newly uncovered vascular antigens.
  • Subsequent cytokine production and polyclonal B-cell activation result in autoantibodies to ECs and SMCs that precipitate the vasculitis.

 

Clinical Features

  • Mnemonic: CREAM-F.
    • Conjunctivitis (non-exudative & non-purulent).
    • Rash (Polymorphous, non-vesicular).
    • Edema (or erythema of hands & feet).
    • Adenopathy (Cervical, often unilateral & non-suppurative).
    • Mucosal involvement (Erythema or fissures or crusting at times, referred to as strawberry tongue).
    • Fever (Most important constitutional symptom).

 

The image below shows the strawberry tongue.

 

Measles (Option B) is a viral infection characterised by a maculopapular rash, Koplik spots in the mouth, and fever. It does not present with the swelling of hands and feet or the specific oral erythema seen in Kawasaki disease.

Scarlet fever (Option C) is caused by a group A Streptococcus infection, typically presenting with a sandpaper-like rash, fever, and sore throat. It does not cause the desquamative rash or the extensive lymphadenopathy seen in Kawasaki disease.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (Option D) is a small vessel vasculitis commonly presenting with purpura, abdominal pain, and arthritis. The signs of erythema of palms and soles and the specific rash described are not characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: How is the calculation of one variable using another variable typically performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Coefficient of Regression

  • The coefficient of regression, also known as the regression coefficient or slope coefficient, is used to calculate the relationship between two variables in a linear regression model.
  • It quantifies the change in the dependent variable per unit change in the independent variable, aiding in estimating or predicting one variable's value based on another's

.

The Coefficient of Correlation (Option A) measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

The coefficient of variation (Option C) measures relative variability between datasets, typically as a percentage, without involving the calculation of one variable using another.

The coefficient of determination (Option D) (R-squared) measures the proportion of variance explained by independent variables in a regression model, assessing goodness of fit without directly calculating one variable using another.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario with thyroid swelling and elevated TSH levels & presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies along with the presence of hurthle cells points towards Hashimoto thyroiditis.

 

Hashimoto thyroiditis:

  • An autoimmune disorder that causes chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism.
  • The characteristic features include elevated TSH levels (due to thyroid failure) and the presence of thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies, which attack the thyroid tissue.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.
  • It is characterised by painless enlargement of the thyroid, commonly in middle-aged women. The enlargement of the gland is generally symmetric and diffuse.
  • In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells, that represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury.

 

 

  • The thyroid parenchyma contains a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centres.

 

Graves' disease (Option B) is an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism, characterised by low TSH levels and the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), not thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Hurthle cells are not a feature of Graves’ disease.

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid (Option C) is a malignant tumour of the thyroid, usually presenting with a solitary nodule and not typically associated with Hurthle cells or elevated TSH levels. Histopathologically, it features follicular cells arranged in a follicular pattern, with capsular and vascular invasion.

 

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (Option D) is a neuroendocrine cancer arising from the C-cells of the thyroid, and it is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histopathologically, it features polygonal or spindle-shaped cells arranged in nests or follicles, with amyloid deposits often present.

questions.text: What are the most reliable indicators for regular monitoring of air pollution?

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

  • Sulfur dioxide (SO2): SO2 is a gaseous air pollutant primarily emitted from the burning of fossil fuels, particularly those containing sulfur. It is a major contributor to acid rain formation and can have detrimental effects on human health, especially respiratory health.
  • Smoke: Smoke is a visible product of incomplete combustion, often associated with burning of biomass or fossil fuels. It consists of solid and liquid particles, such as ash and soot, which can cause respiratory problems and reduce air quality.
  • Suspended particles: Suspended particles, also known as particulate matter (PM), refer to a mixture of solid and liquid particles suspended in the air. These particles can originate from both natural and anthropogenic sources and have adverse effects on human health when inhaled.

 

Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter (Option B): While these are indeed important pollutants, the inclusion of lead as an indicator for routine monitoring of air pollution is not common practice.

Sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide (Option C): While both SO2 and CO are air pollutants, they do not provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality on their own. Monitoring only these two pollutants would not capture the full range of pollutants that contribute to air pollution.

Carbon monoxide and hydrogen sulfide (Option D): While CO is an important pollutant emitted from combustion processes, hydrogen sulfide is not typically monitored as a routine indicator of air pollution.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency is commonly associated with macrocytic anemia, which is characterized by the presence of macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils on the peripheral blood smears.
  • It can be caused by atrophic gastritis, which leads to impaired absorption of B12 due to reduced intrinsic factor production. Atrophic gastritis is frequently seen in pernicious anemia, a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Causes of Vitamin B12 deficiency:

Reduced Dietary Intake

Increased demand

Impaired Absorption
  • Vegetarian diet
  • Pregnancy
  • Lactation
  • Growing child
  • Pernicious anemia (Option A)
  • Infections- Diphyllobothrium latum (Option C)
  • Gastrectomy (Option:D)
  • Ileal disorders
  • Malabsorption
  • Ileal resection
  • Diverticula of bowel

 

Folate deficiency (Option B) can cause macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils. However, it is less commonly associated with atrophic gastritis, and the absence of other features like neural tube defects (in pregnancy) makes it less likely in this case.

Pyridoxine deficiency (Option C) (Vitamin B6) deficiency causes microcytic anemia and not macrocytic anemia and is unlikely to explain the findings of macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils.

Niacin deficiency (Option D) (Vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterised by the "three D's": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It does not cause macrocytic anemia or hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: Which variable determines the disparity in disease occurrence between individuals who have been exposed and those who have not been exposed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Attributable risk

  • Attributable risk, or risk difference, measures absolute difference in disease incidence between exposed and non-exposed groups.
  • It directly captures additional risk of disease associated with exposure.
  • Calculated by subtracting incidence among non-exposed from incidence among exposed.

 

Relative risk (Option A): Relative risk compares disease incidence between groups but doesn't directly measure difference.

Population Attributable risk (Option C): Population Attributable Risk considers relative risk and exposure prevalence but doesn't quantify difference in incidence.

Odds Ratio (Option (Option D)): Odds ratio compares odds of exposure between cases and controls, but doesn't directly measure incidence difference.

questions.text: What type of study is it when a person collects data on lung cancer patients from government hospitals and the corresponding number of cigarette packets sold during the same time period, in order to examine the relationship between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Ecological

  • Ecological study examines relationships between variables at population level, not individual level.
  • Collects data on lung cancer cases and cigarette packet sales over a specific time period.
  • Analyzes associations using aggregate data, providing insights into population-level relationships.
  • Doesn't establish causation or provide individual-level associations.

 

Cross sectional (Option A): A cross-sectional study assesses the prevalence of variables in individuals at a specific point in time, not the relationship between variables over time.

Experimental (Option C): Experimental study involves manipulation of variables and random assignment to determine causation, not applicable here.

Quasi-experimental (Option D): Quasi-experimental study involves manipulation of variables without random assignment, also not applicable here.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

Explanation:

  • Hirschsprung disease arises when the migration of neural crest cells is arrested, causing a lack of ganglion cells (Option B ruled out) in the affected segment, leading to a lack of peristalsis in the affected bowel segment, causing functional obstruction and bowel dilation without inflammation or strictures (Option D ruled out).
  • This leads to aganglionosis, preventing peristalsis and causing bowel dilation.
  • Morphology: Histopathological confirmation involves identifying the absence of ganglion cells, and acetylcholinesterase staining aids in diagnosis. The disease typically involves the rectum, with short-segment or long-segment Hirschsprung disease based on the extent of involvement.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms include failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, constipation, and bilious vomiting.
    • Complications such as enterocolitis, perforation, and peritonitis can occur.
  • Surgical resection of the aganglionic segment is the primary treatment.
  • Acquired Megacolon: Acquired Megacolon, seen in conditions like Chagas disease and ulcerative colitis, may share a similar pathophysiology with Hirschsprung disease, particularly in cases involving the loss of ganglion cells.

Visceral myopathy (Option C) refers to smooth muscle dysfunction, which can affect gastrointestinal motility but is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schwannoma

Explanation:

Schwannoma is a benign tumour of the peripheral nerve sheath, characterised by spindle-shaped cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, which are pathognomonic.

  • Schwannomas are benign tumours originating from Schwann cells, often linked to mutations in the NF2 gene.
  • These tumours are well-circumscribed, encapsulated, and typically attached loosely to nerves, allowing for surgical removal without damaging nerve function.
  • They appear as firm, grey masses.
  • Histology:
    • Antoni A areas: Dense eosinophilic regions with spindle cells in intersecting fascicles.
    • Antoni B areas: Looser, hypocellular regions with a myxoid extracellular matrix.
    • Verocay bodies: Structures with central "nuclear-free zones" surrounded by palisading nuclei.
    • Schwann cells show spindle-shaped nuclei and immunoreactivity for S-100.

 

  • Degenerative changes:
    • Nuclear pleomorphism, xanthomatous change, and necrosis can occur.
    • Malignant transformation is rare, but large mitotically active schwannomas can resemble sarcomas.
  • Other features:
    • Schwannomas may recur if incompletely resected but rarely transform malignantly.
    • They can arise from sensory nerves, including branches of the trigeminal nerve or dorsal roots, and can occur both within and outside the nerve trunk.
    • Surgical removal is typically curative.

 

Neurofibroma (Option B) are benign tumours that develop from peripheral nerves. They are composed of a mix of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and other cellular components. Histologically, neurofibromas have a more varied appearance than schwannomas, with multiple cell types and no presence of Verocay bodies.

Neuroma (Option C) is an abnormal growth of nerve tissue caused by nerve injury or trauma. They are characterised by disorganised nerve fibres and can lead to symptoms such as pain, tingling, and sensory disturbances.

Glioma (Option D) are tumours that arise from glial cells in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Vaccine protocol followed after Disaster?

choices.text: Only the health worker given cholera, typhoid, tetanus toxoid

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Only the health worker given cholera, typhoid, tetanus toxoid

  • Health workers receive additional protection in disaster situations
  • Cholera, typhoid, and tetanus toxoid vaccinations provided to minimize infection risk
  • Ensures safety while providing medical care

 

Vaccination protocol post- disaster :

  • All vaccines except for measles are contraindicated post-disaster.
  • Multidose vaccines, such as typhoid and cholera vaccines, have poor compliance and have not yet proven to be effective as a large-scale public health measure.
