  • The most common post-disaster outbreak is measles. For this reason, measles vaccines can be given within three days of exposure since the time taken for antibodies to form is less than the natural incubation period of the disease.
  • Tetanus vaccine is given based on previous vaccinations and severity of injury.
  • Vaccines for healthcare workers: Cholera, Typhoid, Tetanus, Hep B.

 

Everyone is given diphtheria (Option A): Diphtheria vaccination likely already part of routine immunization schedules

Everyone is given tetanus toxoid (Option B): Tetanus toxoid crucial in disaster scenarios, especially for those with injuries

Everyone is given cholera vaccine (Option C): Cholera vaccination not typically administered to everyone in general disaster response

questions.text: Which compound is primarily responsible for the disinfectant properties of bleaching powder among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Hypochlorous acid

  • Bleaching powder, or calcium hypochlorite (Ca(ClO)2), serves as both a disinfectant and bleaching agent. When dissolved in water, it releases hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and hypochlorite ion (ClO-) as active disinfectants. Hypochlorous acid, primarily responsible for disinfection, acts as a potent oxidizing agent, effectively killing bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

 

Incorrect Option:

Hypochlorite ion (Option A): Bleaching powder releases hypochlorite ion (ClO-) when dissolved, but its disinfecting power mainly comes from HOCl, more effective due to superior antimicrobial activity than ClO-.

Hydrochloric acid (Option B): Bleaching powder doesn't contain hydrochloric acid (HCl). Its disinfecting property stems from chlorine compounds, primarily hypochlorous acid (HOCl), not HCl.

Chloride ion (Option D): Bleaching powder releases chloride ions (Cl-) when dissolved but disinfection is primarily from HOCl formed by hypochlorite ions reacting with water. Cl- lacks significant disinfecting properties

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old female who presents with a tumor located at the knee joint, as shown in the provided biopsy-image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant cell tumour

Explanation:

  • Clinical scenario and biopsy image showing multinucleated giant cells in the background of spindle cells is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT).

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > Proximal tibia > Distal radius > Sacrum

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

Incorrect Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Sunburst appearance on X-ray, seen in children. Biopsy shows cellular pleomorphism, osteoid formation with increased mitotic activity.

Ewing’s Sarcoma (Option B): Associated with fever, Onion peel appearance on x-ray. Small round blue cells, homer-wright rosettes are seen on biopsy.

Osteoblastoma (Option D): Decreased cellularity with lack of necrosis surrounding a well vascularised stroma on biopsy is suggestive of Osteoblastoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely cause for the complaints of a 9-year-old boy presenting with right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever, when the oral cavity examination shows no abnormalities in the external facial examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Quinsy:

  • Quinsy (Peritonsillar abscess): Quinsy is the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms. It typically follows an episode of acute tonsillitis and presents with fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing (odynophagia), pain referred to the ear, and trismus (difficulty opening the mouth).
  • The absence of abnormalities on oral examination and the external facial exam makes this a more probable diagnosis.

Pharyngitis (Option A): is incorrect because pharyngitis generally presents with sore throat and fever, but it typically does not cause significant difficulty in opening the mouth or severe ear pain as seen in this case. There is no mention of visible throat redness or swelling, which would be expected in pharyngitis.

Parotid abscess (Option B): is incorrect because a parotid abscess usually causes swelling in the parotid gland area, which is not described here. Though ear pain is a symptom, there is no external facial swelling or pus drainage from the duct, which are typical signs of a parotid abscess.

Bezold’s Abscess (Option C): is incorrect because Bezold's abscess is a deep neck abscess that occurs as a complication of mastoiditis, usually presenting with swelling in the neck or behind the ear. The absence of such features and mastoiditis symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely in this case.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitamin B3

Explanation:

  • Niacin toxicity (Vit B3) can lead to macular edema and cysts through increased prostaglandin synthesis, resulting in fluid accumulation in the retina.

Mechanism of Macular Edema and cysts:

  • Niacin can raise levels of prostaglandins, particularly prostaglandin D2 (PGD2).
  • Elevated prostaglandin levels lead to increased vascular permeability in the retina.
  • Increased vascular permeability causes fluid and proteins to leak into the retinal layers, resulting in macular edema.
  • Patients may experience blurred vision and distortion in their visual field.

Management:

  • Reducing or stopping niacin can resolve the symptoms.
  • Patients on high doses should be regularly monitored for ocular side effects.

Other effects of niacin toxicity includes:

  • Flushing: Caused by the release of prostaglandins leading to vasodilation.
  • Gastrointestinal Distress: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort.
    • Due to increased gastric acid secretion and irritation of the gastrointestinal lining.
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperurecemia

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IL-4

Explanation:

  • IL-4 plays a crucial role in the activation of B-cells to produce immunoglobulin E (IgE).
  • It is a cytokine primarily produced by Th2 helper cells, mast cells, and basophils.
  • IL-4 stimulates B-cells to undergo class switching to IgE, which is an important mediator in allergic reactions and responses to parasitic infections.

 

Interleukins in Type-1 hypersensitivity reaction:

Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

IL-2 (Option A) is primarily involved in the growth and proliferation of T-cells, especially CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells, and does not induce IgE production.

IL-1 (Option C) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that promotes fever and immune responses, but it does not directly induce IgE production.

IL-6 (Option D) is involved in the acute-phase response and the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it is not specifically involved in inducing IgE production.

questions.text: A graft from an identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Isograft

Explanation:

  • Isograft is a graft transplanted between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. Since there is no genetic difference between the individuals, the recipient's immune system typically does not recognise the graft as foreign, resulting in no rejection.

 

Type of Graft

Description

Autograft (Option B)

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself.

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

Allograft (Option A)

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals.

Xenograft (Option D)

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment).

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) L-Arginine

Explanation:

  • Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine by a group of enzymes called nitric oxide synthases (NOS).
  • The process involves the conversion of L-arginine to NO and L-citrulline.
  • L-arginine: It is the primary precursor for the synthesis of nitric oxide in the body. Nitric oxide synthases convert L-arginine to nitric oxide and L-citrulline in a reaction that requires oxygen and cofactors.
  • The synthesis of nitric oxide (NO) from L-arginine involves a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).

The general equation for NO synthesis is as follows:

  • L-arginine + NADPH + O2+ H* → Nitric oxide + L-citrulline + NADP+ + H2O

There are three isoforms of NOS:

  • Endothelial NOS (eNOS)
  • Neuronal NOS (NOS)
  • Inducible NOS (iNOS).

questions.text: What is the name of the surgical procedure performed to enlarge the cartilaginous segment of the outer ear canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Meatoplasty:

  • Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to enlarge the cartilaginous portion of the external auditory canal.
  • This procedure is commonly done when there is narrowing or stenosis of the ear canal, often due to chronic infections or congenital malformations.
  • The surgery involves removing a portion of the ear canal's walls to create a larger opening, which allows better access to the middle ear and improved drainage. It is often used to treat conditions like chronic otitis externa or to facilitate ear surgeries.

Tympanoplasty (Option B): is incorrect because tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to repair a perforated eardrum (tympanic membrane) or the bones of the middle ear, not to enlarge the ear canal.

Myringoplasty (Option C): is incorrect because myringoplasty is the surgical repair of a perforated eardrum, similar to tympanoplasty, but it does not involve enlarging the ear canal.

Otoplasty (Option D): is incorrect because otoplasty refers to the cosmetic surgical procedure that reshapes the outer ear, usually to correct protruding ears or deformities, rather than enlarging the ear canal.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tryptophan

Explanation:

Tryptophan has a strong UV absorbance at 280 nm due to its aromatic side chain.

  • Replacing alanine (which has low absorbance at 280 nm) with tryptophan will significantly increase the protein’s UV absorbance at this wavelength.
  • Tryptophan is non polar, hydrophobic and aromatic amino acid.
  • Involved in protein synthesis and neurotransmitter synthesis.

Absorption of UV light at different wavelengths:

  • At 280nm: Aromatic amino acids like tryptophan and phenylalanine
  • At 260nm: Purines and pyrimidines

Incorrect Options:

Leucine (Option A ): Leucine is also a non-aromatic amino acid and does not significantly contribute to UV absorbance at 280nm.

Proline (Option B): Proline is an imino acid and absorbs UV light at 260nm. Therefore, it would not increase the UV absorbance at 280nm wavelength.

Arginine (Option C): Arginine is a positively charged amino acid and does not possess an aromatic ring.It does not contribute significantly to UV absorbance at 280nm.

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following causes cough when the external acoustic canal is scratched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Auricular branch of vagus

  • Auricular branch of vagus (Arnold's nerve): Stimulation of the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, which supplies sensation to the external acoustic canal, can trigger a cough reflex.
  • This occurs due to the vagus nerve's involvement in reflex pathways, particularly through its connection to the cough center in the brainstem.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option A): is incorrect because the auriculotemporal nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the anterior auricle and external auditory meatus, but it does not typically cause coughing when stimulated.

Great auricular nerve (Option C): is incorrect because this nerve provides sensory innervation to the ear and the skin over the parotid gland but is not involved in the cough reflex.

Facial nerve (Option D): is incorrect because the facial nerve primarily controls facial muscles and taste sensation, and its stimulation does not trigger a cough reflex in the external acoustic canal.

questions.text: Which of the following features does the histology of the reperfused myocardium show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Eosinophilic contraction band

Explanation:

  • Eosinophilic contraction bands are a hallmark feature of reperfusion injury in the myocardium.

 

Reperfusion injury:

  • Intracellular calcium overload is the most likely the primary mechanism responsible for the reperfusion injury in this patient.
  • During PCI, reperfusion of the occluded coronary artery can lead to a sudden influx of calcium into cardiomyocytes, known as calcium paradox, which can cause cell injury and dysfunction.
  • This phenomenon is characterised by increased mitochondrial calcium levels, leading to mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening, mitochondrial dysfunction, and cell death.
  • The presence of 'Contraction bands' in cardiac muscle tissue serves as histological markers of reperfusion injury.

 

Morphological features of myocardium in MI:

Time

Gross Features

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Reversible Injury

0– 1/2 hour

None

None

Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

Irreversible Injury

1/2 –4 hours

None

Usually none; variable waviness of fibres at the border; myocyte vacuolisation

Sarcolemmal disruption;

mitochondrial amorphous densities (Calcium in mitochondria)

4–12 hours

Occasional dark mottling

Early coagulative necrosis, oedema, haemorrhage

 

12–24 hours

Dark mottling

Ongoing coagulative necrosis; pyknosis of nuclei; myocyte hypereosinophilia; marginal

contraction band necrosis; early neutrophilic infiltrate

 

1–3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct

centre

Coagulative necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations; brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils (Acute inflammation)

 

3–7 days

Hyperemic border; central

yellow-tan softening

Beginning disintegration of dead myofibers, with dying neutrophils; early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border (Chronic inflammation)

 

7–10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins

Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins (Repair)

 

 

10–14 days

Red-gray depressed infarct borders

Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

 

2–8 weeks

Grey-white scar, progressive from the border toward the core of the infarct

Increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

 

>2 months

Scarring complete

Dense collagenous scar

questions.text: The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RNA editing

Explanation :

  • Apolipoprotein B (apoB) is crucial in lipid metabolism, transporting cholesterol and triglycerides in the bloodstream.
  • It has two isoforms: apoB100 synthesized in the liver, part of VLDL, and apoB48 synthesized in the intestine, part of chylomicrons.
  • ApoB48 synthesis involves "A-to-I RNA editing," where a specific cytosine is converted to uridine, creating a premature stop codon and producing apoB48.
  • ApoB48 is found in chylomicrons, mediates the transport of dietary triglycerides from the intestine to peripheral tissues.

Incorrect Options:

RNA alternate splicing (Option A): While alternate splicing generates different mRNA isoforms, it's not directly related to apoB48 synthesis.

DNA editing (Option C): ApoB48 synthesis involves RNA editing, not DNA editing.

RNA interference (Option D): RNAi regulates gene expression but does not directly impact apoB48 synthesis.

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of tumours associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PML-RARA

Explanation:

  • All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is specifically used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), which is associated with the genetic fusion of PML (promyelocytic leukaemia gene) and RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) genes. The fusion disrupts the normal differentiation of promyelocytes, and ATRA helps reverse this block by promoting differentiation.

 

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: FISH
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

BCR-ABL (Option B) fusion gene is characteristic of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The treatment for CML typically involves tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib) rather than ATRA.

cMYC (Option C) is an oncogene often implicated in Burkitt lymphoma and other cancers, but it is not treated with ATRA. Treatment for cMYC-related tumours typically involves chemotherapy and targeted therapy based on the specific malignancy.

RUNX1-ETO (Option D) fusion gene is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), but it does not respond to ATRA treatment. Treatment for AML often includes chemotherapy and other agents.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Battle sign:

  • Battle sign: This is a clinical finding of bruising behind the ear, over the mastoid process, which can be seen after a skull fracture, particularly one involving the base of the skull. The bruising occurs due to blood collecting in the tissues around the ear, typically seen 24-48 hours after the injury. It indicates a possible underlying fracture of the temporal bone, often associated with damage to the middle ear and other structures.

Topic Explanation – Battle Sign:

  • Battle sign is commonly associated with basilar skull fractures, especially those involving the temporal bone.
  • The bruising occurs due to the leakage of blood from the middle ear into the surrounding soft tissue.
  • It is an important clinical sign to help identify skull fractures and potential trauma to the cranial nerves or other vital structures.

Bezold abscess (Option B): is incorrect because Bezold abscess is a deep neck infection that results from untreated mastoiditis, leading to swelling and abscess formation, not bruising behind the ear.

Mastoiditis (Option C): is incorrect because mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone, usually caused by untreated otitis media, and presents with pain, swelling, and fever rather than bruising behind the ear.

Griesinger sign (Option D): is incorrect because Griesinger sign refers to the presence of a high fever and a characteristic rash seen in meningitis, not a skull fracture or bruising behind the ear.

questions.text: In a patient with obstructive jaundice, which of the following outcomes may be observed in Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Direct Positive

Explanation:

Van der Bergh's reaction measures bilirubin levels in blood using diazotized sulfanilic acid.

  • It differentiates between unconjugated (indirect) and conjugated (direct) bilirubin.
  • Elevated direct bilirubin suggests excretion issue like obstructive jaundice. Elevated indirect bilirubin may indicate increased production or liver impairment.
  • Obstructive jaundice: Blocks bile flow, causing accumulation of direct bilirubin.
  • Van der Bergh's reaction in obstructive jaundice: Direct positive result due to increased conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted, and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, along with the presence of caseating granuloma (Characterized by central necrosis (caseation) surrounded by a ring of macrophages (epithelioid cells) and lymphocytes) in the biopsy, strongly suggests tuberculosis as the most probable diagnosis.

 

Type of Granuloma

Examples

Caseating Granuloma

Tuberculosis, Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis, Syphilis

Non-caseating Granuloma

Sarcoidosis, Crohn’s disease, Leprosy

Foreign Body Granuloma

Silicosis, Asbestos-related diseases, Foreign body reactions

Immune Granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis, Giant cell arteritis

Durck’s Granuloma

Cerebral malaria

Stellate Granuloma

Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Which is the enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

Explanation:

Glucose 6-phosphatase activated by decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio.

  • A decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio shifts the body from an anabolic state (storing energy) to a catabolic state (releasing energy).
  • This leads to activation of enzymes involved in pathways like gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, while suppressing enzymes in glycolysis and glycogen synthesis.
  • Glucose 6-phosphatase: Catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, the final step in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.
  • Regulation: Activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases to release glucose into the bloodstream for energy.
  • It is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting or catabolic states.

Incorrect Options:

Glucokinase (Option A): The gluckinase activity decreases with a decrease in the insulin: glucagon ratio.

Hexokinase (Option B): The hexokinase activity decreases with a decrease in the insulin: glucagon ratio.

Phosphofructokinase (Option C ): A decrease in the insulin: glucagon ratio decreases its activity. Phosphoructokinase activity is regulated by various factors, including ATP, ADP, and citrate concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following views involves an X-ray beam angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line is also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Water’s view

  • Water’s view: In this radiographic projection, the X-ray beam is angled at approximately 45° to the orbitomeatal line. It is primarily used to visualize the paranasal sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus, and the facial bones. The patient's head is positioned with the chin raised, and the X-ray beam is directed downward at this 45° angle to obtain clear images of the sinuses and the nasal cavity.

Topic Explanation – Water’s View:

  • Water’s view is a standard radiological projection used to assess the maxillary sinuses, frontal sinuses, and the nasal cavity.
  • The 45° angulation helps project the sinuses clearly, avoiding superimposition of the surrounding bone structures.
  • This view is often used in diagnosing sinusitis and other sinus-related conditions.

Towne’s view (Option B): is incorrect because Towne's view involves a different angulation, typically 30° to the orbitomeatal line, used for visualizing the occipital bone and posterior cranial fossa.

Law’s view (Option C): is incorrect because Law’s view is used for temporomandibular joint (TMJ) imaging, where the X-ray beam is angled at 15° to the horizontal plane.

Stenver’s view (Option D): is incorrect because Stenver’s view is used for imaging the temporal bone and inner ear, with the X-ray beam directed laterally at an angle to the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding competitive inhibition?

choices.text: The inhibitor binds to an allosteric site on the enzyme.
Competitive inhibition decreases the apparent Vmax (maximum reaction rate) of the enzyme.
Increasing substrate concentration can overcome competitive inhibition.
Competitive inhibition decreases the Km for the substrate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increasing substrate concentration can overcome competitive inhibition.

Explanation:

  • Increasing the concentration of substrate can overcome the competitive inhibition. It is more likely to outcompete the inhibitor for binding to the active site, allowing enzyme to function at its maximum rate.
  • Competitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition where a molecule (the inhibitor) competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Mechanism:

  • The inhibitor resembles the substrate and binds to the enzyme’s active site.
  • This prevents the substrate from binding, reducing the rate of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction.

Effect on Enzyme Kinetics:

  • Km (Michaelis constant): Increases because a higher substrate concentration is needed to overcome the competition.
  • Vmax (Maximum reaction velocity): Unchanged because at sufficiently high substrate concentrations, the inhibitor is outcompeted.
  • Reversibility: Competitive inhibition is reversible by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

Examples:

Competitive inhibitors

Clinical Correlation

Methotrexate and Dihydrofolate Reductase

Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor by mimicking dihydrofolate, the natural substrate of DHFR, and binding to its active site, thereby preventing dihydrofolate from binding and inhibiting the enzyme's activity.

Sulfa Drugs and PABA

Sulfa drugs, such as sulfanilamide, competitively inhibit the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase by mimicking para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), a substrate involved in folic acid synthesis in bacteria.

Ethanol and Alcohol Dehydrogenase

Ethanol can act as a competitive inhibitor of methanol metabolism by competing for the active site of alcohol dehydrogenase. This is used in cases of methanol poisoning.

Captopril and Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE)

Captopril competes with the natural substrate of ACE, thereby inhibiting the production of angiotensin II, a peptide that increases blood pressure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and the gross specimen showing
  • emphysematous damage involving the enlargement of the entire acinus are consistent with panacinar emphysema.
  • This pattern of emphysema is most commonly associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • Normal individuals have the PiMM genotype, while those with the disease have the PiZZ genotype.
  • This results in significantly reduced levels of functional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • Carriers possess the PiMZ genotype.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

 

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule. Based on the segments of the respiratory units that are involved, emphysema is subdivided into four major types:

Features

Centriacinar (M/C)

Panacinar

Paraseptal

Irregular

Involves

Proximal acinus

Proximal & distal acini

Distal acinus

Irregular involvement

Site

Upper lobes, especially apical segments

Lower zones & anterior margins of the lung.

More severe at the base of the lung.

The upper half of the lungs (more severe).

 

Airspaces can form cyst-like structures.

Any part of the lung can be involved.

Aetiology

Smokers

Chronic bronchitis

α1-antitrypsin deficiency

Spontaneous pneumothorax

Depends on involvement, most found in autopsy

 

The image below shows centriacinar emphysema.

questions.text: What does a correlation coefficient of less than 0.5 signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Weak Correlation

  • When the correlation coefficient is less than 0.5 (but greater than 0), it indicates a weak correlation between the variables.
  • This means that there is a relationship between the variables, but it is not very strong or significant.
  • The strength and direction of the correlation increase as the correlation coefficient approaches -1 or +1.

 

Confidence interval of 95% (Option A): This option is incorrect because the correlation coefficient measures the relationship between variables, while confidence intervals estimate a parameter's likely range.

Not statistically significant (Option C): This option is incorrect because statistical significance refers to the probability that the observed correlation is due to chance.

Strong correlation (Option D): Strong correlations typically have coefficients closer to -1 or +1, indicating a more pronounced relationship.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with the following X-ray finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Acute laryngotracheobronchitis:

  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): The "steeple sign" seen on the X-ray is characteristic of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup.
  • This sign refers to the narrowing of the subglottic airway, which appears as a "steeple" or "church steeple" shape on the frontal view of the X-ray.
  • Croup typically presents with symptoms such as a barking cough, stridor, and respiratory distress in children.

Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup):

  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is a viral infection most commonly caused by parainfluenza viruses, although other viruses like RSV can also cause it.
  • It leads to inflammation and swelling of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, which results in airway narrowing and the characteristic "barking" cough.
  • The "steeple sign" seen on X-ray is a diagnostic clue, reflecting subglottic narrowing, which is a hallmark of the disease.

Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Epiglottitis vs. Croup

Aspect

Acute Epiglottitis

Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Diagnosis
  • Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to prevent airway obstruction).
  • Lateral Neck X-ray: "Thumb sign" indicating swollen epiglottis.
  • Differentiated based on clinical features (e.g., absence of drooling, voice quality).
  • The "steeple sign" on an X-ray AP view shows a narrowing of the upper airway, often seen in croup.

X-Ray Imaging

Hospitalisation

Required due to the high risk of airway obstruction.

Often necessary due to potential breathing difficulties.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Parenteral administration (e.g., ampicillin, third-generation cephalosporins).
  • Steroids: Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone to reduce oedema.
  • Hydration: IV fluids if needed.
  • Humidified Oxygen: Via mist tent or croupette.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: In cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Antibiotics: Ampicillin 50 mg/kg/day against the H. influenza virus.
  • Humidification: Helps clear crusts and thick secretions that block the tracheobronchial tree.
  • Steroids: to reduce oedema.
  • Racemic Epinephrine: Used as a bronchodilator.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: Considered if obstruction worsens or lasts beyond 72 hours. 

Acute epiglottitis (Option B)- is incorrect because while epiglottitis causes airway obstruction, it is typically associated with a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the "steeple sign." This condition presents more acutely with drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a high fever.

Acute pharyngitis (Option C)- is incorrect because acute pharyngitis does not cause a narrowing of the airway as seen in croup, and it does not present with the characteristic X-ray findings like the "steeple sign."

Parapharyngeal abscess (Option D)- is incorrect because a parapharyngeal abscess would present with different symptoms, such as fever, neck swelling, and difficulty swallowing, but it does not typically cause the "steeple sign" on X-ray.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Niacin

Explanation:

  • Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Dermatitis: Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet).Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
    • Diarrhoea
    • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
    • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
    • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
    • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
    • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
  • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
  • Malabsorption Syndromes

Incorrect Options:

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option B) can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, neurological issues, and anaemia. However, it is not typically associated with the specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and cognitive disturbances seen in this case.

Rickets (Option C) resulting from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, present with bone deformities and growth retardation. It is not associated with dermatitis, diarrhoea, and neurological symptoms characteristic of pellagra.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option D) can cause fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath but does not typically present with skin rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, or cognitive issues associated with pellagra.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the worsening neurological symptoms in a 30-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fatigue, difficulty breathing during exertion, weight loss, and frequent falls, and was found to have bilateral decrease in vibration sense, a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g% with high MCV, and was initially treated with folate which improved her anemia?

choices.text: Folic acid therapy unmasked pyridoxine deficiency.
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS.
Folate therapy caused rapid use of vitamin B12 stores aggravating symptoms.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Folate therapy caused rapid use of vitamin B12 stores aggravating symptoms

Explanation:

  • These are classic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, which leads to impaired DNA synthesis (macrocytic anemia) and demyelination (peripheral neuropathy).

Folate supplementation in isolation:

  • Folate can improve the hematologic symptoms (macrocytic anemia) by bypassing the impaired DNA synthesis caused by B12 deficiency.
  • However, folate does not address the neurologic symptoms caused by the lack of B12, which are due to accumulation of methylmalonic acid and demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

Mechanism of worsening symptoms:

  • When folate is supplemented without correcting B12 deficiency, it increases the demand for B12 in the methylation cycle (conversion of homocysteine to methionine).
  • This depletes the already low B12 stores, worsening the neurologic symptoms, despite initial improvement in anemia.

questions.text: The family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant

Explanation:

  • The disease is transmitted from father to son, ruling out X-linked inheritance & the condition appears in every generation, with both males & females affected, suggesting an autosomal dominant pattern.

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern:

  • The mode of transmission is vertical. An affected person has an affected parent.
  • There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring.
  • Both males and females are equally affected.
  • The dominant gene is expressed in heterozygotes.
  • Delayed age of onset.
  • The trait appears in every generation without skipping.
  • An unaffected offspring does not transmit the disease.

Examples of autosomal dominant disorders:

Mnemonic

Disease

He
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia
  • Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC/Lynch syndrome)

Has
  • Huntington’s disease
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

A

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Very
  • Von Willebrand disease
  • Von Hippel Lindau syndrome

Dominant
  • Dystonia myotonica
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Marfan’s syndrome
  • Intermittent porphyria
  • NF-1 & 2
  • Achondroplasia
  • Noonan syndrome
  • Tuberous sclerosis

Powerful
  • Pseudohypoparathyroidism

Father
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis
  • Li Fraumeni syndrome
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia

questions.text: Which investigation yields the most precise prognostic information for predicting the risk of perioperative cardiac complications among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

Explanation:

  • Dobutamine stress echocardiography provides precise prognostic information for perioperative cardiac complications by directly assessing myocardial function under stress conditions. It evaluates myocardial ischemia and viability, which are critical for assessing perioperative cardiac risk, especially in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

Key points:

  • High sensitivity: Dobutamine stress echocardiography is highly sensitive in detecting inducible ischemia, a critical predictor of perioperative cardiac complications.
  • Risk stratification: It aids in stratifying patients undergoing major noncardiac surgery by assessing cardiac function under stress, ensuring appropriate management and intervention.
  • Proven efficacy: Studies demonstrate its superior ability to predict postoperative outcomes compared to traditional clinical assessments, enhancing decision-making and patient safety.

Incorrect Options:

Exercise ECG testing (option A): While useful in detecting ischemic changes during physical stress, it has lower sensitivity and specificity compared to imaging modalities. It is also less effective in patients unable to exercise adequately or with baseline ECG abnormalities.

Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy (option C): This test evaluates myocardial perfusion and ischemia but is less commonly used compared to stress echocardiography for perioperative cardiac risk stratification. It is more useful for chronic ischemia than acute risk prediction.

Coronary angiography (option D): While this is the gold standard for diagnosing coronary artery disease, it is invasive and not typically used solely for perioperative risk assessment unless clinically indicated, such as in symptomatic or high-risk patients.

questions.text: What could be the probable reason for the observed result in the capnograph of a patient who is intubated and undergoing controlled ventilation?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

Explanation:

  • During controlled ventilation, spontaneous respiratory effort occurs when the patient attempts to breathe independently, alongside ventilator-delivered breaths. This typically results from insufficient sedation or inadequate neuromuscular blockade.
  • Curare notch: Spontaneous effort during the plateau phase disrupts CO₂ exhalation, creating a characteristic curare notch in the capnograph waveform. This indicates patient-initiated breaths superimposed on ventilator-delivered breaths.

Incorrect Options:

Esophageal intubation (Option A) produces an abnormal capnograph waveform with minimal or no CO₂ detection. However, it does not explain the curare notch, which is specifically associated with spontaneous respiratory efforts.

Inspiration with cardiac oscillations (Option B): Cardiac oscillations near the endotracheal tube during inspiration may cause small, irregular fluctuations in the CO₂ waveform. However, they do not produce the distinct curare notch observed during the plateau phase.

Bronchospasm (Option C) alters the capnograph waveform by prolonging expiration and flattening or reducing CO₂ levels. However, it does not cause the curare notch, which is specific to spontaneous breathing efforts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with chest pain, recurrent heartburn, and dysphagia. A barium swallow shows a bird beak sign. Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal esophagus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal esophagus

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation & the bird beak sign on barium swallow suggests achalasia, a condition characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and an absence of peristalsis in the distal esophagus.
  • It is caused by a decreased release of nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), which are essential for smooth muscle relaxation. This results in increased tone of the LES and impaired peristalsis.

 

Achalasia:

  • Pathology:
    • Incomplete LES relaxation/Increased LES tone/Aperistalsis of the esophagus
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), Difficulty in belching, Chest pain
  • Primary Achalasia:
    • It is caused by degeneration of nitric oxide-producing neurons that normally induce LES relaxation.
    • Degeneration of the extraesophageal vagus nerve or dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus may occur.
  • Secondary Achalasia:
    • Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi infection) destroys the myenteric plexus, leading to peristalsis failure and esophageal dilation.
    • Associated with conditions like:
      • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy
      • Infiltrative disorders (e.g., malignancy, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis)
      • Systemic sclerosis
      • Dorsal motor nuclei lesions (post-polio)
      • Down syndrome or Allgrove syndrome (achalasia, alacrima, ACTH-resistant adrenal insufficiency).
  • Some cases linked to HSV1 infection, immunoregulatory gene polymorphisms, Sjögren syndrome, or autoimmune thyroid disease, suggesting immune-mediated destruction of inhibitory esophageal neurons.
  • Treatment:
    • Laparoscopic myotomy
    • Pneumatic balloon dilation
    • Botulinum neurotoxin (Botox) injections to inhibit cholinergic neuron contraction.

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Neostigmine

Explanation:

The drug commonly used postoperatively to reverse muscle weakness induced by a nicotinic receptor antagonist (such as a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent) is Neostigmine.

  • Neostigmine:
    • An acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
    • This facilitates the activation of nicotinic receptors, effectively reversing the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium, vecuronium) and restoring normal muscle function.
  • Neostigmine is often co-administered with an anticholinergic agent (e.g., glycopyrrolate or atropine) to counteract muscarinic side effects such as bradycardia and excessive salivation.
  • It is specifically effective against non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers and is not used for depolarizing agents like succinylcholine.

Incorrect Options:

Physostigmine (Option A): Although physostigmine is also a cholinesterase inhibitor, it primarily crosses the blood-brain barrier and is used to reverse central nervous system effects of anticholinergic toxicity. It is not routinely used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Carbachol (Option C) is a direct cholinergic agonist that mimics acetylcholine. It is used in ophthalmology (e.g., for glaucoma) but not for reversing the effects of muscle relaxants.

Succinylcholine (Option D) is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker used to induce paralysis during short procedures. It is not used to reverse muscle relaxation and may even worsen weakness if given postoperatively.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Huntington's chorea?

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is a loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal length repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to a defect in chromosome 6

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

Explanation:

Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by the expansion of the CAG repeat in the HTT gene on chromosome 4.

Huntington's disease: HD is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the degeneration of striatal neurons, leading to a progressive movement disorder and dementia. Symptoms include chorea, bradykinesia, and rigidity. It is relentlessly progressive and fatal, typically over 15 years.

  • Pathogenesis:
    • HD is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease caused by a CAG repeat (Option C) in the HTT gene on chromosome 4p16.3 (Option D), encoding huntingtin protein.
    • Normal HTT genes have 6 to 35 CAG repeats, while pathogenic mutations have expanded repeats, leading to earlier disease onset with paternal transmission causing anticipation & the toxic gain-of-function (Option B) of mutant huntingtin is believed to be the primary pathogenic mechanism.
  • Morphology:
    • The brain exhibits atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen, along with ventricular dilation.
    • There is a loss of striatal neurons, particularly affecting GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen.
    • Gliosis is more extensive than usual due to neuronal loss.
  • Clinical features:
    • The loss of striatal neurons results in increased motor activity, causing choreoathetosis. Cognitive decline follows, with symptoms such as forgetfulness and dementia.
    • The disease usually manifests in the fourth or fifth decade, and motor symptoms typically precede cognitive symptoms.
    • The leading cause of death is often pneumonia, especially in advanced stages. Suicide rates are higher in HD patients.

questions.text: A deceased male was brought to the morgue for a post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Lymph nodes

Explanation:

  • When a tattoo is present on the skin of a deceased individual but cannot be found during the post-mortem examination, it is important to examine the regional lymph nodes. This is because tattoo pigments can be transported by the lymphatic system and accumulate in the adjacent lymph nodes.

Tattoos in Identification

Age of tattoo
  • Firm union, reddish/bluish scar: 5-6 days
  • Pale, soft and sensitive (tender): 2 weeks-2 months
  • Tough, brownish, glistening, wrinkled and little tender: 2-6 months
  • Tough, white, glistening and non-tender: > 6 months

Dyes Used
  • Common dyes: Indigo, cobalt, carbon, vermilion, cadmium, selenium, Prussian blue and Indian ink
  • Black, blue and red dyes are most commonly employed
  • Depth of penetration: 50-3000 times a minute
  • Pigment can migrate to nearby lymph nodes (Option C)

Erasure Methods

Surgical methods:

  • Dermabrasion (e.g., tannic acid, silver nitrate, trichloroacetic acid)
  • Complete excision and skin grafting

Non-surgical methods:

  • Production of burns by means of red hot iron
  • Scarification
  • Using carbon dioxide snow
  • Electrolysis
  • Caustic or corrosive substances
  • Chronic eczema may cause tattoo designs to disappear

Incorrect Options:

Liver (Option B) is a vital organ involved in various metabolic functions, detoxification, and bile production. While the liver can be examined during a post-mortem examination for any signs of disease or abnormalities, it does not have a direct relationship with the presence or absence of a tattoo. Examining the liver would not reveal any information about the missing tattoo.

Arteries (Option C) are blood vessels responsible for carrying oxygenated blood from the heart to various parts of the body. While examining the arteries can provide information about the overall vascular health and potential causes of death, they are not directly related to the presence or disappearance of a tattoo. Examining the arteries would not provide any information about the missing tattoo.

Skin (Option D) is the outermost layer of the body and the site where tattoos are typically made. When investigating the absence of a tattoo, examining the skin itself is not the most appropriate approach.

questions.text: In relation to the punishment of perjury, which specific section of the IPC addresses this matter?

questions.text: In the OPD, a 5-year-old child presenting with a past medical record of perianal pain is examined. Upon testing a sample obtained from the perianal region, it reveals the presence of yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the specific diagnostic procedure used to identify this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Barberio test

Explanation:

  • Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals, is used to identify the seminal fluid in this condition.
  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Test Name

Substance Detected

Result

Reagent Used

Mnemonic

Notes

Barberio Test

Spermine

Yellow needle-shaped crystals of Spermine Picrate

Picric acid

Barbar picks your hair with a needle

Detects Spermine from the prostate; confirms the presence of seminal fluid.

Florence Test

Dark brown rhombic crystals of Choline iodide

KI (Potassium Iodide)

Florence has 'C', C for Choline

It detects choline from the seminal vesicle and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Florence Test (Option B): This test detects choline and produces different crystal formations (dark brown rhombic crystals).

Takayama test (Option C): Similar to the Teichmann test, the Takayama test is used for hemoglobin detection.

Teichmann test (Option D): This test detects hemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

questions.text: Typically, what is the condition of the hymen in cases of sexual assault involving a young child?

choices.text: Ruptured since it is located superficially
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Unruptured since it is deeply situated

Explanation:

  • In cases of rape or sexual abuse of a young child, the hymen is more likely to be unruptured rather than ruptured.
  • This is because the hymen is situated deeper inside the vaginal canal in children and is not easily accessible or visible externally.

Incorrect Options:

Ruptured since it is superficially ( (Option A): The hymen is not superficially located in children. It is positioned deeper inside the vagina.

Ruptured since it is very thin (Option B): While the hymen is thin, its thinness does not necessarily imply that it will be ruptured in cases of rape or sexual abuse.

Unruptured since it is highly elastic (Option D): The elasticity of the hymen enables it to stretch, but it does not guarantee that it will remain unruptured in cases of sexual abuse

  • These findings indicate that the child's skeletal development is consistent with an age of approximately 13 years.

The capitate and hamate bones ossify during infancy, with the capitate appearing first at 36th week(3-4 months age). Between ages 2 and 6, the number of visible carpal bones on an X-ray roughly corresponds to the child's age (e.g., 3 carpal bones indicate approximately 3 years old).

Incorrect Options:

4 years (Option A) By the age of 4 years, the carpal bones in the hand would not be fully developed, and the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal would not be fused.

7 years (Option B) By the age of 7 years, most of the carpal bones would be visible on X-ray, but the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal would usually not be fused.

questions.text: Please determine the medication utilized for the management of the presented medical condition:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Anti-tubercular therapy

Explanation:

  • The image shows annular plaque with central scarring which is suggestive of Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It presents as a chronic, slowly progressive skin lesion with an annular (ring-shaped) plaque and central scarring.
  • Anti-tubercular therapy: Anti-tubercular therapy is the treatment of choice for lupus vulgaris. It consists of a combination of drugs, including isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. These medications target Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative organism, and aim to eradicate the infection.

Cutaneous TB:

Exogenous:

Endogenous:
  • Source of MTB is from outside the body
  • First exposure to TB - new to TB infection is Naive infection
    • Called TB chance
    • No immunity
  • Once had TB but now recurred due to Exogenous causes:
    • Tuberculosis Verrucous cutis (TBVC)
    • Immunity present
  • Source is within the body
  • Transmitted to skin by:
    • Contiguous (ex: lymphatic TB breaking into skin) - Scrofuloderma
    • Hematogenous - Lupus vulgaris, TB gumma and miliary TB
    • Auto miliary TB
    • Auto inoculation - or Orificial TB

1. TB Chancre / Primary Inoculation TB

2. TBVC or Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis

1. Lupus Vulgaris

Apple jelly nodules on diascopy

2. Scrofuloderma

3. Orificial Tuberculosis

Management

  • All forms of cutaneous TB have the same treatment.
  • Total 6 months treatment:
    • 2 months: Intensive phase = HERZ for 2 months.
    • 4 months: Maintenance phase = HRE for 4 months.
  • HERZ = Isoniazid, ethambutol, rifampicin and pyrazinamide.
  • Doses
    • Isoniazid (H): 5mg/kg/day
    • Rifampicin = 10 mg/kg/day
    • Ethambutol (E): 15 mg/kg/day
    • Streptomycin (S): 15 mg/kg/day
    • Pyrazinamide (P): 25 mg/kg/day


Incorrect Options:

Anti-fungal therapy (Option A) is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris. While superficial fungal infections can also present as annular lesions, the clinical presentation and diagnostic criteria mentioned in the question suggest a mycobacterial infection rather than a fungal infection.

Topical steroids therapy (Option C): Topical steroid therapy is not the primary treatment for lupus vulgaris. While topical steroids may be used in some cases to alleviate inflammation and itching, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection and are not the mainstay of treatment.

Anti-leprosy treatment (Option D): Anti-leprosy treatment is not the correct choice for lupus vulgaris. Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, is a separate disease entity and requires specific anti-leprosy drugs for treatment. It is not indicated for the management of lupus vulgaris.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Herpes labialis

Explanation:

  • Herpes labialis, commonly known as cold sores or fever blisters, is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).
  • The characteristic presentation of multiple vesicles and crusts clustered on an inflamed base around the lips is indicative of a herpes simplex virus infection. Occurs on the vermillion border of lips.
  • Recurrent outbreaks are common, often triggered by factors such as stress, sun exposure, or fever.

Incorrect Options:

Herpangina (Option B): It typically presents as small, painful ulcers or vesicles on the back of the throat, soft palate, or tonsillar pillars.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C): It typically presents as small, raised, dome-shaped papules with a central indentation (umbilication). The lesions are usually flesh-colored

Impetigo (Option D): It commonly presents as honey-colored crusts or bullae on an erythematous base.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis for a child born with membranes around the body, ectropion, and eclabium, presenting with lesions on the face, trunk, and extremities, and brought to the OPD, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Harlequin ichthyosis

Explanation:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is likely a diagnosis based on the image shown.

Harlequin Ichthyosis

Introduction

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is a rare, severe genetic skin disorder characterized by thick, armor-like scales covering the body at birth. It is an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the ABCA12 gene, affecting lipid transport in the epidermis.

Pathophysiology

  • ABCA12 gene mutation leads to defective lipid transport, disrupting the skin barrier.
  • This results in thickened, hyperkeratotic plates with deep fissures, severe dehydration, and increased infection risk.

Features

  • Thick, diamond-shaped scales covering the body
  • Ectropion (everted eyelids) and eclabium (everted lips)
  • Contracted digits (hypoplastic fingers and toes)
  • Risk of severe dehydration, infections, and respiratory distress
  • Delayed skin shedding, improving with time but requiring lifelong care

Investigations & Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination based on characteristic features at birth
  • Genetic testing to confirm ABCA12 mutation
  • Skin biopsy (rarely needed) shows massive hyperkeratosis

Treatment

  • Neonatal intensive care (hydration, temperature regulation)
  • Emollients and keratolytics (e.g., petrolatum, urea, lactic acid) to soften scales
  • Oral retinoids (e.g., acitretin, isotretinoin) to reduce hyperkeratosis
  • Antibiotics for secondary infections
  • Lifelong skin care with moisturization and gentle exfoliation

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis:

Subtype

Clinical Features

Genetic Defect

Harlequin ichthyosis

Thick, plate-like scales covering the entire body

ABCA12 gene mutations

Lamellar ichthyosis (Option B)

Large thick scales, often present at birth

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)

Generalized redness, fine white scales

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Self-healing collodion baby

Membrane-like encasement at birth, followed by shedding

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Harlequin ichthyosis-like phenotypes

Variations resembling harlequin ichthyosis

Different genetic mutations, including PNPLA1, CYPF22, CASP14, CERS3, etc.

Incorrect Options:

Bathing suit ichthyosis (Option C): A rare variant of lamellar ichthyosis where scaling predominantly affects the trunk and proximal limbs, sparing other areas, resembling a "bathing suit" pattern.

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option D): A common inherited skin disorder characterized by fine, dry, scaly skin, especially on the extensor surfaces, due to filaggrin gene mutations leading to impaired skin barrier function.

questions.text: Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017, what is the longest duration for which an individual can voluntarily admit themselves for mental health treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 30 days:

  • Section 86 of the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017 stipulates that a person who voluntarily admits themselves to a psychiatric facility can be kept for treatment for a maximum period of 30 days. After this, the individual must be reassessed, and a formal review is required if further treatment is necessary.

Admission of patients with mental illness according to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017

Section 85

Admission of a person with mental illness as an independent patient in a mental health establishment.

Section 86

Independent admission and treatment.

Section 87

Admission of minors.

Section 88

Discharge of independent patients.

Section 89

Supported admission:

  • An individual who requires admission due to threats or attempts of bodily harm to themselves or others or who is unable to care for themselves and has lost the capacity to make decisions regarding their mental healthcare or treatment.
  • A nominated representative can provide consent for the admission.

Section 90

Supported admission beyond 30 days.

questions.text: A female patient from the northeastern part of the country presents with progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. Examination reveals proximal limb swelling more than distal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Night blood test for worms

Explanation:

  • The northeastern part of the country is endemic for lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi), which causes proximal limb lymphedema due to lymphatic obstruction.
  • Microfilariae exhibit nocturnal periodicity, making a night blood test the preferred initial investigation.

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
  • Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae

 

Life Cycle of Filaria (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi):

 

Lab Diagnosis:

1. Demonstration of Microfilaria:

  • In blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix or hydrocele fluid.
  • Best collect night blood samples between 10pm and 4 am.
  • Microfilaria can be seen in unstained as well as stained specimens.
  • Staining is performed using Giemsa, Leishman, or polychrome methylene blue.

 

Concentration Techniques: Done if microfilaria density is low

  • Knott’s concentration technique
  • Nucleopore filtration
  • Diethylcarbamazine provocation test (DCT):
    • Small dose of DEC given (2 mg/kg body weight)
    • Forces microfilaria to appear in peripheral blood during daytime.
  • Quantitative buffy coat

2. Ultrasonography:

  • Identify motile adult worms in the scrotum and female breast within dilated lymphatics, known as the "filaria dance sign."

3. Hemogram:

  • Eosinophilia
  • Elevated serum IgE levels

4. Demonstration of Antibody: Cannot distinguish between current and past infections.

5. Demonstration of Circulating Antigen:

  • Highly sensitive and specific
  • Trop-bio test: Semiquantitative sandwich ELISA
  • ELISA: To detect specific IgG4 antibody against W.bancrofti antigen (WbSXP-1)
  • Immunochromatographic test (ICT): Detects soluble W.bancrofti antigen using monoclonal antibody (AD12) in serum.

Treatment:

  • Drug of Choice: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC)
  • Mass drug therapy is given as either:
    • DEC alone
    • DEC + Albendazole
    • DEC + Ivermectin

 

Echocardiography (Option A): Cardiac conditions such as heart failure or superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome can cause limb swelling. However, these usually present with bilateral swelling and additional systemic symptoms. Given the patient's regional background and asymmetric proximal swelling, filariasis is a more likely cause.

Duplex venous scan of limbs (Option C): A venous scan is useful in detecting deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which typically causes distal rather than proximal limb swelling. In this case, lymphatic obstruction is a more likely cause.

ECG (Option D): Although the patient has a history of coronary artery disease, ECG does not evaluate limb swelling and is not the next best step in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following drug abuses can lead to the symptoms described by a 25-year-old male patient who complains of a sensation resembling insects crawling beneath his skin and has presented to the clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cocaine

  • Cocaine abuse can lead to formication, which is the sensation of insects crawling under the skin.
  • It is also called coke bugs or cocaine bugs
  • This is a tactile hallucination commonly seen in stimulant-induced psychosis like cocaine.
  • The drug increases dopamine levels in the brain, leading to altered sensory perceptions and pleasure.

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Erythroxylum coca plant

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted, Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

Cannabis (Option A) is a CNS depressant and mild hallucinogen, which primarily causes altered perceptions and mood changes, but it is not commonly associated with formication.

Heroin (Option C) is an opioid with effects that include euphoria, sedation, analgesia, and respiratory depression. It does not typically cause sensory distortions such as formication.

Alcohol (Option D) is a CNS depressant, and its withdrawal in chronic alcoholics can lead to delirium tremens, which include visual hallucinations and delirium. However, formication is not commonly associated with this.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post–menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with a “feeding vessel”, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endometrial polyp

Explanation:

Feeding vessel sign in ultrasound is characteristic of Endometrial polyp

  • Endometrial polyps are soft, fleshy growths that form inside the uterus, composed of endometrial glands, fibrous tissue, and surface epithelium.
  • Factors such as aging, obesity, and tamoxifen use increase the likelihood of developing polyps.
  • Endometrial polyps may remain asymptomatic and are often discovered incidentally during imaging procedures for other reasons. When symptoms are present, they are commonly linked to heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), prolonged bleeding, or intermenstrual bleeding.
  • The primary diagnostic methods include transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) with color Doppler, saline infusion sonography (SIS), and hysteroscopy. TVS is best performed early in the menstrual cycle to avoid false positives from normal secretory endometrium.
  • Color Doppler can help distinguish them from submucous fibroids, as polyps generally have a single arterial feeding vessel.
  • Treatment of endometrial polyps is based on symptoms and the risk of malignancy. Although most polyps are benign, a small percentage can undergo malignant transformation. Higher risks for transformation are associated with postmenopausal status, age over 60, and abnormal bleeding.
  • Higher risks for malignant transformation are associated with postmenopausal status, age over 60, and abnormal bleeding. Larger polyps, tamoxifen use, diabetes, and obesity may also increase the risk. In such cases, hysteroscopic polypectomy is the preferred treatment.


Incorrect Options:

Uterine fibroids (Option A), or leiomyomas, are benign tumors that arise from the smooth muscle tissue of the uterus. While they can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, they are less commonly associated with post-menopausal bleeding. On ultrasonography, fibroids appear as solid masses within the uterine wall and do not typically show a feeding vessel.

Endometrial carcinoma (Option C) refers to cancerous growth in the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium). Post-menopausal bleeding is one of the key symptoms of endometrial carcinoma. However, on ultrasonography, endometrial carcinoma may appear as diffuse thickening of the endometrium or irregular mass, rather than a well-defined polypoid mass with a feeding vessel.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option D) is a rare malignant tumor that arises from the smooth muscle tissue of the uterus. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, but post-menopausal bleeding is more commonly associated with endometrial polyps or endometrial carcinoma. On ultrasonography, leiomyosarcoma may appear as a large, irregular mass within the uterus, often with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents with high-grade fever, confusion, and a purpuric rash. CSF analysis reveals gram-negative diplococci. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria meningitidis

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Neisseria meningitidis infection.

  • Gram-negative diplococci on CSF analysis strongly suggest meningococcal meningitis.
  • Clinical features include fever, altered mental status, and a characteristic purpuric rash (meningococcemia).
  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal hemorrhage due to meningococcemia) can occur in severe cases.

Lab Investigations of N. Meningitidis:

Investigation

Findings

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis

Appearance

Cloudy or purulent

White Blood Cell Count (WBC)

Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils

Protein

Elevated

Glucose

Decreased

Gram Stain

Presence of gram-negative diplococci

Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA

Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests

Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis

White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

 

Neisseria meningitidis treatment

Empirical Antibiotic Therapy
  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Vancomycin: Added to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until pathogen identification.
  • Ampicillin: Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in immunocompromised patients and the elderly.

Definitive Therapy
  • Penicillin G: First choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously.
  • Alternative Antibiotics: Continue Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime if pathogen is susceptible.
  • Duration: Typically lasts 7 days.
  • Dexamethasone: May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, especially if started before or with the first antibiotic dose.

Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts
  • Rifampin: 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children).
  • Ciprofloxacin: Single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children.
  • Ceftriaxone: Single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children).

Vaccination Prophylaxis
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, W135): 2 doses for children aged 3-18 months or a single dose for older children and adults.
  • Not given to children less than 2-3 years of age.

Indications for Vaccination
  • Contacts during outbreaks
  • Splenic dysfunction
  • Terminal complement component deficiency
  • International travelers

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B): A gram-negative rod, not a diplococcus.

  • Causes hospital-acquired meningitis, often associated with neurosurgical procedures or immunocompromised patients.
  • Not typically linked to a purpuric rash.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): A gram-positive diplococcus, ruling it out based on CSF findings.

  • Causes pneumococcal meningitis, which presents with fever, altered mental status, and possible pneumonia but lacks a purpuric rash.

E. coli (Option D): A gram-negative rod, not a diplococcus.

  • Common cause of meningitis in neonates, particularly in association with neural tube defects or preterm birth.

questions.text: In what procedure is the instrument shown in the image utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tubectomy (Female Sterilization)

Explanation:

There are five primary methods of female sterilization:

  1. Tubal sterilization during laparotomy for cesarean delivery or other abdominal surgeries.
  2. Postpartum mini-laparotomy immediately after vaginal delivery.
  3. Interval minilaparotomy.
  4. Laparoscopy.
  5. Hysteroscopy.

Surgical Technique

  • The Pomeroy technique, or a modified version of it, is typically chosen for tubal sterilization during laparotomy. In the classic Pomeroy method, a loop of the fallopian tube is excised, and the base of the loop is ligated with a single absorbable suture.
  • The Madlener technique, which is no longer used due to high failure rates, involved crushing a loop of the tube, ligating it with a permanent suture, and excising the segment.
  • Failure rates for the Pomeroy and partial salpingectomy procedures are low
  • In contrast, pregnancy after sterilization using the Irving or Uchida methods is exceedingly rare. The Irving method involves excising the midsection of the tube, and then turning back the proximal stump and suturing it into a small stab wound in the uterine wall, forming a blind loop.
  • The Uchida method involves injecting a saline–epinephrine solution beneath the mucosa of the tube, separating the mucosa from the underlying tissue. The mucosa is then incised, and a segment of the tube is excised. The mucosa is sutured closed, burying the proximal stump and separating it from the distal end.

Laparoscopy

  • Laparoscopy is the most commonly used method for interval sterilization. During the procedure, the abdomen is inflated with gas, and a laparoscope is inserted through a trocar at the lower edge of the umbilicus. Although single-puncture laparoscopic sterilization can be done using an operating laparoscope, a second, and sometimes third, trocar is often inserted in the lower quadrants or suprapubic area to facilitate the use of special grasping forceps. Laparoscopic sterilization is typically performed in a hospital under general anesthesia, though local anesthesia with conscious sedation can also be used. Most patients do not require overnight hospitalization after the procedure.

 

Incorrect Options:

A punch biopsy (Option A) is a procedure to obtain a small sample of tissue for examination. The instrument used in a punch biopsy is typically a circular blade or punch, which is different from the instrument depicted.

A bone marrow biopsy set (Option C) is used to obtain a sample of bone marrow for diagnostic purposes. It typically includes a needle and a syringe, and the instrument depicted does not resemble the components of a bone marrow biopsy set.

The instrument depicted does not resemble a trocar and cannula used in laparoscopy (Option D), which typically consists of a sharp-pointed instrument and a hollow tube for accessing the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: The patient exhibited an enlarged lymph node in the inguinal area. The primary cause that is most probable is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Anal cancer

Explanation:

  • The inguinal lymph nodes primarily drain the lower limb, perineum, external genitalia, and anal canal below the dentate line. Anal cancer (especially if it arises below the pectinate/dentate line) spreads to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making it the most probable cause of an enlarged inguinal lymph node.

 

Lymphatic Drainage of the Rectum and Anal Canal:

Region

Lymphatic Drainage

Upper half of the rectum

Inferior mesenteric nodes via pararectal and sigmoid nodes

Lower half of the rectum & upper anal canal

Internal iliac nodes

Anal canal (below the pectinate line)

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

 

 

 

Testicular cancer (option A): Testes drain to the para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymph nodes, not the inguinal nodes. Inguinal node involvement is uncommon unless there is scrotal skin involvement.
