Marasmus

 

Indian childhood cirrhosis (Option C) is a liver disease that primarily affects infants and young children in India. It is characterized by liver damage and fibrosis, leading to liver dysfunction. But it is not associated with a swollen belly or dull face.

Kawasaki disease (Option D) is an acute febrile illness that primarily affects children under the age of 5. It involves inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body, leading to various symptoms such as high fever, rash, red eyes, swollen lymph nodes, and changes in the extremities.

questions.text: What is the causative organism responsible for vulval warts among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Human Papilloma Virus

Explanation:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the causative organism of vulval warts. Vulval warts, also known as genital warts or condylomata acuminata, are sexually transmitted infection caused by certain types of HPV. HPV is a group of more than 100 related viruses, and the specific types responsible for genital warts are usually HPV types 6 and 11.

Incorrect Options:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) (Option B) is not the causative organism of vulval warts. While HSV is another sexually transmitted infection, it is responsible for causing genital herpes, which presents with clinical features such as painful ulcers or blisters rather than warts.

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) (Option C) is the virus that causes AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). HIV is not directly associated with the development of vulval warts. However, individuals with HIV infection or other conditions that compromise the immune system may have a higher risk of developing persistent or more extensive warts.

Cytomegalovirus (Option D) is a common virus that can cause various manifestations, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems. However, it is not the causative organism of vulval warts. CMV is more commonly associated with infections such as congenital CMV infection, viral pneumonia, or hepatitis.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 41-year-old female patient who presented with a twisted swelling on the scalp and face, accompanied by a pulsating sensation and a bruit heard during auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Cirsoid Aneurysm:

  • In this case, the most likely diagnosis is a cirsoid aneurysm, given the pulsatile swelling, the bruit heard on auscultation, and the location of the lesion (scalp/face).
  • It is a vascular malformation characterised by abnormal communication between arteries and veins, leading to variceal dilatation of the draining veins.
  • This results in a pulsatile swelling, often associated with a palpable thrill and an audible bruit, which are hallmark signs of this condition.
  • The mass in a cirsoid aneurysm can cause cosmetic concerns and may also lead to local pain, headache, tinnitus, and hemorrhage.
  • Treatment for cirsoid aneurysm typically involves surgical fistula repair through simple ligation or endovascular embolisation techniques (using coils or cyanoacrylate).
  • In some cases, gross total resection by a plastic surgery team is also done.

Neurofibromatosis (Option A) is benign nerve sheath tumours (neurofibromas) that may present as skin nodules or masses. These tumours would not produce the characteristic pulsatile swelling or bruit associated with a cirsoid aneurysm.

Liposarcomas (Option B) are malignant tumours of the adipose tissue. They can cause swelling or mass, but unlike a cirsoid aneurysm, they do not present with a pulsatile sensation or an audible bruit.

Varicocele (Option D) is a condition characterised by the enlargement of veins within the scrotum, commonly occurring on the left side. It is not relevant to the case presented, as the description mentions a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face, not the scrotum.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a 3-year-old male who has the given buccal mucosa findings and subsequently develops a rash after three days?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation:

The image shows Koplik’s spot on the buccal mucosa, which is pathognomonic of measles. Koplik's spots are small, white spots with a bluish-white centre and red halo that appear on the buccal mucosa.

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset.

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

Vitamin A reduces the morbidity and mortality of measles.

 

Leukoplakia (Option B) appears as a white patch in the oral cavity that cannot be wiped off.

Scarlet fever (Option C) is group A Streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis and is characterized by a distinctive sandpaper rash. The rash appears as a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption that turns the skin bright red and blanches on pressure. It starts around the neck and spreads to the trunk and extremities and strawberry tongue is also seen.

Kawasaki disease (Option D) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash (maculopapular, erythema multiforme), conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph nodes and strawberry tongue is also seen.

questions.text: What is the etiologic agent responsible for causing granuloma inguinale
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calymmatobacterium Granulomatis

Explanation:

  • Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is an infection caused by the gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis or Calymmatobacterium granulomatis (Option A). The incubation period can range from several days to weeks.
  • The infection typically presents with painless inflammatory nodules that evolve into highly vascular, nontender ulcers. These ulcers eventually heal through fibrosis, which can lead to scar formation similar to keloids.
  • Lymphadenopathy is generally absent. Diagnosis is primarily based on identifying Donovan bodies, which appear as "closed safety pins" when examined microscopically after Wright-Giemsa staining.
  • Treatment of granuloma inguinale is azithromycin 1 g once a week for at least three weeks or until the lesions are fully healed. Other treatment options include doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or erythromycin base. Improvement is typically seen within the first few days of treatment, though complete resolution may take time, and relapses have been reported.

Incorrect Options:

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B) is a bacterium that causes various sexually transmitted infections, including chlamydia. However, it is not the causative agent for granuloma inguinale. Chlamydial infections typically present with symptoms such as urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease.

Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option C) is a bacterium that belongs to the family Mycoplasmataceae and can be associated with certain genital infections. However, it is not the causative agent for granuloma inguinale. Ureaplasma infections are more commonly linked to conditions such as urethritis, bacterial vaginosis, and infertility.

Treponema pallidum (OptionD) is the bacterium responsible for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection. While syphilis can cause genital ulcers similar to those seen in granuloma inguinale, the causative agent for granuloma inguinale is specifically Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, not Treponema pallidum.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is utilized in contemporary obstetrics for monitoring the fetus of a mother who is Rh-negative and sensitized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

Explanation:

  • MCA doppler is a specialized ultrasound technique used to assess fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers. When an Rh-negative mother is sensitized to Rh-positive fetal red blood cells, maternal antibodies can cross the placenta and cause the destruction of fetal red blood cells, leading to fetal anemia.
  • MCA doppler measures the peak systolic velocity in the middle cerebral artery of the fetus, which correlates with fetal blood flow and oxygenation. A high MCA doppler peak systolic velocity indicates fetal anemia, prompting further evaluation and possible intervention, such as intrauterine transfusion.

Incorrect Options:

A biophysical profile (BPP) (Option A) is a prenatal ultrasound-based assessment that evaluates various parameters of fetal well-being, including fetal movement, fetal tone, fetal breathing, amniotic fluid volume, and reactive fetal heart rate. While BPP is a useful tool for assessing fetal well-being, it is not specifically used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother.

Fetal blood sampling (Option B), also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), is a diagnostic procedure in which a sample of fetal blood is obtained from the umbilical cord for laboratory analysis. It is typically performed to assess specific fetal conditions, such as genetic disorders or fetal anemia. Although Rh sensitization can lead to fetal anemia, fetal blood sampling is not the primary investigation used for monitoring Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

There is no specific diagnostic test called "amniospectometry" (Option C) in modern obstetrics. It may refer to the assessment of amniotic fluid volume, which can be evaluated using various methods, including ultrasound measurement of amniotic fluid index (AFI) or single deepest pocket (SDP). While monitoring amniotic fluid volume is important in certain situations, it is not the specific investigation used for

questions.text: Which of the following is not taken into consideration in ASEPSIS wound scoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Induration

  • The Asepsis scoring system evaluates infection based on visible signs like erythema, exudate type, and laboratory investigations, but induration is not directly taken into account.
  • Asepsis wound score:

Parameters

Score

Additional treatment:

  1. Antibiotics
  2. Pus drainage
  3. Wound debridement

 

10

10

Serous discharge - For 5 days of the first 7 days of wound infection

(Option B ruled out)

0-5 Daily

Erythema - For 5 days of first 7 days of wound infection (Option C ruled out)

0-5 Daily

Purulent fluid - For 5 days of the first 7 days of wound infection

0-10 Daily

Separation of deep tissues - For 5 days of the first 7 days of wound infection

0-10 Daily

Isolation of bacteria (Option A ruled out)

10

Stay in the hospital (in-patient) >14 days due to infection

5
  • Asepsis scores are grouped into the following categories:
    • Satisfactory healing: 0-10
    • Disturbance of healing:11-20
    • Minor SSI: 21-30
    • Moderate SSI: 31-40
    • Severe SSI: >40

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency department following a fall into a manhole, resulting in injury to his perineum. He experiences a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. During examination, blood is observed at the opening of the urethra, and there is swelling of the penis and scrotum. Which specific area is affected by the injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Bulbar urethra injury

  • Bulbar urethra injury occurs due to trauma to the perineum, especially in cases like falls onto the perineum (e.g., falling into a manhole).
  • The bulbar urethra is the part of the urethra that passes through the perineum, and it is the most commonly injured part in pelvic fractures.
  • Blood at the urethral meatus, along with swelling of the scrotum and penis, points toward this injury.

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries

Membranous urethra rupture (Option A) is usually identified by a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination and difficulty voiding. However, the presence of blood at the urethral meatus and swelling of the penis and scrotum, in this case, points to a more distal injury, making membranous rupture unlikely.

Prostatic urethra (Option C) injury is uncommon and usually results from high-energy trauma, often involving significant pelvic fractures. The symptoms would be less likely to involve external swelling and blood at the meatus, which suggests of a distal injury.

Urinary bladder rupture (Option D) presents with abdominal pain, tenderness, hematuria and inability to pass urine. Blood at the urethral meatus and swelling of the external genitalia are not typical findings for bladder rupture.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of an 18-year-old girl who has been experiencing low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea for the past six months? During examination, a pelvic mass is detected on the left side, and signs of ascites are present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculosis with tubo–ovarian mass

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, amenorrhea, pelvic mass, and ascites is highly suggestive of genital tuberculosis.
  • Genital tuberculosis is a common extrapulmonary manifestation of tuberculosis, and it often involves the female genital tract, leading to tubo-ovarian masses, fallopian tube adhesions, and ascites. These clinical features are consistent with the diagnosis of tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass.

Incorrect Options:

While ovarian malignancy (Option B) can present with similar symptoms such as pelvic mass, weight loss, and abdominal pain, the presence of low-grade fever and signs of ascites makes tuberculosis a more likely diagnosis in this case. Ovarian malignancies typically do not cause systemic symptoms like fever, and ascites in ovarian cancer are usually associated with advanced disease.

Ectopic pregnancy (Option C) refers to the implantation of a fertilized egg outside the uterine cavity, usually in the fallopian tube. While ectopic pregnancy can cause abdominal pain, amenorrhea, and pelvic mass, it is not typically associated with low-grade fever and ascites. Therefore, it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

Submucous fibroids (Option D) are benign growths that develop in the uterine wall. They can cause symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure symptoms, but they are not typically associated with systemic symptoms like low-grade fever, weight loss, and ascites. Hence, submucous fibroid is an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with a tumour less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Partial nephrectomy

  • For renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with a tumour size of less than 4 cm, the treatment of choice is partial nephrectomy.
  • This approach preserves kidney function while removing the tumour, making it the preferred method for small tumours.

Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant (Option B & D ruled out)

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible (Option C ruled out)

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past one year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sheehan’s syndrome

Explanation:

  • The given scenario is characteristic of Sheehan syndrome.
  • Sheehan's syndrome, also known as postpartum pituitary necrosis, occurs due to severe postpartum hemorrhage leading to hypotension and inadequate blood supply to the pituitary gland. This can result in ischemic necrosis of the pituitary tissue. One of the common manifestations of Sheehan's syndrome is postpartum lactational failure, followed by amenorrhea or absence of menstrual periods. The history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure in the given scenario is suggestive of Sheehan's syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Rotor syndrome (Option B) is a rare inherited disorder characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (elevated direct bilirubin) without evidence of liver disease. It does not present with amenorrhea or lactational failure, making it an incorrect choice in this case.

Prolactinoma (Option C) is a type of pituitary adenoma, a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that secretes excessive prolactin hormone. Hyperprolactinemia can lead to amenorrhea, as well as galactorrhea (abnormal breast milk production) and infertility. However, the given scenario does not mention symptoms related to elevated prolactin levels (e.g., galactorrhea). Hence, prolactinoma is less likely.

Acromegaly (Option D) is a hormonal disorder caused by excessive production of growth hormone by a pituitary adenoma. It typically presents with gradual enlargement of hands, feet, facial features, and other tissues. While hormonal imbalances can affect menstrual cycles, acromegaly does not specifically cause amenorrhea or lactational failure, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: What is the cause of the greenish-black color of the initial stool in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Biliverdin

Explanation:

The greenish-black color of the initial stool (meconium) in the newborn is caused due to biliverdin.

Meconium is made up of various products of secretion such as desquamated fetal cells, glycerophospholipids from lungs, lanugo, scalp hair, vernix, and undigested products from swallowed amniotic fluid. And the greenish black color of the meconium is due to presence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, especially biliverdin (oxidation of bilirubin).

 

Bilirubin (Option A) is responsible for the yellow color of the stool.

Meconium (Option C) is a dark, viscous material that is normally present in the intestine of the fetus and passes within the 1st 48 hours of life. Meconium appears after the 20th week and at term, distributed till rectum uniformly indicates normal intestinal peristalsis.

Gut flora (Option D) has not been developed in the neonate.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be what percentage of total energy intake?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) < 10%

Explanation:

According to the current recommended dietary guidelines for children, the energy intake from saturated fats should be less than 10% of the total energy intake. This guideline is in place to promote a diet that is low in saturated fats and cholesterol without transfat, and encourages the consumption of healthier sources of fat, such as unsaturated fats.

 

Acceptable macronutrient distribution ranges (AMDA % of energy) :

Macronutrient

Age 1 to 3 years

Age 4 to 18 years

Fats

30- 40 %
