questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Female condom

Explanation:

  • Female condom: Female condoms are soft, loose-fitting pouches with flexible rings at each end. One ring is inserted into the vagina to hold the condom in place, while the other ring remains outside to cover the area around the vaginal opening.

Images of various barrier methods:

 

 

 


Incorrect Options:

Male condoms (Option A) are typically made of latex or polyurethane and are worn over the erect penis to prevent pregnancy and protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). However, the image described does not depict a male condom.

A diaphragm (Option C) is a barrier contraceptive device that is inserted into the vagina to cover the cervix and prevent sperm from entering the uterus. It is usually made of latex or silicone and requires fitting by a healthcare provider. The image and description do not match a diaphragm.

Similar to a diaphragm, a cervical cap (Option D) is a barrier contraceptive device that is placed over the cervix to prevent sperm from entering the uterus. It is smaller in size compared to a diaphragm and fits directly onto the cervix. The image and description do not correspond to a cervical cap.

questions.text: The mother brought her 3-year-old daughter to seek medical attention due to the girl's enlarged clitoris. The results of the karyotype test showed a 46XX pattern. What is the probable underlying cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

Explanation:

  • In individuals with XX chromosomes (typically female), the excess androgens due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency can cause virilization of the external genitalia, resulting in an enlarged clitoris.
  • 21 hydroxylase deficiency characterized by impaired production of cortisol and aldosterone leads to an increase in adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion, which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce excess androgens (male sex hormones).

 

21-Hydroxylase Deficiency
  • Most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (90%)
  • Enzyme Affected: 21-hydroxylase

Pathogenesis
  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency impairs the synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • Low cortisol levels lead to elevated ACTH levels.
  • Elevated ACTH causes the accumulation of steroid precursors, including dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), androstenedione, and 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP).

Clinical Manifestations
  • Salt wasting form: Severe deficiency with nearly absent enzyme activity.
    • Presents in neonates with salt-wasting, virilization, ambiguous genitalia in girls, failure to thrive, polyuria, hyperpigmentation, critical electrolyte imbalances and shock. Diagnosis may be missed in boys.
  • Simple virilizing form: Partial enzyme activity (25%) allows aldosterone production.
    • Features include virilization in girls and peripheral precocious puberty in boys.
  • Non-classic form: Mild enzyme deficiency with mild hyperandrogenism. Symptoms include hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities in adolescents.

Diagnosis
  • Salt-Wasting Form: Extreme elevations of 17-OHP levels (10000-20000 ng/dL, normal <200 ng/dL) in the context of clinical signs of adrenal insufficiency.
  • Simple Virilizing and Non Classic Forms: Elevated 17-OHP levels measured before and 60 minutes after an intramuscular ACTH injection (0.25 mg).

Treatment

Salt wasting and virilizing forms treated with

  • Hydrocortisone (10-15 mg/m²/day) and Fludrocortisone (0.1 mg/day).
  • Long-acting glucocorticoid preparations (dexamethasone or prednisolone) may be used after growth and puberty are complete.

 

 

11 hydroxylase deficiency (Option B) is another form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), but it typically leads to hypertension and may cause ambiguous genitalia and hypokalemia. It is less commonly associated with an enlarged clitoris.

3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency (Option C) is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) characterized by impaired conversion of pregnenolone to progesterone. It can lead to impaired production of cortisol and aldosterone, but it is not typically associated with virilization and an enlarged clitoris.

17α-OH deficiency (Option D) is generally present with complaints of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics in a female patient. The presentation in male patients is typically under masculinization and can range from phenotypic females to ambiguous or small male genitalia.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a newborn who presents with protrusion of bowel loops through a defect in the abdominal wall located to the right side of the umbilicus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gastroschisis

Explanation:

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect of the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus. It involves evisceration of abdominal contents, such as bowel loops, without a covering sac. The exposed intestines are in direct contact with the amniotic fluid.

 

 

Gastroschisis

Omphalocele

(Option A)

Definition

A congenital defect where the abdominal wall fails to close, leading to herniation of intestinal loops into the amniotic cavity.

M/c in premature/SGA babies

 

A congenital ventral body wall defect where portions of the midgut fail to return to the abdominal cavity after physiological herniation.

Location of defect

Right paraumbilical

Central

Sac

Absent, bowel is exposed.

Present (if not ruptured).

Sac is made of amnion, Wharton's jelly and peritoneum

Description

Free intestinal loops.

(Liver is not usually herniated)

Firm mass including liver, intestine and/ other organs (like stomach, spleen)

Umbilical cord

Adjacent to the defect

Attached to the sac

Associated anomalies

Associated anatomic defects are uncommon

Associated abnormalities are common and include:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Chromosomal defect

Detection

  • Identified through fetal ultrasound.
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentrations in maternal serum and amniotic fluid, similar to gastroschisis.

Complication

  • Affected bowel loops may be damaged due to exposure to corrosive amniotic fluid.
  • Risk of volvulus, where the bowel twists around itself, compromising blood supply.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Failure to thrive
  • Inguinal hernias
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Occasionally esophagitis

Prognosis

Favorable

High mortality rates

 

Omphalocele (Option A) is a congenital abdominal wall defect in which abdominal contents herniate into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac. Omphalocele is typically centrally located.

Umbilical hernia (Option B) is a protrusion of abdominal contents through a weakness or incomplete closure of the umbilical ring. It is not associated with evisceration of bowel loops to the right of the umbilicus.

Ectopia vesicae (Option D) refers to the abnormal positioning of the urinary bladder, typically exposed on the abdominal wall due to a defect in the lower abdominal wall.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and intense itching. On examination, the cervix and vagina were spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trichomonas vaginalis

Explanation:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. It is known to cause symptoms such as foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. The cervix and vagina may appear reddened and have a characteristic appearance described as a "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" due to small red or punctate lesions on its surface.
     

Incorrect Options:

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option B) is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV), which is a common vaginal infection. BV typically presents with a creamy-white discharge with a fishy odor. However, it does not cause the characteristic "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" appearance seen in the given scenario.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C) is the bacterium responsible for the sexually transmitted infection, gonorrhea. While it can cause vaginal discharge and itching, it does not typically produce the "strawberry cervix" appearance described in the question.

Candida albicans (Option D) is a fungus responsible for vaginal yeast infections, also known as candidiasis. The typical symptoms include thick, white, curd-like discharge and itching. However, it does not cause the "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is presenting with wrist pain on the lateral side. On examination the following test was positive. Tendon sheaths of which two muscles have been involved?

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with lateral wrist pain and a positive Finkelstein test (most commonly performed for diagnosing De Quervain’s tenosynovitis).

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves the inflammation of the tendon sheaths of:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

These tendons pass through the first dorsal compartment of the wrist.

 

Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus (option B): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is located in the third dorsal compartment and is not involved in De Quervain’s tenosynovitis.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis (option C): Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is part of the thenar muscles and does not pass through the first dorsal compartment.

Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus (option D): Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is not affected, and abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is a thenar muscle.

questions.text: The given chest x-ray is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tetralogy of Fallot

Explanation:

The given chest X-ray shows boot shaped cardiac silhouette, which is suggestive of cardiac anomaly Tetralogy of Fallot. It is due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Pulmonary Stenosis
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
  • Overriding Aorta
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy

General Clinical Features of TOF

  • Cyanosis
  • Hypercyanotic Spells (Tet Spells)
  • Murmurs.

Treatment of ToF:

  • Management of Tet Spells
    • Immediate interventions:
      • Knee-chest position
      • Oxygen administration
      • Morphine for sedation
      • Intravenous fluids
  • Surgical Repair
    • Complete Repair
      • Procedure: Close VSD, relieve RVOT obstruction
      • Approach: Transatrial-transpulmonary
      • Considerations: Minimizing pulmonary insufficiency with smaller patches
    • Palliative Shunts
      • Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Connects subclavian artery to pulmonary artery
      • Central Shunt: Connects ascending aorta to main pulmonary artery

 

In Atrial septal defect and Ventricular septal defect (Option B and C) typical boot-shaped heart is not seen.

Box-shaped heart seen in Ebstein’s anomaly (Option D)

Named malformation of CVS in chest X ray

Snowman or "figure-of-eight" appearance: seen in Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)"

Scimitar sign: seen in Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC)
 

Box-shaped heart: seen in Ebstein’s anomaly

Gooseneck deformity: seen in

endocardial cushion defects

questions.text: Where in the fallopian tube does fertilization take place?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ampulla

Explanation:

  • Out of the nearly half a billion sperm deposited in the vagina, only a few thousand successfully make it to each ampulla.
  • Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla (Option A) of one of the fallopian tubes shortly after both the sperm and the ovum arrive there.

Incorrect Options:

The isthmus (Option B) is the narrower and proximal part of the fallopian tube, closer to the uterus. While the isthmus serves as a passageway for the fertilized embryo to reach the uterine cavity, fertilization does not usually occur in this region.

The interstitial segment (Option C), also known as the intramural segment, refers to the small portion of the fallopian tube that traverses the uterine wall. Fertilization does not occur in this segment of the fallopian tube.

The infundibulum (Option D) is the funnel-shaped opening of the fallopian tube located near the ovary. It has finger-like projections called fimbriae that help capture the released oocyte from the ovary. While the infundibulum plays a role in capturing the oocyte, fertilization itself typically occurs in the ampulla rather than the infundibulum.

questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by the :

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Dorsal scapular nerve

Explanation:

  • The levator scapulae muscle is primarily innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve (C5), with additional contributions from C3 and C4 spinal nerves. The dorsal scapular nerve arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and also supplies the rhomboid major and minor muscles. Function: Elevates the scapula and assists in downward rotation.

 

Part of brachial plexus

Branches

Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve - C5

Long thoracic nerve - C5 to C7

Trunks

Suprascapular nerve - C5, C6

Nerve to subclavius - C5, C6

Division

None

Cords

Lateral pectoral nerve (Lateral cord: C5-C7)

Upper subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (Posterior cord: C6-C8)

Lower subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)

Medial pectoral nerve (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Terminal branches

Musculocutaneous nerve (Lateral cord, C5-C7)

Axillary nerve (Posterior cord, C5, C6)

Radial nerve (Posterior cord, C5-T1)

Median nerve (Lateral and Medial cords, C5-T1)

Ulnar nerve (Medial cord, C8, T1)

 

Suprascapular nerve (option B): Innervates supraspinatus and infraspinatus, not the levator scapulae. Arises from the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus.

From the dorsal rami of C1 (option C): C1 dorsal ramus contributes to the suboccipital nerve, which innervates suboccipital muscles, not the levator scapulae.

Subscapular nerve (option D): The upper and lower subscapular nerves (from C5-C6) supply the subscapularis and teres major, not the levator scapulae.

questions.text: A tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas affects which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Superior mesenteric artery

Explanation:

  • The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small, hook-like projection from the head of the pancreas that extends posteriorly and inferiorly, wrapping around the superior mesenteric vessels (SMA and SMV).
  • A tumor in this region is likely to compress or invade the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which supplies blood to the midgut (small intestine and proximal colon).

 

Relationship of the Pancreas, Veins, and Aorta in Nutcracker Syndrome

Nutcracker Syndrome:

  • A condition caused by compression of the left renal vein leading to the left renal vein hypertension.
  • Highlights the anatomical relationship between the pancreas, veins, and aorta.

Anatomical Features

Description

Left Renal Vein

Originates from the hilum of the left kidney.

Travels behind the pancreas and splenic vein.

Crosses the abdominal aorta anteriorly below the superior mesenteric artery.

Nutcracker Analogy

The left renal vein is compressed between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery, resembling a nutcracker.

Symptoms

Can lead to left renal vein hypertension.

Symptoms include hematuria and varicocele, especially in children.

Pancreas' Role in Nutcracker Syndrome:

  • Positioned directly in front of the compression site, anterior to the SMA.
  • Proximity to vascular structures suggests the potential to worsen the condition.
  • The uncinate process being close to the superior mesenteric artery and vein further emphasises the pancreas's proximity to major vessels.

Portal vein (option B): Formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and splenic vein, located posterior to the neck of the pancreas. The uncinate process is more inferior, so it typically does not directly compress the portal vein.

Common hepatic artery (option C): Arises from the celiac trunk and gives rise to the proper hepatic artery and gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the pancreas and is not typically affected by tumors of the uncinate process.

Inferior mesenteric artery (option D): Arises from the abdominal aorta at a lower level, supplying the hindgut (distal colon and rectum). It is too distant from the uncinate process to be affected.

questions.text: Where is the probable location of the lesion in a patient who has presented with weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face along with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left leg?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Lateral medulla

Explanation:

  • The clinical features described—weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face, along with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left leg—are indicative of a lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome.
  • In this condition, there is damage to the lateral part of the medulla.
  • This syndrome typically involves the spinothalamic tract (for pain and temperature sensation), the descending trigeminal tract (for facial sensation), and other structures like the nucleus ambiguus (which affects the motor function of the larynx and pharynx).

 

Wallenberg Syndrome (Lateral Medullary Syndrome)

  • Due to stroke or infarction in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata.
  • Mainly due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Sometimes the vertebral artery directly supplies the lateral brainstem.
  • Affects the dorsolateral aspect of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum.

 

Anatomical structure affected and features:

  1. Spinothalamic tract: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the trunk.
  2. Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face.
  3. Nucleus ambiguus: Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx.
  4. Inferior cerebellar peduncle and cerebellum: Ipsilateral ataxia.
  5. Vestibular nuclei: Giddiness.

 

 

Medial medulla (option A): Lesions here typically affect the medial lemniscus (responsible for touch and proprioception) and corticospinal tract (which affects motor function). This would cause contralateral weakness and loss of touch/proprioception, but not facial pain/temperature loss.

Lateral pons (option B): Lesions in the lateral pons often affect the spinothalamic tract and trigeminal nerve (similar to the lateral medulla), but this would typically involve contralateral body symptoms, not the contralateral leg. The face could have sensory loss on the same side, but the involvement of the left leg would point more toward the medulla.

Medial pons (option C): A lesion here would primarily affect structures like the corticospinal tract, abducens nucleus, and the medial lemniscus, leading to contralateral motor deficits and sensory loss of the body. Facial pain/temperature loss would not occur with a medial pontine lesion.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) 6th arch

Explanation:

  • The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch, which is derived from the sixth aortic arch. During embryonic development, the sixth arch contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on the left side, giving it its characteristic long course.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve anatomy:

  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, looping around it before ascending between the trachea and esophagus.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the arch of the aorta, loops around it, and ascends along the tracheoesophageal groove, giving it a longer course compared to the right nerve, making it more prone to injury.

 

Superior laryngeal nerve:

  • Origin - from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve; courses behind the internal carotid artery; divides into external and internal branches at the level of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
  • The external branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle.
  • The internal branch provides sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx after piercing through the thyrohyoid membrane.

 

3rd arch (Option A): This is incorrect because the 3rd arch gives rise to the common carotid artery and part of the internal carotid artery, but not the structures associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

4th arch (Option B): This is incorrect for the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, as the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, which is derived from the 4th arch. The left recurrent nerve loops around the aortic arch, which is from the sixth arch.

5th arch (Option C): This is incorrect because the 5th arch is rudimentary and does not contribute to the development of significant vascular structures or nerves.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Interossei and lumbricals

Explanation:

  • The interossei and lumbricals are responsible for flexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, as well as extension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.
  • Dysfunction of these muscles, such as in ulnar nerve damage, leads to the characteristic posture of MCP extension and IP flexion, known as "claw hand."

Extensor digitorum (option A): This is incorrect because the extensor digitorum is primarily responsible for extending the MCP, PIP, and DIP joints. It does not cause the flexion of the IP joints with extension at the MCP joint.

Abductor pollicis longus (option C): This is incorrect because the abductor pollicis longus is involved in the abduction and extension of the thumb, not the flexion or extension of the fingers.

Abductor pollicis brevis (option D): This is incorrect because the abductor pollicis brevis is responsible for the abduction of the thumb and does not influence the MCP or IP joints of the fingers.

questions.text: What is the child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dl, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR =2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class B
Explanation: This patient belongs to Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B based on the following scoring:

  • Serum Bilirubin: 2.5 mg/dL (2 points)
  • Serum Albumin: 3 g/dL (2 points)
  • Prothrombin Time (INR): 5 seconds (INR = 2) (2 points)
  • Encephalopathy: None (1 point)
  • Ascites: Mild (2 points)

The total score is 9 points, which places the patient in Child-Pugh Class B.

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score:

  • Employed to assess the severity of liver disease, predict prognosis for liver cirrhosis, and determine a patient's eligibility for liver transplantation, using a scoring system that incorporates parameters such as:
    • Bilirubin
    • INR
    • Albumin
    • Ascites
    • Hepatic encephalopathy

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

Parameters

1

2

3

Encephalopathy

None

Grade 1-2

(Minimal)

Grade 3-4

(Advanced)

Ascites

None

Mildly controlled

Poorly controlled

Bilirubin (mg/dL)

< 2

2 - 3

> 3

Albumin (g/dL)

> 3.5

3 - 3.5

< 3.5

INR

< 1.7

1.7 - 2.3

> 2.3
  • The Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score is determined by summing the scores for each parameter.
    • Category A: 5-6 (Compensated cirrhosis)
    • Category B: 7-9 (Decompensated cirrhosis)
    • Category C: > 10 (Severely decompensated cirrhosis)

questions.text: According to the TNM staging, a patient with lung cancer of size 2.5 cm is staged as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - T1c:

  • Given that the tumour size is 2.5 cm, it falls under T1c (as it is > 2 cm but ≤ 3 cm).

AJCC 8TH Edition of TNM Staging of Lung Carcinoma

Primary Tumor (T)

T1

T1a(mi)

Minimally invasive carcinoma

T1a

≤ 1 cm (Option D ruled out)

T1b

1 - 2 cm (Option A ruled out)

T1c

2 - 3 cm

T2
  • Involvement of the main bronchus with the involvement of carina
  • Involvement of visceral pleura
  • Association with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis

 

T2a

3 - ≤4 cm (Option C ruled out)

T2b

4 - ≤5 cm

T3

 
  • > 5 - ≤7 cm OR
  • Direct invasion of the Chest wall, Phrenic nerve, Pericardium, (Or)
  • Satellite nodules in the same lobe

T4

 
  • > 7 cm in greatest dimension (Or)
  • Any tumour with invasion of the mediastinum, diaphragm, heart, great vessels, recurrent laryngeal nerve, carina, trachea, oesophagus, spine (Or)
  • Separate tumours in different lobes of the ipsilateral lung.

Lymph Node (N)

N1

Ipsilateral peribronchial and/or hilar nodes and intrapulmonary nodes

N2

Ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal nodes

N3

Contralateral mediastinal or hilar; ipsilateral/contralateral scalene/supraclavicular

Distant Metastasis (M)

M1

Distant metastasis

 

M1a

Tumor in contralateral lung or pleural/pericardial nodule/malignant effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasis, including single non-regional lymph node

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Ligament of berry

Explanation:

  • The ligament of Berry is a fibrous connection between the thyroid gland and the thyroid cartilage. It helps anchor the thyroid gland to the trachea and prevents upward extension of thyroid swelling. This structure is key in maintaining the position of the thyroid gland and preventing its upward displacement.

Pretracheal fascia causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing

  • It encloses the thyroid gland and allows it to move with the trachea during swallowing
  • Berry's ligament also firmly connects the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring the gland moves with the trachea during swallowing.
  • This anatomical relationship is useful in physical examinations to distinguish thyroid masses from other cervical masses.

 

Pretracheal fascia (Option A): This is incorrect because the pretracheal fascia surrounds the thyroid gland and the trachea, providing a support layer, but it does not directly prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.

Sternothyroid (Option B): This is incorrect because the sternothyroid muscle is involved in depressing the thyroid cartilage and thyroid gland. While it plays a role in movement, it does not prevent upward extension of the thyroid gland.

Thyrohyoid membrane (Option C): This is incorrect because the thyrohyoid membrane connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone and does not prevent the upward extension of the thyroid gland. Its primary function is related to the movement and positioning of the larynx.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding anatomical closure is incorrect?

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 2 to 3 weeks
Right umbilical vein is absent after birth
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

Explanation:

  • Foramen ovale does not anatomically close within 3 to 5 days. Functional closure occurs soon after birth due to increased left atrial pressure, but anatomical closure (fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum) takes months to years. In some individuals, it may persist as a patent foramen ovale (PFO).
  • Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 2 to 3 weeks (option B): The ductus venosus shunts oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava in fetal circulation. After birth, it functionally closes within hours and anatomically closes in 2 to 3 weeks, forming the ligamentum venosum.

 

 

Formation of the Interatrial Septum:

Septum Primum

 
  • Formed as a sickle-shaped fold from the roof and dorsal wall of the primitive atrium due to pressure from the bulbus cordis.
  • Grows downward toward the atrioventricular (AV) canal and septum intermedium, fusing with the latter.

Ostium Primum

 

Before the septum primum reaches and fuses with the septum intermedium, a gap (foramen primum) allows blood flow between the right and left atria.

Ostium Secundum

Upper part of the septum primum breaks down, creating a new gap (foramen secundum) before the foramen primum closes. The septum primum now has a free upper edge.

Septum Secundum

Grows down from the roof of the atrial chamber, to the right of the septum primum, overlapping the free upper edge of the septum primum as it grows.

Foramen Ovale Formation
  • Overlapping septa create the foramen ovale, allowing blood to flow from right to left atrium during fetal life, preventing left-to-right flow.
  • Patent throughout fetal life.

Obliteration of Foramen Ovale
  • Post-birth, the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs, increasing pressure in this chamber greater than the right atrium, causing fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, closing the foramen ovale.
  • Annulus ovalis (adults) corresponds to the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

 

Right umbilical vein is absent after birth (option C): The right umbilical vein degenerates during fetal life, leaving only the left umbilical vein to carry blood from the placenta. After birth, the left umbilical vein also closes, forming the ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver).

Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks (option D): The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 24 to 48 hours due to oxygenation and prostaglandin metabolism. Anatomical closure occurs by 2 to 3 weeks, forming the ligamentum arteriosum.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carcinoma esophagus

Explanation:

  • The provided barium swallow findings of irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins are highly indicative of carcinoma of the esophagus.
  • It is often associated with symptoms such as dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), weight loss, and loss of appetite.

Radiological findings in Achalasia cardia and Carcinoma Esophagus

Feature

Achalasia Cardia

Carcinoma Esophagus

Esophageal Appearance

Massively dilated esophagus

Irregular narrowing of esophagus

Distal Esophagus

Narrow lower end ("bird beak" sign)

Malignant stricture

Location

Affects lower esophageal sphincter

Mid-esophagus in this case

Contour

Smooth tapering at distal end

Irregular, abrupt narrowing

Additional Features

Proximal esophagus is dilated

May show shouldering or "apple core" appearance (not visible in this image)


Fig. Apple core appearance

Incorrect Options:

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B): This condition causes a "corkscrew esophagus" or "rosary bead" appearance on barium swallow

Esophageal leiomyoma (Option C): This benign tumor might appear as a smooth, localized filling defect on barium studies

Esophageal web (Option D): Seen in conditions like Plummer-Vinson syndrome, it presents as a thin, membranous structure causing dysphagia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and is admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-invasive PPV should be given
Explanation: The initial management for acute exacerbation of COPD is non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (PPV), as it helps reduce the work of breathing and improves gas exchange, leading to better outcomes, including reduced hospital duration and improved overall survival outcomes.

Management of Acute Exacerbation of COPD:

  • Initial Management and Assessment:
    • Home management: Increased bronchodilator therapy, short course of oral glucocorticoids, and possibly antibiotics.
    • Hospital referral indicators:
      • Cyanosis
      • Peripheral oedema
      • Altered consciousness
    • Comprehensive assessment upon admission:
      • Level of consciousness (response to commands, ability to cough)
      • Signs of CO2 retention (warm peripheries, bounding pulse, flapping tremor)
      • Airway obstruction assessment (wheeze, prolonged expiration)
      • Signs of cor pulmonale (peripheral oedema, raised JVP)
      • Background functional status and quality of life
      • Precipitating causes (e.g., infection, environmental factors)

 

Investigations:

Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Arterial blood gases

Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation.

Chest X-ray

Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion.

Management Strategies:

Management

Details

Oxygen Therapy
  • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%.
  • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy.

Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)
  • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality.
  • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway.

Bronchodilators
  • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium).
  • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation.

Glucocorticoids
  • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations.
  • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness.
  • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms.

Mechanical Ventilation (Option B)
  • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated.
  • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP.

Additional Therapy
  • Diuretics for peripheral oedema.
  • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk.
  • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates.
  • Discharge and Follow-Up:
    • Discharge criteria:
      • Clinically stable on maintenance medication.
      • Off nebulised therapy for at least 24 hours.
      • PEF reaches 75% of predicted or personal best.
    • Post-exacerbation follow-up:
      • Identify and avoid trigger factors.
      • Provide asthma education and a written self-management plan.

 

IV corticosteroids should be administered (Option C): Systemic corticosteroids are helpful in treating acute COPD exacerbations by reducing airway inflammation and improving lung function over time, but their effects are not immediate. Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV), on the other hand, provides immediate respiratory support, reducing the work of breathing and stabilizing the patient's condition, making it the priority in the initial management.

Permissive hypercapnia is allowed (Option D): Permissive hypercapnia involves allowing elevated carbon dioxide levels to avoid lung injury from over-ventilation, but this is not an approach used in the initial management of acute COPD exacerbations. The goal during the acute phase is to normalize blood gases and relieve respiratory distress, which is best achieved with NIPPV. Permissive hypercapnia is typically considered only after NIPPV fails and invasive positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is required.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
Explanation: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

  • X-linked recessive
  • Caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP)
  • Pathology:
    • Mutations in the WASP gene affect T lymphocytes and other lymphocyte subsets, i.e. dendritic cells, and platelets
    • WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cell.s
    • Clinical Triad: Immunodeficiency, thrombocytopenia, and eczema.
  • Clinical manifestation:
    • Recurrent bacterial infections
    • Eczema
    • Bleeding
    • Associated with IBD - Colitis
    • Increased risk of development of malignant lymphoma
  • Investigation:
    • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Paradoxically the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated
    • Blood smear: Thrombocytopenia, reduced-sized platelets, impaired platelet aggregation.
    • Diagnosis is made by expression of intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) in blood cells. There is defective or absent WAS protein.
  • Treatment:
    • Prophylactic antibiotics
    • Immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation
    • Topical treatment of eczema

 

Chediak-Higashi syndrome (Option B) (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections, partial oculocutaneous albinism, neurologic abnormalities, and thrombocytopenia. However, eczema is not a feature of CHS.

Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome (Option B) (TAR syndrome) is characterized by severe thrombocytopenia at birth and the absence of the radius bone in the forearm, with thumbs typically present. Eczema is not part of the presentation in TAR syndrome.

Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome (Option D) involves oculocutaneous albinism, platelet dysfunction causing bleeding, pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis. While thrombocytopenia and recurrent infections may occur, eczema is not a characteristic of this syndrome.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intussusception

Explanation:

  • The barium study findings shows barium in the lumen of the intussusception, intramural space, and an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, are consistent with intussusception.
  • The description of a "coiled spring appearance" is a classic radiological finding associated with Intussuseption.

Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into another, often leading to bowel obstruction and ischemia.
  • It is a common cause of acute abdomen in children, while in adults, it is typically associated with a focal lesion acting as a lead point.
  • The classic clinical presentation of intussusception in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable "sausage-like" mass in the right upper quadrant, although these symptoms occur in less than 20% of cases.
  • Parents may also report "currant jelly" stools, indicating bowel ischemia, and approximately 15% of patients may present without abdominal pain.
  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Elongated soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
    • Bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels and proximal bowel dilation.
    • Possible absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.
  • Fluoroscopy:
    • Gold standard is the contrast enema, showing the intussusception as an occluding mass.
    • Characteristic "coiled spring sign."
  • Ultrasound:
    • Target sign (doughnut sign)- Concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechoic bands are observed, where the echogenic bands represent the serosa and submucosa, flanking the hypoechoic muscularis propria.
    • Pseudokidney sign- Longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted segment of bowel which mimics a kidney
    • Crescent in a doughnut sign.
    • Absence of blood flow in the intussusceptum (contraindication for enema).
    • Features favoring ileocolic intussusception: hyperechoic core, thicker outer hypoechoic wall, larger anteroposterior diameter, and presence of lymph nodes.
  • CT Scan:
    • Characteristic "bowel-within-bowel" configuration.
    • Concentric rings of bowel on axial images, and sausage-shaped mass on longitudinal images.
    • Visualization of the lead point if present, with surrounding mesenteric fat and vessels.

Incorrect Options:  

Volvulus (Option B): This is twisting of a bowel loop, typically causing a "bird beak" or "coffee bean" appearance on imaging, not a coiled spring pattern.

Diverticulitis (Option C): This involves inflammation of diverticula. Imaging may show thickened bowel walls or abscesses but does not produce a coiled spring appearance.

Ulcerative colitis (Option D): This causes continuous inflammation of the colonic mucosa with findings such as lead pipe appearance on barium studies, not a coiled spring pattern.

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Esophageal dysmotilit

Explanation: 

  • Esophageal dysmotility is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

 

Limited v/s Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

Feature

Limited Cutaneous SSc

Diffuse Cutaneous SSc

Skin involvement
  • Indolent onset
  • Limited to fingers, distal to elbows, face
  • Slow progression
  • Rapid onset
  • Diffuse: fingers, extremities, face, trunk
  • Rapid progression

Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Antedates skin involvement, sometimes by years
  • May be associated with critical ischemia in the digits
  • Onset coincident with skin involvement
  • Critical ischemia less common

Musculoskeletal (Option B)

Mild arthralgia
  • Severe arthralgia
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Tendon friction rubs
  • Frequent, early onset and progression, can be severe

Esophageal dysmotility

90% of cases

80% of cases

Interstitial lung disease (Option C)
  • Slowly progressive
  • Generally mild

Frequent, early onset and progression, can be severe

Pulmonary arterial hypertension

Frequent, late, may occur as an isolated complication

Often occurs in association with interstitial lung disease

Scleroderma renal crisis (Option D)

Very rare

Occurs in 15%; generally early (<4 years from disease onset)

Calcinosis cutis

Frequent, prominent

Less common, mild

Characteristic autoantibodies

Anti-centromere

Anti-topoisomerase (Scl-70), anti-RNA polymerase III

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aortic regurgitation

Explanation: Water hammer pulse is seen in Aortic regurgitation.

Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse/ Corrigan's pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

 

Aortic stenosis (Option A): Severe aortic stenosis is associated with pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by a carotid pulse that rises slowly and peaks late due to restricted blood flow through the narrowed valve, which is distinct from the bounding water hammer pulse seen in aortic regurgitation.

Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation (Option C): In cases where aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation coexist, the stenosis reduces the stroke volume ejected into the aorta, limiting the high-amplitude and rapid upstroke typical of a water hammer pulse seen in isolated aortic regurgitation.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D): Chronic mitral regurgitation shows a sharp, low-volume pulse due to reduced forward cardiac output, while acute mitral regurgitation may present with a narrow pulse pressure. Neither scenario produces the rapid upstroke and collapse characteristic of a water hammer pulse.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH=7.30, HCO3=10 mEq/L, paCO2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

Explanation: The mechanism for the secondary disorder is Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout.

  • The arterial blood gas findings indicate partially compensated metabolic acidosis. Compensation is incomplete because the reduction in PaCO2 is insufficient for the degree of bicarbonate reduction, suggesting a secondary respiratory acidosis caused by hypoventilation. Hypoventilation reduces the ability to wash out CO2, leading to higher-than-expected PaCO2 levels.
  • The expected PaCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula:
    • Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 × HCO3−) + 8 ± 2
    • For HCO3− = 10 mEq/L:
    • Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 × 10) + 8 ± 2 = 21 to 25 mmHg.
  • The actual PaCO2 of 30 mmHg exceeds the expected range, indicating an additional respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation. Thus a mixed acid-base disorder is present, combining metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis.

 

Hyperventilation causing decreased CO₂ washout (Option B): Hyperventilation would enhance CO₂ elimination, leading to a lower PaCO₂, which would provide better compensation for metabolic acidosis. However, in this case, the PaCO₂ is higher than expected (30 mmHg compared to the expected 21-25 mmHg), which rules out hyperventilation. Instead, the findings indicate inadequate CO₂ elimination due to hypoventilation.

Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO₃⁻ (Option C): Increased tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate occurs as a renal compensation mechanism in response to respiratory acidosis, not metabolic acidosis. Since this is primarily a case of metabolic acidosis, increased bicarbonate reabsorption is not the compensatory mechanism here.

Increased excretion of H⁺ (Option D) by the kidneys is a compensatory response to metabolic acidosis, but it is a slower process that takes days to have a significant effect. This mechanism does not explain the higher-than-expected PaCO₂ observed in this case, which is due to hypoventilation causing decreased CO₂ elimination.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for a cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification seen on MRI is a craniopharyngioma.
  • Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors that arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch, which is an embryonic structure.
  • They are often located in the suprasellar region, near the pituitary gland. The presence of calcifications is a characteristic feature of craniopharyngiomas and can help differentiate them from other suprasellar lesions.

Craniopharyngioma

  • Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch.
  • It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Adamantinomatous subtype
    • It is more common
    • Seen in children
    • Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications.
  • Papillary subtype
    • Seen in Adults
    • Primarily solid lesion
    • Rarely exhibit calcifications

Pituitary Adenoma (Option B)

Pituitary Microadenomas

  • Less than 10 mm in size.
  • Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
  • In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland.

Pituitary Macroadenomas

  • Larger than 10 mm in size.
  • Most of the macroadenomas are nonfunctioning.
  • They may cause endocrine disturbances or compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Typically appear as sellar-suprasellar masses with a “snowman” or “figure of eight” appearance due to a waist at the diaphragma sellae.
  • The sella is usually enlarged.
  • These tumors can invade the cavernous sinuses.


 

Meningioma (Option C)
  • Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings.
  • They are the most common benign intracranial tumors.
  • Most common in females
  • Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation.
  • Meningiomas are dural based extra-axial masses that appear isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2-weighted images.
  • They demonstrate intense homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging, accompanied by a dural tail sign.
  • Characteristic imaging features:
    • CSF cleft sign (thin layer of CSF around the mass)
    • Cortical buckling
    • Widening of the subarachnoid space with visible pial arteries/veins,
    • Hyperostosis or erosion of the calvarium.
    • Mother in law sign (early enhancement during the arterial phase and remain opacified long after the venous phase has passed)
    • Calcification

Oligodendroglioma (Option D)
  • Oligodendrogliomas are diffuse infiltrating glial tumors originating from oligodendrocytes and are characterized by IDH mutations and 1p/19q codeletion.
  • These tumors can be either WHO grade 2 (well-differentiated oligodendrogliomas) or WHO grade 3 (anaplastic oligodendrogliomas).
  • Typically occurs in the frontal lobe.
  • They are slow-growing, non-encapsulated, and tend to infiltrate the overlying cortex.
  • CT: Oligodendrogliomas are isodense to hypodense with calcification
  • MRI: Tumors are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2. They generally do not enhance with contrast

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, which type of achalasia does the patient have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Type III

  • The given description in the question, massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions, corresponds to Type III achalasia and is defined by spastic contractions of the oesophagus.

Chicago Classification of Esophageal Motility (4.0)

Esophageal Disorder

Description

Values

1. Achalasia

Type I

Minimal contractility (Option B ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis

Type II

Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option A ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurisation

Type III

Spastic contractions (Option D)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO)

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis

3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s)

4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus

Extremely strong peristaltic contractions

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM)

Weak or failed peristalsis

Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis)

6. Absent Contractility

Complete lack of esophageal contractility

Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis

Type IV (Option C) is not part of the classification mentioned above.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 30% is associated with Hepatitis B

Explanation: 30% of polyarteritis nodosa is associated with Hepatitis B.

Polyarteritis Nodosa:

  • A multisystem, necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries. (Option A)
  • Characteristically involves renal and visceral arteries.
  • Kidneys: Arteritis without glomerulonephritis; glomerulosclerosis may be seen in hypertensive patients.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa-like vasculitis may be seen in 30% of patients with hepatitis B, with circulating immune complexes composed of hepatitis B antigen and immunoglobulin.
  • Pathology and Pathogenesis:
    • Vascular lesion: Necrotizing inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries.
    • Lesions are segmental, involving bifurcations and branches of arteries.
    • In acute stages: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils infiltrate vessel walls and perivascular areas, causing intimal proliferation and degeneration.
    • In subacute and chronic stages: Mononuclear cells infiltrate, leading to fibrinoid necrosis, lumen compromise, thrombosis, infarction, and hemorrhage.
    • Aneurysmal dilations up to 1 cm in size are characteristic.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Nonspecific symptoms: Fever, weight loss, malaise, weakness, headache, abdominal pain, myalgias.
    • Renal involvement: Hypertension, renal insufficiency, hemorrhage due to microaneurysms.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance (eosinophilia is rare).
    • Anemia of chronic disease.
    • Elevated ESR and CRP.
    • Hypergammaglobulinemia may be present. (Option B)
    • Hepatitis B and C screening is essential.
  • ANCA is rarely present. (Option C)
  • Diagnosis: Based on biopsy of involved organs (e.g., nodular skin lesions, painful testes, nerve/muscle) for vasculitis findings.
  • Treatment:
    • Prednisone and cyclophosphamide significantly improve survival.
    • In patients with hepatitis B or C, antiviral therapy should be included along with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there’s elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Heart failure
Explanation: The patient’s symptoms, including progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema, are indicative of heart failure.

Clinical features of Congestive Heart Failure:

  • Cardiac output decreased
  • Stroke volume decreased
  • Heart rate increased
  • Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

 

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

 

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop

 

Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal edema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

 

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option B): While hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea, the patient’s clinical signs of elevated JVP, hepatojugular reflux, crackles, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are more indicative of heart failure due to volume overload, which is not a characteristic feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Mitral regurgitation (Option C): Although mitral regurgitation can lead to heart failure, the signs observed here (e.g., ascites, pedal edema, crackles) indicate a more generalized failure of the heart to pump blood effectively, which is more consistent with heart failure (particularly congestive heart failure) rather than isolated mitral regurgitation.

Portal hypertension (Option D) can occur secondary to right heart failure, but the progressive dyspnea, along with the extensive signs of systemic congestion (e.g., elevated JVP, ascites, hepatojugular reflux), points toward a primary cardiac condition like heart failure.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TAPVC

Explanation:

  • Plethoric lung fields are seen on chest X-ray when there is increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • In TAPVC, pulmonary veins connect abnormally to the systemic venous circulation instead of the left atrium. This results in mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and congestion.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathology
  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection
  • Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion

Sites of venous connection
  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava (Most common)
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation
  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure
  • With ASD- wide and split S2

Chest X-ray
  • Snowman or figure-8 configuration in supracardiac TAPVC

Treatment
  • Surgery
  • No indication for prostaglandins (Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion)

Incorrect Options:

Tricuspid atresia (Option B): is a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is completely closed or absent. It leads to cyanosis and reduced pulmonary blood flow, which is typically associated with diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields.

Ebstein anomaly (Option C): is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal tricuspid valve anatomy. It results in a displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle, causing right atrial enlargement. Plethoric lung fields are not a characteristic radiological finding associated with this condition.

TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot) (Option D): TOF is a congenital heart defect characterized by four specific abnormalities in the heart's structure. It includes a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. While TOF can result in a right-to-left shunt and cyanosis, it typically leads to reduced pulmonary blood flow and diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a middle-aged man who comes to the emergency department with upper abdominal pain following a large meal? During clinical examination, there is tenderness in the upper abdomen, and a chest X-ray reveals a widening of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

  • The given presentation, along with the findings on chest X-ray, is suggestive of esophageal perforation, particularly a spontaneous perforation (also known as Boerhaave syndrome).
  • It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation.
  • The rupture leads the gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Classic triad: Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema).
  • Symptoms: May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis.
  • Physical exam: Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema).
  • Complications: Pneumothorax, mediastinitis, and sepsis.

Perforation of peptic ulcer (Option B) can cause localised abdominal pain and even air under the diaphragm, but not pneumomediastinum.

Foreign body in esophagus (Option C) presents with dysphagia, odynophagia, and discomfort. The clinical signs and pneumomediastinum on the X-ray are more suggestive of perforation or rupture rather than foreign body ingestion.

Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung (Option D) generally presents with respiratory symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or cough, particularly in patients with COPD. The lack of these symptoms makes it less likely than oesophagal perforation.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • The presence of blood in the cisterns on a CT scan is a hallmark of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). SAH occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, often caused by the rupture of an aneurysm or trauma.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.

Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern

Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

Incorrect Options:

Meningitis (Option A): Presents with headache, neck stiffness, and fever but does not show blood on CT. Meningitis may show leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI or CT with contrast.

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Blood would appear within the brain parenchyma, not in the cisterns. Common causes include hypertension or trauma.

Hemorrhagic stroke (Option D): While hemorrhagic strokes can include intraparenchymal or subarachnoid hemorrhages, the specific finding of blood in the cisterns points more specifically to subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of myelin sheath

Explanation: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to the loss of myelin sheath.

Multiple sclerosis

  • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring), and neuronal loss.
  • The course can be relapsing or progressive.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Immune hypothesis: Increased T lymphocytes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and higher immunoglobulin synthesis in the CNS
    • Blood-brain barrier (BBB) injury: Activated T lymphocytes cross the blood-brain barrier, recognize myelin antigens on nervous system antigen-presenting cells (microglia) and proliferate
    • Demyelination:
      • Inflammatory cascade releases cytokines, leading to oligodendrocyte- myelin destruction by macrophages
      • Lesions: disintegration of myelin, lymphocyte/macrophage infiltration, and perivascular inflammation
      • Ectopic lymphoid follicles are linked to demyelination and neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex
      • Diffusible factors from these lymphoid cells may cause demyelination and neurodegeneration
    • Axonal damage:
      • Demyelination reduces trophic support for axons, redistributes ion channels, and destabilizes action potential membrane potentials
      • Neuronal and axonal death may result from glutamate excitotoxicity, oxidative injury, iron accumulation, and mitochondrial failure
      • Inflammatory mediators like nitric oxide initiate and worsen axonal damage
      • Axons can adapt initially to these injuries, but over time, distal and retrograde degeneration (“dying-back” axonopathy) occurs
      • Axonal loss accumulates over time due to repeated attacks and lack of neurotrophic factors from oligodendrocytes
    • Plaque formation:
      • After acute attacks, gliosis occurs by astrocyte cells, forming scars.
      • Surviving oligodendrocytes partially remyelinate axons causing shadow plaques.
    • Oligodendrocyte precursor cells often fail to differentiate into myelin-producing cells.
    • Long-term myelin loss leads to reduced impulse propagation and conduction block, impairing CNS functions.

 

 

Gliosis (Option A): This refers to the proliferation of glial cells (especially astrocytes) in response to central nervous system injury. While gliosis occurs in MS as part of the tissue response to demyelination and inflammation, it is not the primary cause of slowed conduction. Instead, it is a secondary effect resulting from the damage.

Defect at the Node of Ranvier (Option C): Nodes of Ranvier are small gaps in the myelin sheath where voltage-gated sodium channels are concentrated, allowing for the rapid "jumping" of action potentials (saltatory conduction). Although defects at these nodes can disrupt impulse propagation, in multiple sclerosis the main problem is the loss of myelin rather than a defect in the nodes themselves.

Leaky Na⁺ Channels (Option D): In demyelinated axons, the redistribution or abnormal functioning of sodium channels can occur, which may contribute to conduction issues. However, this change is a consequence of myelin loss rather than a primary cause of conduction slowing. The loss of the insulating myelin sheath is the key factor impairing the proper function of these channels.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered neuroendocrine tumour in the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Insulinoma

  • Insulinoma is the most common type of neuroendocrine tumour found in the pancreas, which is usually benign and results in excessive insulin secretion, causing hypoglycemia.

Insulinoma

Category

Details

Definition

A rare, typically benign tumour of the pancreatic islet cells that produce excess insulin.

Clinical Features

Whipple's Triad:

  • Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes
  • Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose
  • Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise

Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures)

Diagnosis
  • Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast.
  • Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia
  • Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic
  • Imaging:
    • CT, MRI, EUS

Management
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
  • Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumours.

Gastrinoma (Option A) is a neuroendocrine tumour that arises from the cells producing gastrin in the pancreas. While they are commonly associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which involves excessive gastrin production and gastric acid hypersecretion, they are less common than insulinomas.

Somatostatinoma (Option B) is a somatostatin-secreting tumour usually found in the pancreas or duodenum and is rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome.

VIPoma (Option D) is a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). They cause Verner-Morrison syndrome, characterised by watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. VIPomas are much less common than insulinomas.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. Which of the following is not a parameter in the selection criteria for transplantation?

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Jaundice less than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy

  • Jaundice is not a parameter in the Nazer Prognostic Index for liver transplantation. It’s the other parameters (age, PT, and bilirubin levels) that are considered critical in assessing prognosis and transplant eligibility.
  • NAZER prognostic index:
    • It is used to calculate the prognosis of the liver disease and determine the need for liver transplantation.
    • A failed medical treatment indicates the need for liver transplantation.
    • It is indicated in a patient with acute liver failure due to Wilson disease with a NAZER prognostic score of 9 or more.

 

Laboratory measurement

(Other options ruled out)

 

Score (in points)

Normal value

1

4

Serum bilirubin

0.2-1.2 mg/dL

<5.8

5.8-8.8

8.8-11.7

>17.5

Serum aspartate transferase

10-35 IU/L

<100

100-150

151-200

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of his hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of his hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sickle cell anaemia

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a child with fever, recurrent swelling of the hands, and a shrunken spleen is consistent with the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia.

Clinical Features of Sickle Cell Anemia:

  • Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) persists up to 6 months of life, with a residual amount (<1%) in adulthood.
  • In regions without newborn screening, affected children are typically identified after 6 months of age.
  • Sickle cell disease does not predispose to neonatal jaundice.
  • Fever:
    • Autosplenectomy, along with reduced splenic function, increases susceptibility to infections from encapsulated bacteria:
      • Pneumococci
      • Meningococci
      • H. influenzae
  • Acute abdominal pain:
    • Occurs during vaso-occlusion or distal tissue ischemia.
    • Constant, non-positional abdominal pain, not aggravated by food, was located in the left upper quadrant and epigastric area.
    • Misdiagnosed as acute pancreatitis or splenic abscess.
  • Bone pain:
    • Sickled cells can obstruct blood flow in blood vessels supplying the bones, leading to inadequate oxygen delivery.
    • Lack of oxygen to bone tissue can cause cell death, leading to a complication called avascular necrosis (AVN).
    • IOC for avascular necrosis: MRI
  • Dactylitis/Hand and foot syndrome:
    • Refers to painful, symmetric swelling of the hands and feet in children with sickle cell disease.
    • It occurs due to infarction of the metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges caused by sickled erythrocytes blocking blood vessels.
    • Swelling is followed by hyperemia and subperiosteal new bone formation, visible on radiographs 10-14 days after the swelling subsides.

 

Malaria (Option B): While malaria can cause splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) due to the sequestration of parasitized red blood cells, it does not typically lead to splenic atrophy (shrunken spleen). Additionally, recurrent hand swelling is not a characteristic symptom of malaria.

Pancreatitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the pancreas, typically presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. It does not cause symptoms such as fever, hand swelling, or splenic atrophy, which are present in this patient.

Measles (Option D) is a viral infection primarily affecting the respiratory system, with characteristic symptoms such as cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash. It does not cause splenic atrophy or recurrent hand swelling, making it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well’s score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High
Explanation: The risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient, according to the Well’s score, is high.

Based on the Well's Clinical Prediction Rule for Pulmonary Embolism (PE) in the given patient scenario:

  • Clinical signs of deep-vein thrombosis (patient has swelling in the legs, pain on palpation) = 3 points
  • Alternative diagnosis is less likely than PE = 3 points
  • Heart rate >100 beats/min (heart rate is 70 beats per minute) = 0 points
  • Immobilization >3 days or surgery in previous 4 weeks (patient had hip replacement surgery one week ago) = 1.5 points
  • History of deep-vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism = 0 points
  • Hemoptysis (no hemoptysis) = 0 points
  • Malignancy (with treatment within 6 months) or palliative = 0 points

Total score = 7.5, indicating high risk for pulmonary embolism.

 

Well’s Clinical Prediction Rule for Pulmonary Embolism (PE):

Clinical Feature

Points

Clinical signs of deep-vein thrombosis

3

Alternative diagnosis is less likely than PE

3

Heart rate >100 beats/min

1.5

Immobilization >3 days or surgery in previous 4 weeks

1.5

History of deep-vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism

1.5

Hemoptysis

1

Malignancy (with treatment within 6 months) or palliative

1

 

Interpretation

Score Range

Risk

High

>6.0

High

Intermediate

2.0 - 6.0

Intermediate

Low

<2.0

Low

questions.text: Which layer is accountable for preserving the moisture and clarity of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endothelium

Explanation:

Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

(Option D ruled out)
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)

  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane (Option A ruled out)
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

(Option B)
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: What is the distinguishing characteristic of a fungal ulcer?

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Satellite lesion

Explanation:

Keratomycosis

Clinical Features

  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering of the eye
  • Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision
  • Redness.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry-looking with elevated, rolled-out margins.
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish appearance, possible with dematiaceous fungi.
  • Feathery Extensions: Delicate, finger-like projections into the surrounding stroma.
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation where fungal antigen and host antibodies meet.
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Multiple small lesions around the main ulcer.
  • Hypopyon (Option A ruled out): Large, non-sterile, even with a small ulcer.
  • Endothelial Plaque: Located under the stromal lesion, made of fibrin and leucocytes.
  • Corneal Vascularization: Typically absent in pure fungal ulcers.
  • Perforation: Rare but possible.

Investigations

  • Corneal Scraping: Performed under topical anaesthesia for microbiological examination.
