  • Wet KOH Mount: Reveals filamentous fungi (branched, septate hyphae) or non-filamentous yeast-like fungi (Candida).
  • Gram's & Giemsa Stains: To detect fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells.
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar medium is used for fungal culture.
  • PCR: Recommended for rapid identification of fungal pathogens.
  • Anterior Chamber Paracentesis: Considered if there is an intraocular extension.
  • Corneal Biopsy: Indicated for deep stromal abscess or when cultures are negative.
  • Confocal Microscopy: Used for identifying actual fungi within the cornea.

Incorrect Options: 

Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye (Option B) is a characteristic finding of herpetic keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Ring abscess (Option C) is seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis commonly seen in patients using contact lens and using tap water to clean it.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Complication of surgery

  • The Thoracoscore is a risk assessment tool used to evaluate the operative risk in patients undergoing thoracic surgery, but complications of surgery are not a component of it.
  • The components of thoracoscore are:
    • Age: <55 years, 55-65 years, >65 years
    • Sex
    • ASA Classification: ≤2, ≥3 (Option C ruled out)
    • Performance status (Zubrod scale): ≤2, ≥3 (Option A ruled out)
    • Severity of dyspnea (Medical Research Council Scale): ≤2, ≥3
    • Surgery Priority: Elective, Urgent/Emergency (Option D ruled out)
    • Extent of resection: Pneumonectomy, Other
    • Diagnosis: Malignant, Benign
    • Comorbidity score

questions.text: The drug increasing uveoscleral flow is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Latanoprost

Explanation:

Medical management of glaucoma

1. Medical:

The drugs either decrease the formation of aqueous or increase the drainage to decrease IOP. This is of 2 types:

  1. Topical (6 types)
  2. Systemic (2 types)

Topical:

  • Beta-blockers
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: Timolol (Option A) , betaxolol
    • C/I in asthma
    • S/E: corneal anesthesia and blepharoconjunctivitis
  • Alpha agonists:
    • They have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
    • Brimonidine is safe in pregnancy
    • Adrenaline is C/I in aphakic glaucoma
  • Miotics:
    • These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage
    • Eg: Pilocarpine (Option C)
    • S/E of Pilocarpine: Pseudo myopia, retinal detachment, shallow anterior chamber, iris cysts
  • Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors:
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: dorzolamide and brinzolamide
    • These are C/I in sulpha allergies
  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: this increases the contractile property of the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing the trabecular outflow and it also decreases the aqueous production.
    • It is a Rho-kinase inhibitor
    • S/E: vortex keratopathy
  • PGF2 alpha agonist:
    • It increases the uveoscleral outflow
    • These are also contraindicated in uveitis and asthma
    • For eg- Latanoprost (Option B), bimatoprost, travoprost , tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl
    • Latanoprost causes heterochromia iridis
    • Bimatoprost increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow
    • Side effects: Hypertrichosis

Systemic:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • For eg: acetazolamide(Option D), methazolamide
    • S/E: Tingling and numbness, constipation, renal stones, and a bad metallic taste
  • Hyperosmotic agents:
    • These draw aqueous out of the eye
    • For eg: I/V mannitol (C/I in heart disease), glycerol (C/I in diabetes), isosorbide, and urea

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with fatigue. Imaging revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones and a large stone in the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • The next step in the management of this patient is ERCP, which is used to relieve biliary obstruction caused by the stone in the common bile duct.
  • It is a procedure that combines endoscopy and fluoroscopy to visualise and treat conditions affecting the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts.
  • It allows for the removal of common bile duct stones, dilation of strictures, and placement of stents to relieve biliary obstruction.
  • It has both diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities.
  • Stones up to 12 mm can usually be removed by Endoscopic Retrograde.

Choledocholithiasis

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater.
  • Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.
  • Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction.

Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy (Option A): Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of the gall bladder. When there is an active obstruction of the bile duct, the focus should first be on relieving the biliary obstruction before considering cholecystectomy. Once the obstruction is addressed, the patient can undergo cholecystectomy to prevent future complications.

Wait and watch (Option C) is not appropriate in this case because the patient has an impacted stone in the common bile duct with associated dilation of the biliary tree and is symptomatic. If left management is delayed, it could lead to complications.

CT scan (Option D) may provide additional information about the extent of the biliary tree dilatation and the presence of other abnormalities, but it does not address the immediate need for intervention to relieve the biliary obstruction.

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Exudative retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • Shifting Fluid sign is seen in Exudative retinal detachment
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

Etiology:

  • Age: most common in 40-60 years.
  • Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2).
  • Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic.
  • Aphakia and pseudophakia.
  • Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor.
  • Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases.
  • Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps.

 

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (Option C)

1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.

2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.

3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.

4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.

6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.

8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option B)

1. Gradual, progressive visual loss

2. Typically painless

3. No associated flashes or floaters

4. Vitreoretinal bands present

5. No retinal breaks

6. Detached area - concave and localized

7. No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option A)

1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss

2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.

3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances

4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.

5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

Retinal dialysis (Option D) involves a circumferential tear at the ora serrata, often due to trauma, but it does not exhibit the shifting fluid sign as seen in exudative detachments.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the finding observed by a physician during an eye examination of a small child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyperopia

Explanation:

Squint / Strabismus / Heterotropia:

  • A condition where the visual axes of both eyes do not meet at a point (Misalignment of Visual axes)
  • Pseudo-Strabismus: Eyes appear misaligned but are actually well-aligned.

Classification of Strabismus:

Heterophoria (Latent Strabismus): (Diagnosed by Cover-Uncover test)

  • A tendency for the visual axes to misalign & is usually corrected by the eye's ability to fuse images.
  • Types:
    • Esophoria: Convergent tendency.
    • Exophoria: Divergent tendency.
    • Hyperphoria: Vertical deviation based on the upwardly deviating eye (e.g., right hyperphoria).
    • Cyclophoria: Torsional deviation.

Manifest Strabismus (Heterotropia):

  • Visible misalignment of the eyes, which is always present and not corrected by the eye's fusional capacity.
  • Types:
    • Esotropia: Inward misalignment of the eyes. (Common in Hypermetropes) (Option C)
    • Exotropia: Outward misalignment of the eyes. (Common in Myopes) (Option A)
    • Hypertropia: Upward misalignment of one eye relative to the other.
    • Hypotropia: Downward misalignment of one eye relative to the other.

Astigmatism (Option B) can blur vision and contribute to refractive issues, it is not directly linked to a specific type of strabismus like hyperopia.

Emmetropia (Option D) refers to normal vision without refractive errors and is not associated with squint development.

questions.text: What stage of Hinchey's classification is indicated when a patient with clinical features suggestive of peritonitis presents with diverticular perforation and faecal peritonitis during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Stage 4

  • The presence of faecal peritonitis indicates that faecal material has spilled into the peritoneal cavity, which is a hallmark of Stage 4 in the Hinchey classification.
  • The Hinchey classification is used to stage the severity of diverticulitis and its associated complications.

Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis)

Stage 0

Mild diverticulitis

Stage 1

(Option A ruled out)

Ia: Pericolic inflammation

Ib: Pericolic abscess

Stage 2

(Option B ruled out)

Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess

Stage 3

(Option C ruled out)

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: What is the likely reason for a patient showing both unilateral and bilateral abducent palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Explanation:

Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI)

Type

Motor

Origin

Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla).

Course

Functional component
  • General somatic efferent fibres: Arise from the abducent nucleus in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball.
  • General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Supply

Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball

Clinical aspect

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to abducens nerve palsy
  • Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to:
    • Inability to abduct the eye
    • Diplopia (double vision)
    • Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus)

Incorrect Options:

Retinoblastoma (Option A) is a type of eye cancer that primarily affects young children. It originates in the retina. It can occur unilaterally and also be bilateral.

Orbital pseudotumor (Option B), also known as idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome, is a condition characterized by inflammation and swelling of the tissues within the orbit.

Orbital cellulitis (Option C) is an infection characterized by inflammation and infection of the soft tissues within the orbit. It is usually caused by the spread of an infection from the adjacent structures, such as the sinuses or eyelids.

questions.text: Which statement regarding retrosternal goitre is accurate?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision:

  • Surgical approach decisions for retrosternal goitre depend on the size, location, and associated symptoms, and while some may require a sternotomy, most can be removed through a neck incision alone.

Retrosternal goitre

Definition
  • A thyroid gland enlargement that extends into the mediastinum behind the Sternum

Types
  • Primary: Ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum (10%)
  • Secondary: Starts from neck and extends retrosternally (90%)

Clinical Features
  • Neck Swelling with Compression Symptoms: Difficulty breathing (tracheal compression) and swallowing (esophageal compression).
  • Pemberton Sign: Facial flushing and increased difficulty breathing when raising the arms due to thoracic inlet compression.

Diagnosis
  • Physical examination: Limited palpation of the lower border of the thyroid swelling.
  • Imaging: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan of the Neck and Chest is IOC to assess the extent of mediastinal involvement and to evaluate compression of surrounding structures.

Management
  • Primary / Recurrent / Large Malignant Retrosternal Goiter - Median Sternotomy (Option B ruled out)
  • Secondary Retrosternal Goiter - Cervical / Neck Incision

Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms (Option A): Surgical resection is the preferred standard for managing symptomatic retrosternal goitres and some asymptomatic cases. However, a "watchful waiting" approach may be appropriate for selected asymptomatic patients, especially with the development of alternative treatments.

It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery (Option C): blood supply to a retrosternal goitre primarily comes from the thyroid arteries, and the thoracodorsal artery mainly supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle, not the thyroid or retrosternal goitre.

questions.text: The movement lost on left gaze as depicted in the image is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3rd CN palsy

Explanation:

  • The image depicts limited adduction of the right eye due to weakness of medial rectus muscle seen in 3rd nerve palsy.
  • The oculomotor nerve is responsible for innervating several extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.

Nerves of the eye:

Optic nerve (CN II)
  • Purely sensory
  • Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles
  • Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle.

Trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V)

  • Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye
  • Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Abducens Nerve (CN VI)
  • Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle

Facial Nerve (CN VII)
  • Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Sympathetic Nervous System
  • Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis

Parasympathetic nervous system
  • Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis

Incorrect Options:

6th CN palsy (Option C) This affects lateral rectus muscle and inability to abduct the eye towards the side of gaze.

4th CN palsy (Option B) This affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to difficulty in looking downward, particularly in an adducted position (e.g., difficulty descending stairs). It does not impact horizontal gaze.

7th CN palsy (Option D) This nerve innervates facial muscles, not extraocular muscles.

questions.text: The lesion in which of the following nerve is responsible for right eye squint, as depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Abducent

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the abducent nerve causes paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abducting the eye. In its absence, the unopposed pull of the medial rectus causes the eye to deviate inward, resulting in esotropia (convergent squint). This condition is commonly seen in abducent nerve palsy.

Paralytic squint : Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint in which ocular deviation results from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles.

  • History of diplopia and confusion
  • Secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation.
  • Ocular movements are restricted towards the action of paralyzed muscle.
  • Head is turned towards the action of paralyzed muscle.

Incorrect Options: 

Oculomotor (Option A) lesion causes ptosis, mydriasis (pupil dilation), and difficulty moving the eye upward, downward, or inward. The eye often rests in a "down and out" position.

Trochlear (Option B) nerve lesion affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and difficulty looking downward, particularly in adduction

Trigeminal (Option C) nerve is responsible for facial sensation and mastication; it does not innervate any extraocular muscles.

questions.text: In MEN 1 syndrome, where is the most frequent occurrence of gastrinoma observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Duodenum

  • In MEN 1 syndrome, the most frequent occurrence of gastrinomas is in the duodenum.
  • Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete gastrin, a hormone that stimulates acid production in the stomach. This leads to conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • These tumours are mainly found in the small intestine or pancreas, with the duodenum being the most common extrapancreatic site for gastrinomas. (Other options ruled out)
  • While surgical resection is indicated in some cases, it is not curative in all. Surgical resection can be curative only if metastasis is absent.
  • Treatment involves proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression, high-dose PPI therapy for acid control, and somatostatin analogues as adjunctive therapy

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nephrogenic DI
 

  • A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to Nephrogenic DI.

Diabetes Insipidus (DI):

  • It is a disorder characterized by excessive hypotonic urinary output (>50 mL/kg body weight per 24 hours) and polydipsia (>3 litres/day).
  • It results from an inability to concentrate urine adequately due to a deficiency or insensitivity to antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
  • Types of Diabetes Insipidus:

 

Feature

Central DI

Nephrogenic DI

Primary Polydipsia

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake, suppressing AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection has no effect on severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

Posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioral therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

Liddle’s syndrome (Option A) is caused by an inherited gain-of-function mutation in genes regulating the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) in the collecting duct.

Cystic fibrosis (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, which encodes a chloride channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells.

Bartter syndrome (Option D) results from loss-of-function mutations in transporters and ion channels in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, most frequently affecting the Na-K-2Cl transporter.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Focal oligemia

  • Focal oligemia, also known as Westermark’s sign, is a radiological finding associated with pulmonary embolism, not left heart failure.

Area of focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) (white arrow), with prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow)

Radiographic Changes in Left Heart Failure:

  • Pulmonary venous dilation and congestion (Option C)
  • Cephalization of pulmonary veins: Upper lobe vessels become more prominent due to redistribution of blood flow (Option D)
  • Kerley B (septal) lines: Horizontal lines caused by interstitial edema (Option A)
  • Thickened interlobar fissures
  • Pulmonary interstitial edema: Blurring of vascular margins and peribronchial cuffing
  • Pulmonary alveolar edema: Bat-wing or butterfly pattern of opacities
  • Pleural effusion
  • Cardiomegaly (increased cardiothoracic ratio)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness, which lasted for a few seconds, followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario?

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation:

  • The patient’s presentation of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness, which lasted only a few seconds and was followed by full recovery, suggests a transient loss of consciousness episode, likely syncope. This could be due to arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, atrioventricular block, ventricular tachyarrhythmia) or structural cardiac abnormalities, making an ECG crucial in this case to rule out cardiac causes.

Syncope:

  • Transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to acute global impairment of cerebral blood flow.
  • Rapid onset, brief duration, and spontaneous, complete recovery.
  • Categories of Syncope Causes:
    • Neurally mediated syncope (reflex or vasovagal syncope)
    • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cardiac syncope
  • Initial Evaluation of Syncope:
    • Detailed history and thorough questioning of eyewitnesses.
    • Complete physical and neurologic examination.
    • Measure blood pressure and heart rate in the supine position and after 3 minutes of standing to assess for orthostatic hypotension.
    • ECG Indications:
      • If there is suspicion of syncope due to arrhythmia or underlying cardiac disease.
      • Relevant electrocardiographic abnormalities include bradyarrhythmias, tachyarrhythmias, AV block, acute myocardial ischemia, old myocardial infarction, long QT, and bundle branch block.

If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done (Option B): A CT scan would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. Given that the episode lasted only a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar events, and there are no lasting neurological deficits, a CT scan is not typically needed at this point.

Tilt-table testing (Option C) is generally reserved for patients with recurrent or unexplained syncope. It is not typically used for a single isolated episode of syncope, especially in the absence of a history of similar events.

Vestibular neuritis (Option D) typically causes dizziness and a sense of spinning (vertigo), but it does not generally lead to loss of consciousness. Since the patient’s primary symptom is syncope (brief loss of consciousness), vestibular neuritis is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/d,l and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Arterial blood gas

  • The child’s presentation with confusion, tachypnea (Kussmaul respirations), dry mucous membranes, hypotension, hyperglycemia, and positive urine ketones strongly points to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The next step is an arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess the severity of acidosis and guide management.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • Is a hyperglycemic emergency characterized primarily by a triad of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical Features:

Symptoms

Signs

  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Shortness of breath
  • Thirst, polyuria
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness
  • Leg cramps
  • Blurred vision
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension (postural or supine)
  • Tachypnea
  • Kussmaul respirations (air hunger)
  • Smell of acetone
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypothermia
  • Cold extremities/peripheral cyanosis
  • Abdominal tenderness (may resemble acute pancreatitis or surgical abdomen)
  • Lethargy/obtundation/cerebral oedema/possibly coma
  • Investigations of DKA:
    • Urine ketostix: Detects acetoacetate and acetate, but cannot detect ß-hydroxybutyrate.
    • Serum ß-hydroxybutyrate: Produced three times more than acetoacetate and is preferred for accurate diagnosis of DKA.
    • Random Blood Sugar: 250 - 600 mg/dL
    • Serum electrolytes:
      • Potassium:
        • Total body potassium deficiency of 3-6 mEq/kg in DKA occurs due to osmotic diuresis and vomiting.
        • Insulin shifts potassium intracellularly, lowering serum levels, and potassium correction with IV potassium chloride (KCl) should be done.
      • Sodium:
        • Serum sodium is reduced due to hyperglycemia: 1.6 meq/L reduction in sodium per 100 mg/dL rise in serum glucose.
        • Dilutional hyponatremia is common due to water driven into the intravascular space from inside cells.
    • Renal function test: Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine.
    • Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis:
      • pH: 6.8-7.3
      • pCO2: 20-30 mmHg
      • HCO3: <18 meq/L
      • Anion gap: Increased
      • Indicates DKA causes High anion gap metabolic acidosis.
    • Serum amylase and lipase: High
    • Total leukocyte count: Increased
    • Phosphorus and magnesium levels: Reduced, but not accurately shown due to hypovolemia and hyperglycemia.

2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours (Option A): Fluid resuscitation is essential in DKA, but without knowing the acid-base status through an ABG, it is not appropriate to start fluid therapy blindly. The ABG will guide the volume and rate of fluid administration based on the patient’s acidosis and hydration status.
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour (Option B): Insulin therapy is critical, but it should be initiated after evaluating the patient’s acid-base status through an ABG. Correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances is essential before starting insulin to avoid complications like hypokalemia and worsening dehydration.
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg (Option D): While insulin is needed, a bolus should not be given without first assessing the acid-base status and correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA):
 

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is associated with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

Microvascular Vasculitis:

Disease

Key Features

Antibodies/Labs

Pathology

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
  • Pauci-immune vasculitis
  • Upper/lower respiratory
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • PR3-ANCA
  • c-ANCA pattern
  • Granulomatous inflammation
  • Small vessel vasculitis

Microscopic Polyangiitis

 
  • Pulmonary-renal syndrome
  • No granulomas
  • Segmental necrotizing GN
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • Necrotizing vasculitis
  • No granulomas

Churg-Strauss Syndrome/ Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangitis (EGPA)

  • Asthma
  • Peripheral eosinophilia
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • MPO-ANCA
  • p-ANCA pattern
  • Eosinophilic granulomas
  • Vasculitis

Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
  • Often HCV-associated
  • Purpura
  • Arthralgias
  • Cryoglobulins
  • HCV antibodies
  • Immune complex deposits
  • Small vessel vasculitis

SLE nephritis (Option A): Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) nephritis involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to kidney inflammation. This is not pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

Anti-GBM glomerulonephritis (Option B) is characterized by antibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), resulting in linear immune complex deposition, not pauci-immune.

IgA nephropathy (Option C): In IgA nephropathy, immunoglobulin A (IgA) is deposited in the glomeruli, causing inflammation. This is an immune complex-mediated disorder and not pauci-immune.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - >140/90 mmHg

  • According to the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for hypertension management:

Indications for Immediate Pharmacological Treatment:

Adults aged 18-79 years with:

  • Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP): ≥140 mmHg
  • Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP): ≥90 mmHg

In patients with no cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological therapy is initiated if the BP is ≥140/90 mmHg.

AHA Hypertension Grading

 

Category

Systolic BP (mmHg)

Diastolic BP (mmHg)

Normal

<120

<80

Elevated

120–129

<80

Hypertension Stage 1

130–139

80–89

Hypertension Stage 2

≥140

≥90

Hypertensive Crisis

>180

>120

ACC/AHA Guidelines for Hypertension Management

Indications for Use of antihypertensives
  • Secondary prevention of recurrent CVD events in patients with clinical CVD (defined as CHD, CHF, stroke) and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg
  • Primary prevention in patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10% and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg
  • Primary prevention of CVD and low CVD risk in patients with BP ≥140/ ≥90 mmHg

Blood Pressure Goal in Treating Hypertension
  • BP target < 130/80 mmHg for adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD event risk ≥10%

Exceptions to Therapeutic Target of <130/80 mmHg
  • Age >80 years
  • Blood pressure <140/90 mmHg in previously untreated hypertensive patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA
  • Acute therapy for most hypertensive urgencies and emergencies

Abbreviations:

  • ASCVD - atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease
  • CHD - coronary heart disease
  • CHF - congestive heart failure
  • CVD - cardiovascular disease

Patient type

First Drug

Add a Second Drug If Needed to Achieve the target BP

If a Third Drug is Needed to Achieve the target BP

Black patients (African ancestry): All ages

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Combination of CCB + ACE inhibitor or ARB + thiazide diuretic

 

 

 

White and other non-black Patients: Younger than 60 years

ARB or ACE inhibitor

CCB or thiazide diuretic

White and other non-black patients: 60 years and older

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Abbreviations:

  • CCB - Calcium channel blocker
  • ACE - Angiotensin converting enzyme
  • ARB - Angiotensin receptor blocker

Hypertension with other associated conditions

Initial drug of choice

Hypertension and diabetes

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and chronic kidney disease

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Note: in black patients, good evidence for the renal protective effects of ACE inhibitors

Hypertension and clinical coronary artery disease

β-Blocker plus ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and stroke history

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and heart failure

Regardless of blood pressure, ARB or ACE inhibitor + β-blocker + diuretic + spironolactone. A dihydropyridine CCB can be added if needed for BP control.

Pneumonic: ABDS

questions.text: A lesion at which level produces incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Wernicke's pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Optic tract

  • Wernicke's pupil occurs due to a lesion at the optic tract, leading to incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

Wernicke’s Hemianopic Pupil:

  • Indicates a lesion in the optic tract.
  • Light Reflex: Ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual light reflexes are both absent in the affected areas.
    • Absent when light is shone on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side.
    • Present when light is shone on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side.

Visual cortex (Option B): Lesions in the visual cortex, located in the occipital lobe, cause congruous homonymous hemianopia (same field defect in both eyes) and do not produce Wernicke's pupil, which is specific to lesions in the optic tract.

Optic radiations (Option C): Lesions in the optic radiations also result in congruous homonymous hemianopia but do not lead to Wernicke's pupil.

Optic nerve (Option D): Lesions in the optic nerve cause monocular vision loss (loss of vision in one eye), not homonymous hemianopia, and therefore do not result in Wernicke's pupil.

questions.text: What should be the next course of action in managing a 50-year-old patient who has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, and is currently presenting with a feeble pulse and a blood pressure reading of 90/40 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C) DC cardioversion

Explanation:

  • Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT) is characterised by a rapid heart rhythm, which in this case is associated with low blood pressure and a weak pulse, making the situation haemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention is essential for stabilisation.
  • DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion delivers a synchronised electrical shock, which is the most effective and rapid method to terminate the tachycardia. This restores sinus rhythm, improving cardiac output and blood pressure in unstable patients.

 

IV adenosine (Option A): Adenosine can transiently halt the tachycardia by inducing temporary AV nodal block. However, in haemodynamically unstable patients, it is not the first choice as it may worsen the instability by causing transient asystole or severe bradycardia.

IV Diltiazem (Option B): Diltiazem slows AV nodal conduction and can terminate PSVT. However, in patients with low blood pressure and haemodynamic instability, it is contraindicated as it may further depress cardiac output and exacerbate hypotension.

Ibutilide (Option D): Ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic, has a slower onset of action and is not appropriate in emergencies requiring immediate restoration of rhythm. It also carries a risk of arrhythmias, such as torsades de pointes.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

Explanation: The patient's symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain point towards hypothyroidism. The increase in TSH levels upon TRH administration indicates a lack of proper stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus.

 

Feature

Primary Hypothyroidism

Secondary Hypothyroidism

Definition

Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production

Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion

Causes
  • Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)
  • Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium)
  • Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis)
  • Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava.
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Sheehan’s syndrome
  • Trauma
  • Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies
  • Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemochromatosis

Lab

TSH - ↑

Free T3/T4 - ↓

TSH - Normal or ↓

Free T3/T4 - ↓

Clinical Features
  • Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance
  • Dry skin, hair loss
  • Increased sleep
  • Bradycardia, constipation
  • Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema)
  • Similar to primary hypothyroidism
  • Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH)

Treatment

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable)

 

Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option A) would result in elevated TSH and thyroid hormone levels, which is not consistent with the patient's low plasma TSH and hypothyroidism symptoms.

Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option B): In pituitary hypothyroidism, TSH would be low due to the lack of pituitary secretion. However, unlike the hypothalamic case, TSH would not increase after TRH administration because the pituitary is unable to respond to TRH.

Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus (Option D): In hypothalamic hyperthyroidism, there would be a lack of feedback inhibition on the hypothalamus and pituitary, leading to elevated TSH and thyroid hormones. This is not consistent with the patient's low TSH and hypothyroidism.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioural change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Explanation: The patient's symptoms of behavioral changes, falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia are indicative of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH), which is commonly associated with the classic triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline.

 

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Clinical Triad
  • Gait disturbance: Progressive difficulties in walking
  • Urinary issues: Urgency or incontinence
  • Cognitive impairment: Decline in cognitive functions

Imaging Characteristics
  • Ventriculomegaly is typically seen
  • Evans ratio: the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy.
  • An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy.
  • A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci.
  • CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

 

 

Frontotemporal dementia (Option B) (FTD) primarily affects personality, behavior, and language, often presenting with early changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and loss of empathy. Urinary incontinence is not a typical early feature of FTD, and gait disturbances or falls are also not commonly seen at the onset, making it less likely in this case.

Parkinson's disease (Option C) primarily presents with motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. While dementia and falls can occur in the later stages, urinary incontinence is not a typical early feature, and the behavioral changes in Parkinson's disease are usually associated with the later stages or due to medication effects, which makes it less consistent with the initial presentation.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Option D) (CJD) is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions, characterized by rapidly progressing dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and other neurological signs. While behavioral changes can occur, urinary incontinence and multiple falls are not typical presenting features of CJD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism Category A agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anthrax

Explanation:

  • The CDC classifies bioterrorism agents into three categories (A, B, and C) based on their ease of dissemination, mortality rates, and public health impact.
 

Category A

Category B

Category C

Priority

High-priority agents posing a risk to national security

Second highest priority

Third highest priority with emerging pathogens

The reason they are classified into the respective categories:
  • Easily disseminated in the environment
  • High mortality risk
  • Cause public panic and social disruption
  • Requires special action for public health preparedness
  • Moderately easy to disseminate.
  • Moderate morbidity risk.
  • Requires enhanced disease surveillance.
  • It can be engineered for mass dissemination in the future.
  • It has the potential for high mortality and morbidity.

Examples:
  • Bacillus anthracis - Anthrax (Option B)
  • Francisella tularensis - Tularemia
  • Clostridium botulinum - Botulism
  • Yersinia pestis - Bubonic plague
  • Ebola virus - Ebola hemorrhagic fever
  • Clostridium perfringens - epsilon toxin.
  • Cryptosporidium parvum.
  • Escherichia coli (O157:H7)
  • Shigella dysenteriae.
  • Salmonella.
  • Vibrio cholera.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Option C ruled out)
  • Brucella (Option D ruled out)
  • Hantavirus
  • MDR-tuberculosis
  • Nipah Virus (Option A ruled out)
  • Yellow fever
  • Tick-borne encephalitis /hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shock

Explanation: Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy.

Pituitary apoplexy

Pathology

  • Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency
  • It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock.
  • Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal

Clinical features

  • Severe headache
  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Loss of consciousness (secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock) (Option C)
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypotension (Option A)
  • Shock
  • Cardiovascular collapse

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids are the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia.
  • Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness.
  • Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough for 5 days. Chest X-ray findings suggest the diagnosis. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Parainfluenza

Explanation:

  • The child’s barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and low-grade fever are characteristic of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).
  • Chest X-ray finding: "Steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing), a hallmark of croup.
  • Croup is most commonly caused by Parainfluenza virus (types 1 and 2 and 3).

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Mild cough,
  • Low-grade fever.

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough,
  • Hoarseness,
  • Inspiratory stridor,
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice,
  • Coryza,
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Incorrect Options:

Moraxella (Option A): Causes otitis media and sinusitis, not croup. Not associated with stridor or the steeple sign.

Ebola virus (Option C): Causes viral hemorrhagic fever with bleeding, high fever, and multiorgan failure. Does not cause croup or inspiratory stridor.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option D): Can cause bacterial tracheitis, which presents with high fever, toxic appearance, and purulent secretions. Not the most common cause of croup-like symptoms in children.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 60-year-old man who is grieving the loss of his wife and expressing guilt, believing his intestines have deteriorated and that he deserves to be imprisoned? He also reports persistent sadness and a lack of interest in daily activities since his wife's passing.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psychotic depression

Explanation:

  • The patient's depressive symptoms (anhedonia, sadness) coupled with guilt-driven psychotic delusions strongly suggest psychotic depression. His delusions and guilt (feeling that he deserves punishment) are classic features of depression with psychosis.
  • Patients with Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features experience psychotic symptoms only during mood episodes.

Psychotic depression

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

Occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

 

Older patients may exhibit more brain atrophy and higher mortality rates compared to non-psychotic patients.

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective.

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Normal grief reaction (Option A) is a natural response to loss, and it typically involves sadness, yearning, and a range of emotional reactions. However, it is usually not associated with psychotic symptoms such as delusions.

Delusional disorder (Option C) is characterised by the presence of delusions, but it is typically not accompanied by mood disturbances like depression. The patient’s depressive symptoms (persistent sadness, anhedonia) point towards psychotic depression.

Schizophrenia (Option D) is a chronic, severe mental illness that is often characterised by delusions, hallucinations, disorganised thinking, and negative symptoms. Although delusions are present, the patient's symptoms are more in line with depression than with schizophrenia, which is a more pervasive and chronic disorder not typically linked to a recent loss.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema, and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with respiratory distress, hypotension, subcutaneous emphysema, and absent air entry on the right side following a trauma, indicating tension pneumothorax. The next best step is needle decompression at the 5th intercostal space, anterior to the midaxillary line.

 

TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
    • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
      • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
      • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
      • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.

  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

 

Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula (Option A): While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the underlying problem of tension pneumothorax, which is the primary cause of the patient's instability.

Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him (Option C): Intubation and ICU care may be necessary later, but delaying decompression can lead to rapid deterioration. Positive pressure ventilation without prior decompression could worsen the tension pneumothorax.

Start positive pressure ventilation (Option D): This is contraindicated in tension pneumothorax because it can further increase intrathoracic pressure and exacerbate the condition, leading to cardiovascular collapse

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment option for postpartum blues?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Support and Education

Explanation:

  • Postpartum blues, also known as baby blues, is a common and temporary mood disturbance that typically occurs in the first few days following childbirth, the condition is usually self-limiting, resolving on its own within a couple of weeks.
  • Hence, support and education are the first-line interventions for postpartum blues.

 

Postpartum Blues

Postpartum Depression

Postpartum Psychosis

Occurrence

It affects up to 80% of women after childbirth
  • It affects 10 - 15% of women
  • 70% risk of recurrence in the next pregnancy
  • Incidence is about 1-2 in 1000 deliveries
  • 50% risk of recurrence in the next pregnancy

Timing

Onset 3-5 days postpartum, resolves by days to weeks

Within the first 6 weeks postpartum or after abortion

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months.

Symptoms

Transient symptoms such as

  • Emotionally labile
  • Insomnia
  • Weepiness
  • Loss of energy
  • Depressed mood
  • Loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia)
  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal thoughts

Initial symptoms: insomnia, tearfulness, mood lability, fatigue, followed by

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions

Treatment

Supportive treatment and reassurance

Antidepressants and psychotherapy
  • Hospitalization, pharmacological treatment (lithium, antipsychotics, antidepressants), long-term psychiatric care
  • Temporary separation from the infant and nursing supervision may be necessary

Fluoxetine (Option A) is an SSRI and is commonly used for major depressive disorder and anxiety disorders. While it may be used for postpartum depression, it is not recommended for postpartum blues, as these symptoms are mild and transient.

Cognitive behavioural therapy (Option B) is not necessary for postpartum blues, which is generally mild and self-limiting. However, if postpartum blues evolve into postpartum depression, CBT might become part of the treatment strategy.
Lithium carbonate (Option C) is a mood stabiliser that is used for bipolar disorder; it is not the first-line treatment for postpartum blues as they are generally mild and self-limiting, it may be used in severe postpartum depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fimbriae

Explanation:

Fimbriae (also called pili) are hair-like appendages on the surface of bacteria.

  • They play a crucial role in bacterial adhesion to host tissues and surfaces, facilitating the formation of biofilms and the establishment of infections.
  • Fimbriae bind to specific receptors on host cells, allowing bacteria to colonize tissues.

Fimbriae

Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins. They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella.

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer.

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility.

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae.

 

Incorrect Options:

Cytoplasmic membrane (Option A): The cytoplasmic membrane is involved in processes like energy generation, transport, and signal transduction, but it does not directly aid in bacterial adhesion.

Mesosomes (Option B): Mesosomes are invaginations of the cytoplasmic membrane and not directly involved in bacterial adhesion.

Lipopolysaccharides (Option D): Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are components of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria and play a role in the immune response (e.g., endotoxin activity), but they do not directly mediate bacterial adhesion.

questions.text: Please determine the sleep stage based on the red-highlighted EEG findings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage 4

Explanation: The red-highlighted EEG findings show slow wave sleep (SWS), which typically corresponds to the dominance of delta waves, which is characteristic of Stage 4 sleep, indicating the deepest level of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep.

Stage

EEG

Awake (Stage W)

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) with eyes closed

N1 Stage (Light Sleep)

(Option A ruled out)

Loss of alpha waves, theta waves (4-7 Hz)

N2 Stage (Moderate Sleep)

(Option B ruled out)

Sleep spindles (12-14 Hz), K complexes (sharp negative followed by positive waves)

N3 Stage (Deep Sleep)

(Option C ruled out)

Delta waves (slow, high amplitude)

N4 Stage

It largely overlaps with Stage 3 in terms of characteristics. Predominantly delta waves (low-frequency, high-amplitude brain waves) indicate very deep sleep.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female from a tribal area presents with fever for the last 3 days. A peripheral smear confirms the diagnosis of malaria. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

  • Plasmodium falciparum is the most common cause of malaria in tribal and endemic areas of India, particularly in regions with high transmission rates.
  • It causes severe malaria with complications such as cerebral malaria, renal failure, and severe anemia.
  • It is responsible for most fatal cases of malaria worldwide.
 

Vivax

(Option A ruled out)

Falciparum

(Option A)

Malariae

(Option B ruled out)

Ovale

(Option C ruled out)

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm)

Fills the RBC

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.text: What antenatal complication can be anticipated in the mother of the first baby, considering the second baby is a healthy newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational diabetes

Explanation:

As the second baby given in the image is a healthy newborn the condition described in the image is fetal macrosomia

The exact molecular mechanisms behind fetal macrosomia are not fully understood, but fetal hyperinsulinemia is a known contributing factor.

Insulin-like growth factors, leptin, and other adipokines play crucial roles in regulating placental development and function.

Maternal obesity is a significant factor in the development of fetal macrosomia. Additionally, some theories propose that maternal obesity may influence the growth of fetal cardiomyocytes, potentially leading to fetal cardiomyopathy or even congenital heart disease.

Option A) Intake of Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic medication. While the use of certain antiepileptic drugs during pregnancy may pose risks to the developing fetus, such as congenital malformations, this option does not specifically indicate any complications for the mother.

Option C) Intake of ACE inhibitors : ACE inhibitors are a type of medication used to treat conditions like high blood pressure. However, ACE inhibitors are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to their potential to harm the developing fetus. This option does not mention any complications for the mother specifically.

Option D) Intake of sodium valproate : Sodium valproate is another antiepileptic medication. Like with other antiepileptic drugs, there are concerns about the potential adverse effects on the developing fetus. However, this option does not indicate any specific complications for the mother.

questions.text: What is the association of Project MONICA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cardiovascular diseases:

  • Project MONICA (Multinational Monitoring of trends and determinants in Cardiovascular disease) is an international collaborative study that aimed to monitor trends and investigate determinants of cardiovascular diseases.
  • It involved multiple countries and regions and collected data on various aspects related to cardiovascular health, such as incidence, mortality, risk factors, and preventive measures.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fluent

Explanation: Lesion of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus indicates Wernicke's aphasia. This condition is characterized by fluent speech.

 

Feature

Wernicke's Aphasia

Broca's Aphasia (Option B)

Global Aphasia

Conduction Aphasia (Option D)

Speech Output

Fluent, but paraphasic and circumlocutious, jargon speech

Nonfluent, labored, dysarthric, telegraphic

Nonfluent, severely impaired

Fluent, but many phonemic paraphasias

Comprehension

Impaired for spoken and written words

Intact, except for syntactically complex sentences

Severely impaired

Intact for spoken language, impaired for reading aloud

Repetition

Impaired

Impaired

Severely impaired

Severely impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Naming

Impaired, leading to neologisms

Impaired

Severely impaired

Impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Writing

Impaired

Impaired

Severely impaired

Impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Motor Output (Facial and Limb)

Often unremarkable (rare mild facial flattening)

Right facial weakness, hemiparesis, buccofacial apraxia

Right hemiplegia, hemisensory loss

Varies depending on lesion site

Cause (Common Lesions)

Posterior part of superior temporal gyrus, inferior MCA branches

Inferior frontal gyrus, superior MCA branches

Involves entire MCA distribution

Arcuate fasciculus, MCA branches

Associated Features

Severe agitation, paranoia, possible right hemianopia

Right facial weakness, hemiparesis, emotional distress

Right hemiplegia, hemisensory loss, homonymous hemianopia

No significant associated features

Anomic (Option C) aphasia is associated with lesions in areas such as the left temporal/ occipital lesions (area 37) and left thalamus, which disrupt the brain's ability to access words, especially nouns and verbs. This results in difficulty finding words, although comprehension and fluency are generally preserved.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an emergency contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Danazol

Explanation:

Emergency contraception, also known as post-coital contraception or the "morning-after pill," is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure.

Danazol is not used for emergency contraception. It is a medication primarily indicated for the treatment of endometriosis and certain hormone-related conditions. It does not prevent pregnancy.

CuT200 (Option B) refers to a copper intrauterine device (IUD) that can be used as emergency contraception. When inserted within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse, the copper IUD can prevent pregnancy. It is an effective and long-acting form of emergency contraception.

RU486 (Option C), also known as mifepristone or the "abortion pill," is not a method used for post-coital contraception. It is a medication used for medical abortion or termination of an established pregnancy. It works by blocking the action of progesterone, which is necessary to maintain pregnancy.

Combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills (Option D) have been used as emergency contraception in the past but are no longer recommended due to their potential side effects. They are less effective and have more significant adverse effects compared to other available emergency contraception options, such as dedicated emergency contraceptive pills or the copper IUD.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is responsible for the production of superantigens?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pyogenes

Explanation:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes produces Streptococcal Pyrogenic Exotoxins (SPEs), which act as superantigens.
    • Responsible for Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome (STSS) and scarlet fever.
  • Superantigens are toxins that cause excessive T-cell activation by directly binding to MHC class II molecules and T-cell receptors (TCRs) without requiring antigen processing.
  • This results in massive cytokine release (cytokine storm), leading to severe inflammatory responses like toxic shock syndrome (TSS).

Streptococcus pyogenes and virulence factors

Virulence Factor

Description

Mechanism of Action

Associated Diseases

M Protein

Surface protein

Resists phagocytosis by inhibiting opsonization, interacts with host cell receptors
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Rheumatic fever

Streptolysin O and S

Hemolysins

Lyse red and white blood cells, and platelets; cause tissue damage
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Skin infections

Streptococcal Pyrogenic Exotoxins (SPEs)

Exotoxins

Act as superantigens, causing a massive immune response; associated with scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome
  • Scarlet fever,
  • Toxic shock-like syndrome (TSLS)

Hyaluronidase

Enzyme

Degrades hyaluronic acid in the host's connective tissue, facilitating bacterial spread
  • Cellulitis,
  • Necrotizing fasciitis

Streptokinase

Enzyme

Converts plasminogen to plasmin, dissolving blood clots and facilitating spread
  • Deep tissue infections,
  • Pharyngitis

DNases (A, B, C, D)

Enzymes

Depolymerize free DNA in pus, reducing viscosity and aiding the spread
  • Abscess formation,
  • Skin infections

C5a Peptidase

Enzyme

Degrades the C5a component of the complement system, inhibiting chemotaxis of phagocytes
  • Immune evasion,
  • Systemic infections

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule

Composed of hyaluronic acid; inhibits phagocytosis
  • Severe invasive diseases,
  • Immune evasion

Incorrect Options:

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option A): Primarily a skin commensal and causes biofilm-associated infections (e.g., catheter-related infections). Does not produce superantigens.

Clostridium perfringens (Option C): Produces α-toxin (lecithinase), which causes gas gangrene, but not superantigens.

Vibrio cholerae (Option D): Produces cholera toxin, which activates adenylate cyclase, leading to severe watery diarrhea. Not a superantigen.

questions.text: Which influenza virus caused the pandemic that took place in 2009?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - H1N1

The pandemic that occurred in 2009 was due to H1N1 influenza virus.

  • The pandemic, commonly known as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by a novel strain of the influenza A virus subtype H1N1.
  • It was first identified in Mexico in April 2009 and quickly spread worldwide, leading to a declaration of a global pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) in June 2009.
  • The H1N1 virus strain was a combination of swine, avian, and human influenza viruses, and it caused significant illness and mortality globally during that time.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below.

choices.text: For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) For tubal ligation

Explanation:

The Falope ring involves using a specialized applicator to place a Silastic ring around the midisthmic portion of the tube, leading to ischemic necrosis over time. Care must be taken to avoid laceration of the tube during application. The Hulka and Filshie clips are applied across the mid-isthmus of the tube. Proper placement of the clips is crucial to ensure complete occlusion of the tube.

The falope ring applicator is not used for ligation of the uterine artery during hysterectomy (Option B). Hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus and may or may not involve ligation of the uterine arteries, but the falope ring applicator is not used for this purpose.

An ovarian cystectomy (Option C) is a surgical procedure to remove ovarian cysts while preserving healthy ovarian tissue. The falope ring applicator is not used for ovarian cystectomy, as it is unrelated to this procedure.

An ectopic pregnancy (Option D) occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, usually in the fallopian tube. The treatment for ectopic pregnancy typically involves surgical intervention, but the falope ring applicator is not used for this purpose.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, bone pain and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

Explanation: The clinical scenario of fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, abdominal distension, iron deficiency anemia, and osteoporosis strongly indicates celiac disease. The single best test for its evaluation is the IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody.

Celiac Disease:

  • Also called celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy.
  • Associated with HLA-DQ2 and DQ8.
  • Small intestinal enteropathy caused by immune response to gluten.
  • Characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase.
  • Gluten is found in wheat, rye, barley, and some oats.
  • Pathogenesis: Tissue transglutaminase deamidates glutamine residues of gluten-derived peptides, facilitating immune response.
  • Affects the proximal small intestine.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diarrhea, weight loss, growth failure (children).
    • Bloating, irregular bowel habits, migraines, ataxia.
    • May present with osteoporosis, iron-deficiency anemia, or abnormal liver enzymes.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum antibodies: Tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies.
    • Measure serum IgA levels to detect IgA deficiency.
  • Confirmatory testing:
    • Endoscopy with small-intestinal biopsy.
    • Biopsy findings: Villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.
    • Marsh classification used for severity grading.
  • Management: Lifelong strict gluten-free diet.

 

TSH levels (Option A): Thyroid dysfunction can cause fatigue and weight loss, but it does not explain chronic diarrhea, iron deficiency anemia, or osteoporosis. These symptoms point toward malabsorption rather than thyroid disease, making TSH an inappropriate choice in this context.

C-peptide levels (Option B): C-peptide is useful in evaluating insulin secretion and distinguishing between type 1 and type 2 diabetes. However, diabetes does not typically present with chronic diarrhea, iron deficiency anemia, or osteoporosis, making it irrelevant here.

Urine sugar and ketones (Option C): While this test helps identify diabetes and diabetic ketoacidosis, the patient's symptoms, such as malabsorption and nutrient deficiencies, do not suggest these conditions. Chronic diarrhea and weight loss are not hallmark features of diabetes.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgA

Explanation:

The image shows dimeric IgA, which is characterized by:

  • Two IgA monomers linked by a J chain
  • Secretory component that protects it from enzymatic degradation in mucosal surfaces

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

IgG (Option B): The most abundant antibody in circulation

  • Monomeric in structure (no J chain or secretory component).
  • Involved in long-term immunity, opsonization, and complement activation.

IgM (Option C): Exists as a pentamer in serum with a J chain and is efficient in complement activation and agglutination.

IgE (Option D):

  • Heat-labile (sensitive to heat)
  • It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism)
