  • Mediates Prausnitz-Küstner Reaction
  • Distribution: Primarily found in extravascular spaces
  • Elevated Levels: In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections
  • Function: Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators

IgD:

  • IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes
  • Function:
    • Acts as recognition receptors for antigens
    • It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

The given image is a hysterosalpingogram in which B/L fallopian tubes are blocked.

Bilateral hydrosalpinx refers to the presence of fluid-filled dilatation or blockage of both fallopian tubes. This finding is characterized by the contrast agent filling the fallopian tubes and appearing as fluid-filled sacs on the HSG images. Bilateral hydrosalpinx can be a result of various conditions, such as infection, scarring, or previous pelvic surgery.

Bilateral hydrosalpinx:

  • Fallopian tube neoplasms are uncommon, with most fallopian tube masses being related to ectopic pregnancy or the aftermath of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). One of these conditions, hydrosalpinx, is a chronic cystic enlargement of the fallopian tube that results from distal tubal obstruction.
  • On sonographic examination, hydrosalpinx appears as a thin-walled, cystic, fusiform structure with incomplete septa and anechoic content. In certain cases, multiple small hyperechoic nodules (2 to 3 mm) may form around the inner circumference of the tube, creating a "beads on a string" appearance. These nodules represent fibrotic endosalpingial folds. Hysterosalpingography, often performed for fertility evaluation, reveals ballooned, clubbed fallopian tubes filled with contrast.
  • Management of hydrosalpinx depends on the certainty of the diagnosis, the woman's desire for future fertility, and the severity of symptoms. For asymptomatic women who have completed childbearing and whose sonographic findings support hydrosalpinx, expectant management is typically recommended. However, if pelvic pain or infertility is present, or if the diagnosis is uncertain, diagnostic laparoscopy is often performed.

Extravasation into the venous system (Option B) would indicate that the contrast agent has leaked into the veins rather than following the normal flow through the fallopian tubes. This is an abnormal finding and typically not observed during a normal HSG.

 

Normal HSG (Option C) refers to a hysterosalpingogram with no abnormal findings. In a normal HSG, the contrast agent should flow freely through the uterus and fallopian tubes without any blockages or abnormalities. This choice is incorrect because the question describes a specific finding seen in the HSG.

Bilateral cornual block (Option D) refers to the obstruction or blockage of both cornua, which are the narrowest portions of the fallopian tubes where they connect to the uterus. This blockage prevents the contrast agent from flowing into the tubes and can be identified on the HSG. However, the question specifically mentions bilateral hydrosalpinx, not cornual block, as the finding observed.

questions.text: Which of the following methods relies on the principles of behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Management by objective

Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences.

  • Qualitative type of health management is based on behavioral sciences. It includes
    • Personal management
    • Organizational design
    • Communication
    • Information system
    • Management by objective

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C are incorrect.

  • Decision making, network analysis, and system analysis is Quantitative which is not based on behavioral sciences.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aedes aegypti

Explanation:

  • Zika virus is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes, especially Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.
  • These mosquitoes are day-biters, with peak activity during early morning and late afternoon.

Zika virus:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) is an arbovirus from the Flaviviridae family, characterized by its single-stranded RNA.

Transmission:

  • ZIKV is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.
  • Other transmission modes include mother-to-child (especially in the first trimester), and rarely through sexual contact, blood transfusion, and organ transplantation.

The life cycle of Zika virus

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Incubation: A few days to 1 week; >80% of infections are asymptomatic.
  • Zika Fever: Symptoms include mild fever, rash, and conjunctivitis.
  • Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS): Characterized by microcephaly and neurological issues.
  • Neurological Complications: Rarely includes Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT): RT-PCR is the preferred method, detecting ZIKV RNA in blood and urine up to 7 days after symptom onset.
  • IgM Antibody Detection: Appears after 1 week of symptoms and can remain positive for several months; may cross-react with dengue antibodies.
  • Enzyme Immunoassays (EIAs) and Immunofluorescence Assays (IFA): Used if symptoms last ≥ 7 days, utilizing viral lysate or recombinant proteins.

Phlebotomus (Option D): Transmits Leishmania spp. (causing leishmaniasis), not Zika virus. These are sandflies, different from mosquitoes.

questions.text: What is the function of proteasomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein degradation

Explanation:

Proteasomes are large protein complexes that degrade damaged, misfolded, or unneeded proteins tagged with ubiquitin, maintaining cellular protein quality and regulating various biological processes.

  • Proteasomes are large protein complexes found in cells that are responsible for protein degradation.
  • They play a vital role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by selectively breaking down proteins that are damaged, misfolded, or no longer needed.
  • Proteasomes consist of multiple subunits that work together to recognize and degrade target proteins.
  • The main function of proteasomes is to break down proteins into smaller peptide fragments, which can then be further processed and recycled by the cell.
  • The degradation of proteins by proteasomes is essential for various cellular processes, including the regulation of cell cycle progression, removal of misfolded or damaged proteins, antigen presentation in the immune system and control of protein levels and turnover.

questions.text: In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to_____ (per 1 lakh live births)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - <70

  • In Sustainable Development Goal 3, target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to < 70 (per 1 lakh live births)
  • "Transforming our world: the 2030 agenda for sustainable development" was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 25th September 2015.
  • It has 17 goals and 169 targets, including a specific goal 3 for health with 13 targets.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following contains the maximum amount of vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Animal products

Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal products such as meat, fish, eggs, and dairy.
  • Plant-based sources like green leafy vegetables, roots, tubers, and vegetarian diets generally lack significant amounts of vitamin B12 unless fortified or supplemented.
  • So Vit B12 deficiency is significantly seen among plant sources.

Symptoms:

  • Hematologic: Macrocytic anemia, fatigue, pallor.
  • Neurological: Paresthesias, ataxia, memory loss, peripheral neuropathy.
  • Psychiatric: Depression, irritability, cognitive decline.
  • Glossitis: Sore, red, swollen tongue.

Diagnosis:

  • Low serum vitamin B12 levels.
  • Elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) and homocysteine levels.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Macrocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: If the percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. What is the % of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 22%

Explanation:

Chargaff's rule, which states that in DNA, the amount of adenine (A) is equal to the amount of thymine (T), and the amount of guanine (G) is equal to the amount of cytosine (C).

  • DNA consists of four deoxyribonucleotides: deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).
  • The two strands of DNA are complementary, meaning adenine pairs with thymine, and guanine pairs with cytosine.
  • Since the total percentage of nucleotides should add up to 100%, and 28% + 28% is already accounted for by thymine and adenine, the remaining percentage for guanine and cytosine is 44%.
  • Since guanine and cytosine are present in equal amounts, the percentage of cytosine would be half of the remaining percentage, which is 22%.

questions.text: What is the probable reason for the worsening of neurologic symptoms in a patient who initially showed improvement in blood picture after receiving a dose of 5mg folate for peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia?

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores.

Explanation:

  • These are classic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency, which leads to impaired DNA synthesis (macrocytic anemia) and demyelination (peripheral neuropathy).

Folate supplementation in isolation:

  • Folate can improve the hematologic symptoms (macrocytic anemia) by bypassing the impaired DNA synthesis caused by B12 deficiency.
  • However, folate does not address the neurologic symptoms caused by the lack of B12, which are due to accumulation of methylmalonic acid and demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

Mechanism of worsening symptoms:

  • When folate is supplemented without correcting B12 deficiency, it increases the demand for B12 in the methylation cycle (conversion of homocysteine to methionine).
  • This depletes the already low B12 stores, worsening the neurologic symptoms, despite initial improvement in anemia.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is the financial advantage quantified?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cost-benefit Analysis

  • Cost-benefit analysis: Cost-benefit analysis measures the outcome of a program in monetary terms. It compares the economic benefits and cost of the program.

Incorrect Options:

Cost-effective analysis (Option A): Cost-effective analysis measures outcome of a program in nonmonetary terms .

Network analysis (Option C): A graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Input-output analysis (Option D): It is an economic technique. Monetary benefits are not measured in this technique.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Homogentisate oxidase

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of black urine on standing along with abdominal pain points to alkaptonuria, a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase.

  • Homogentisate oxidase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of the amino acids tyrosine and phenylalanine.
  • Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body.
  • Pathophysiology: Homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. Upon exposure to air (oxidation), it polymerizes, causing the urine to turn black on standing.

Clinical Features

  • Urine discoloration: The hallmark sign is black urine when exposed to air.
  • Abdominal pain: Likely due to deposition of homogentisic acid or associated complications like kidney stones.
  • Ochronosis: Long-term deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to bluish-black discoloration (typically seen in adulthood).
  • Arthropathy: Degenerative joint disease due to ochronotic deposits in cartilage.
  • Diagnosis: Urine analysis: Elevated levels of homogentisic acid. Genetic testing: Mutations in the HGD gene (homogentisate oxidase gene).
  • Management: Limit intake of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Vitamin C may slow ochronosis progression.
  • Nitisinone: A newer drug that inhibits the production of homogentisic acid by blocking the enzyme upstream in the metabolic pathway.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350mg/dl, pH-7.2, HCO3-10, pCO2-30. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation: The patient has primary metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation.

 

Stepwise Acid-Base Diagnosis:

Step 1: The patient's pH is 7.2 (normal: 7.35-7.45), indicating acidosis.

Step 2: The bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) level is 10 mmol/L, lower than the normal range (22-30 mmol/L), suggesting metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Use Winter's formula to calculate the expected pCO₂ compensation for metabolic acidosis:
Expected pCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2
For HCO₃⁻ = 10,
Expected pCO₂ = (1.5 × 10) + 8 ± 2 = 21-25 mmHg.

Step 5: The patient’s actual pCO₂ is 30 mmHg. This is higher than the expected range (21-25 mmHg), indicating partially respiratory compensation.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of a water bath for a patient with frostbite is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 37 degree C

Explanation: The recommended temperature of a water bath for a patient with frostbite is 37 degree C.

 

Frostbite:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Tissue freezes below 0°C (32°F), leading to the ice-crystal formation that destroys the cellular structure.
    • Vascular endothelial damage causes stasis, microvascular thrombosis, and progressive dermal ischemia.
    • Thrombosis, ischemia, and necrosis lead to mummification and demarcation over weeks to months.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Sensory deficits (light touch, pain, or temperature perception); "chunk of wood" sensation in extremities.
    • Signs:
      • Superficial frostbite: Anesthesia, erythema, pliable subcutaneous tissue, and no tissue loss.
      • Deep frostbite: Waxy, mottled, violaceous-white tissue; hemorrhagic vesicles indicate severe injury.
  • Treatment:
    • Rewarming:
      • Immerse frozen tissue in circulating water at 37°- 40°C (99°-104°F) for 30-60 minutes.
      • Avoid premature termination of thawing despite the pain.
    • Medical Management:
      • Prostacyclin analogs (e.g., iloprost) within 48 hours.
      • Thrombolysis (rt-PA) and heparin for deep frostbite within 24 hours to reduce amputation risk.
    • Surgical Considerations: Delay debridement or amputation until demarcation.

questions.text: Which demographic is most likely to present with warty lesions on the vulva, along with multiple warty growths around the anal canal, as observed during examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Condyloma accuminata

Explanation:

Condyloma acuminata, also known as anogenital warts, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV).

  • It commonly presents as multiple warty growths on the vulva, perianal region, and other areas of the anogenital area.
  • The warts may have a cauliflower-like appearance and can vary in size and number.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option B) is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). It typically presents as small, flesh-colored, dome-shaped bumps on the skin. While it can occur in the anogenital area, it is less commonly associated with warty lesions compared to condyloma acuminata.

Chancroid (Option C) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers or sores, rather than warty growths.

Herpes (Option D) is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It can manifest as genital ulcers or blisters, often accompanied by pain and itching. While herpes can cause vesicular or ulcerative lesions, it is not typically associated with warty growths like condyloma acuminata.

questions.text: All of the following is used in the management of breathless patients at a high altitude of 3000 mts except.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intravenous digoxin

Explanation: A breathless patient at a high altitude of 3000 meters suggests High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), and intravenous digoxin is not used in its management.

 

High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE):

  • Risk Factors:
    • Rapid ascent, history of HAPE, respiratory infections, cold temperatures.
    • Cardiopulmonary abnormalities (e.g., mitral stenosis, primary pulmonary hypertension) increase risk, even at moderate altitudes.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Reduced exercise tolerance greater than expected at altitude.
    • Dry cough may precede, followed by blood-tinged sputum.
    • Tachypnea, tachycardia, crackles on auscultation.
    • Hypoxemia and respiratory alkalosis are present unless on acetazolamide (which may cause metabolic acidosis).
  • Investigation:
    • Chest X-ray: Patchy or streaky interstitial edema.
    • Electrocardiograms: Right ventricular strain or hypertrophy.
  • Prevention:
    • Gradual ascent is key to acclimatization.
    • Sustained-release nifedipine (30 mg twice daily) prevents HAPE in those ascending rapidly or with a history of HAPE.
    • Acetazolamide (Option D) and dexamethasone are potential options, though their roles require careful monitoring.
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate descent (Option C) and supplemental oxygen (Option B) (targeting >90% saturation) are the most effective treatments.
    • Maintain rest, warmth, and limit exertion.
    • Hyperbaric therapy (portable altitude chamber) may be lifesaving if descent is not possible.
    • Oral nifedipine as adjunctive therapy.

questions.text: What is the drug that commonly leads to physical dependence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Heroin

Explanation:

  • Heroin, also known as diamorphine, is an opioid drug that is derived from morphine. It is highly addictive and is known to cause physical dependence.
  • When individuals use heroin regularly, their body adapts to the presence of the drug, and they develop a tolerance to its effects. This means that over time, they require higher doses of heroin to achieve the desired effect.
  • If a person becomes physically dependent on heroin and abruptly stops using it or significantly reduces its dosage, they may experience withdrawal symptoms.
  • These symptoms can be severe and include cravings, restlessness, muscle and bone pain, insomnia, gastrointestinal distress, and flu-like symptoms.

Heroin:

Drug Class

Opioid (Narcotic)

Origin

Derived from morphine, which is extracted from the opium poppy plant.

Forms

Powder (white or brown), black tar (sticky resin)

Route of Administration

Injected, smoked, snorted, orally ingested

Effects
  • Euphoria
  • Pain relief
  • Relaxation
  • Drowsiness
  • Slowed breathing
  • Sedation

Symptoms
  • Drowsiness
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Slow or shallow breathing
  • Unconsciousness
  • Overdose
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness

Long-Term Risks
  • Addiction
  • Liver and kidney damage
  • Collapsed veins (if injected)
  • Lung complications
  • Brain damage
  • Overdose

Withdrawal Symptoms
  • Anxiety
  • Sweating
  • Muscle pain
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Insomnia
  • Cravings

Overdose Symptoms
  • Slow or difficult breathing
  • Blue lips or nails
  • Unconsciousness
  • Pinpoint pupils
  • Death

Treatment
  • Methadone or buprenorphine replacement therapy
  • Counseling and rehabilitation.

 

Ketamine (Option A) is a dissociative anesthetic that produces hallucinogenic effects. While it can lead to psychological dependence, it is not typically associated with significant physical dependence.

LSD (Option C) is a hallucinogenic drug that does not typically produce physical dependence. However, it can lead to psychological dependence or addiction in some individuals.

Phencyclidine (Option D) is a dissociative drug that can cause hallucinations, distorted perceptions, and other psychological effects. It is not commonly associated with physical dependence, but it can lead to psychological dependence in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent impacts of puberty are not influenced by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hair growth

Explanation:

  • Hair growth during puberty is mainly influenced by androgens, not estrogen.
  • Androgens, such as testosterone, play a significant role in the development of secondary sexual characteristics, including pubic hair growth in both males and females.

Cervical mucus secretion (Option B) is influenced by estrogen. During puberty, the increasing levels of estrogen stimulate the cervical glands to produce and secrete mucus, which helps facilitate sperm transport and fertility.

Vaginal cornification (Option C) is a process in which the cells lining the vaginal epithelium undergo changes, becoming thicker and more keratinized. Estrogen plays a vital role in promoting vaginal cornification during puberty. It helps transform the vaginal epithelium from a thin, delicate state to a thicker, more resistant state.

Menstruation (Option D) is a complex process that involves hormonal changes, particularly the interaction of estrogen and progesterone. Estrogen stimulates the growth and development of the endometrium (lining of the uterus) during the menstrual cycle. However, progesterone, along with estrogen, is primarily responsible for initiating and regulating menstruation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: The secondary structure is stabilized by disulfide bonds.
Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation.
The secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tertiary structure is three-dimensional

Explanation:

The tertiary structure represents the overall three-dimensional folding of a single polypeptide chain.

  • It is stabilized by interactions like hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, hydrophobic interactions, and disulfide bridges.
  • Functionality: The tertiary structure is crucial for the biological activity of the protein, as it determines the placement of active sites, binding sites, and interaction regions.
  • This makes the three-dimensional nature of tertiary structure a key feature in protein organization.

Incorrect Options:

Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation (Option B): Denaturation affects only the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures, leaving the primary structure (amino acid sequence) intact.

The secondary structure is stabilized by disulfide bonds (Option C): The secondary structure (e.g., α-helices and β-sheets) is primarily stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen and amide hydrogen of the polypeptide backbone.

The secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence (Option D): The amino acid sequence (primary structure) dictates how the protein folds into its secondary and tertiary structures, but this does not directly address the structural organization.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of severe menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hormonal therapy

Explanation:

  • Hormonal therapy, such as oral contraceptive pills or progestin-only therapy, is often considered the initial treatment for menorrhagia.
  • These hormonal treatments can help regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce excessive menstrual bleeding. They work by stabilizing the endometrium (inner lining of the uterus) and decreasing its thickness, thereby reducing the amount of menstrual bleeding.
  • Hormonal therapy is effective for many women with menorrhagia and is considered a conservative approach before considering more invasive interventions.

Uterine artery embolization (Option A) is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat conditions such as uterine fibroids. It involves blocking the blood supply to the uterus to shrink the fibroids and reduce symptoms. While it can be an effective treatment for certain cases of menorrhagia, it is usually considered when other conservative treatment options have failed or are not suitable.

Endometrial ablation (Option B) is a procedure that destroys the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) to reduce or stop menstrual bleeding. It is typically considered for women who have completed childbearing and have persistent or recurrent menorrhagia that has not responded to other treatments. It is a more invasive option compared to hormonal therapy and may not be the first-line choice in this scenario.

Hysterectomy (Option D) involves surgical removal of the uterus and is a definitive treatment for menorrhagia. It is typically reserved for cases where conservative management options have failed or are not appropriate. Hysterectomy is a major surgical procedure and is usually considered when other treatments have not been successful or when there are other underlying conditions necessitating removal of the uterus.

questions.text: Which among the following absorbs the least water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cellulose

Explanation:

Cellulose absorbs the least water because it is a highly crystalline and rigid polysaccharide.

  • It is composed of long chains of β-glucose units connected by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds, forming strong hydrogen bonds within and between the chains.
  • These extensive hydrogen bonds create a stable, insoluble structure that resists water absorption.

 

Incorrect Options:

Mucilage (Option A): Highly hydrophilic and absorbs large amounts of water. Common in plants for water storage and seed germination.

Gums (Option C): Hydrophilic polysaccharides that swell and absorb water to form gels.Found in plant exudates.

Pectin (Option D): Highly hydrophilic and forms gels by trapping water molecules. Used in food products like jams and jellies for its water-absorbing properties.

questions.text: In a civil negligence case against a doctor, who is responsible for providing evidence?

choices.text: Police not under the rank of sub-inspector

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Patient

Explanation:

  • In a civil negligence case against a doctor, the burden of proof lies with the patient. The patient is the one making the claim against the doctor and alleging negligence. Therefore, it is the patient's responsibility to provide evidence and prove that the doctor's actions or omissions fell below the standard of care expected, resulting in harm or injury.

·

Feature

Civil Negligence

Criminal Negligence

Offense

No specific and clear violation of law

Must have specifically violated a particular criminal law

Negligence

Simple absence of care and skill

Gross negligence, inattention, or lack of competence

Conduct of physician

Compared to a generally accepted simple standard of conduct

Not compared to a single test

Consent for act

Good defense, cannot recover damages

Not a defense, can be prosecuted

Trial by

Civil court

Criminal court

Evidence

Strong evidence is sufficient

Guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt

Punishment

Liable to pay damages

Imprisonment, fine, or both

Contributory negligence

Defense for doctor

Not a defense

Double jeopardy

Cannot be tried twice for the same offense

Can be tried twice for the same crime

Damage

Repairable damage or harm to patient

Irreparable damage to the patient

Dispute

Between two parties in their individual capacities

Between the State and the offending doctor

Complainant

Sufferer party is the complainant

Public prosecutor on behalf of the State is the complainant

 

Police not under the rank of sub-inspector (Option B) The police are not directly involved in civil negligence cases against doctors.

Magistrate (Option C) In civil negligence cases against doctors, the burden of proof does not lie with the magistrate. Their role is to oversee the proceedings and apply the relevant laws.

Doctor (Option D) is the defendant in a civil negligence case, meaning they are the party being accused of negligence. It is not the doctor's burden to prove their innocence

questions.text: During a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation, a pregnant woman's abdominal examination showed that the size of her uterus was equivalent to that of a 16-week gestation. Additionally, an ultrasound detected the presence of oligohydramnios. What is the probable cause for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

  • Renal agenesis refers to the absence or underdevelopment of one or both kidneys. It can result in reduced or absent urine production, leading to oligohydramnios.
  • Oligohydramnios is characterized by a decreased amniotic fluid volume, which is assessed through ultrasound examination. The decreased amniotic fluid can be observed as a small gestational sac size or less fluid visible around the fetus.

Fetal anemia (Option B) is not a likely cause of oligohydramnios. Fetal anemia can lead to hydrops fetalis, which is characterized by excessive accumulation of fluid in the fetus and may result in polyhydramnios (increased amniotic fluid).

Barter syndrome (Option C) is a rare genetic disorder affecting renal tubular function. It is characterized by abnormal salt and water reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to electrolyte imbalances. While it can cause renal abnormalities, oligohydramnios is not typically associated with Barter syndrome.

Anencephaly (Option D) is a severe congenital malformation where the neural tube fails to close during early development, resulting in the absence of major portions of the brain and skull. Anencephaly is not directly related to oligohydramnios, although it can be associated with other anomalies that may affect amniotic fluid levels.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Arsenic·

Explanation:

  • Arsenic is a poison that can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. It has the ability to accumulate in bones over time, making it detectable even after the decomposition of soft tissues. Arsenic is a heavy metal, it replaces phosphorus and gets absorbed into the bones, where it may remain for years.

 

Postmortem findings of Arsenic Poisoning

External findings

Internal findings

  • Emaciation
  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Keratosis
  • Alopecia
  • White streaks on nails (Aldrich Mees’ lines)
  • Jaundice and muscle wasting,
  • Nasal septum ulceration.
  • Sunken eyeballs
  • Cyanosed and shrunken body.
  • Rigor mortis (sets in late and persists for a prolonged duration)
  • Reddening of stomach mucosa (red velvet or strawberry) due to gastrointestinal congestion.

  • Flea-bitten appearance of the stomach (due to focal haemorrhages).
  • The inflammation and presence of “rice water” contents in the intestines.
  • Subendocardial haemorrhages in the heart.
  • Fatty degeneration of the heart, liver, and kidneys.
  • Along with routine viscera and body fluids, the items preserved for chemical analysis are:
      • A piece of long bone (preferably femur)
      • A bunch of pulled scalp hair
      • A wedge of muscle
      • A small portion of skin (from the back of the trunk)

 

Carbon monoxide (Option B) is a gas that is produced during the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials. It is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains since it is a volatile gas that dissipates quickly and does not accumulate in the body or bones.

Hydrogen sulphide (Option C) is a toxic gas that has a strong odor of rotten eggs. Similar to carbon monoxide, it is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains as it is a volatile gas that dissipates rapidly and does not accumulate in the body or bones.

Phosphorus (Option D) is a chemical element that can be toxic in certain forms, such as white phosphorus. However, it is not typically found in skeletonized remains as it is highly reactive and tends to undergo chemical reactions or degradation over time.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Elastic cartilage

Explanation:

  • The histological image shows numerous branching elastic fibers, which are characteristic of elastic cartilage.
  • Elastic cartilage contains elastic fibers in the extracellular matrix, providing flexibility and resilience.
  • It is found in structures requiring both strength and elasticity, such as:
    • Auricle of the ear
    • Epiglottis
    • Eustachian tube

Types of Cartilage

Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage

Fibrocartilage

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

 

Incorrect Options:

Hyaline cartilage (option A): Lacks elastic fibers and appears as a glassy, homogenous matrix. Found in articular surfaces, costal cartilages, trachea, and nasal septum.

Articular cartilage (option C): A specialized type of hyaline cartilage covering joint surfaces. It lacks elastic fibers and has a smooth, glassy appearance.

Fibrocartilage (option D): Contains dense collagen fibers but lacks elastic fibers. Found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and menisci.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged when the obstetrician observes that the episiotomy performed during a successful delivery has extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) External anal sphincter

Explanation:

The external anal sphincter is a muscular structure that surrounds the anal canal and is responsible for voluntary control of bowel movements. When an episiotomy extends beyond the perineal body, it can result in injury to the external anal sphincter, potentially leading to complications such as fecal incontinence.
The ischiocavernosus muscle (Option B) is located in the perineal region and is involved in the erectile mechanism in males.

The bulbospongiosus muscle (Option C) is also located in the perineal region and plays a role in the erectile mechanism as well as in the expulsion of urine and semen. While it may be involved in the episiotomy, it is less likely to be injured compared to the external anal sphincter.

The urethral sphincter (Option D) is responsible for maintaining urinary continence and is located in close proximity to the vaginal area. While it can be affected during childbirth, an episiotomy extending beyond the perineal body is less likely to directly injure the urethral sphincter.

questions.text: In a dead body, bloating of face, tongue protrusions were noted along with the findings in the image. Identify the phenomenon:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Putrefaction

  • Various signs and changes are observed during putrefaction, including bloating of the face and other body parts, as well as tongue protrusion.

 

Putrefaction

  • Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

 

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

 

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.

 

Timing of Discoloration:

  • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

 

Electrocution & Crocodile burns (Option A & B) refers to the injury or death caused by an electric shock. It does not specifically result in bloating of the face, tongue protrusion, or putrefaction. Electrocution-related findings would typically involve specific burn patterns or injury marks associated with the electrical source. Crocodile burns are seen in high voltage electric burns.

Scalds (Option C) are burns caused by contact with hot liquids or steam. Changes, such as blisters and skin peeling are seen. Scalds are acute injuries and do not involve postmortem processes

questions.text: In which of the following situations is the equation V/Q = infinity accurate?

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option B - Equal to dead space

Explanation:

  • V/Q Ratio: Infinite (Option B)

  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive ventilation, but no perfusion. The partial pressures of gases in the alveoli match those of the inspired air, resulting in PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mmHg.

  • It occurs in conditions like embolism.

Option (A) : foreign body Obstruction in the bronchus

  • V/Q Ratio: Zero (Option A ruled out)

  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive no ventilation, but perfusion continues. Consequently, the partial pressures of gases in the alveoli equilibrate with the venous blood, resulting in PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mmHg.

Option (C) : During V/Q = infinity , PO2 = 149 mmHg and PCO2 = 0 mmHg ( not equal)

Option (D) : during V/Q = infinity , PO2 = 149 mmHg (not 159mm Hg) and PCO2 = 0 mmHg (not 40mmHg )

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the image below is:
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Synovial

Explanation:

The costotransverse joint is a synovial joint that forms between:

  • The tubercle of the rib
  • The transverse process of the corresponding thoracic vertebra

It is a plane-type synovial joint, allowing slight gliding movements during respiration.

Type of joint

Examples

Hinge Joint

Elbow joint, Knee joint, Temporomandibular joint.

Pivot Joint

Superior radioulnar joint, C1 and C2 joint

Ball-and-Socket Joint

Shoulder (glenohumeral) joint, Hip joint

Saddle Joint

Sternoclavicular joint, Carpometacarpal joint of the thumb

Ellipsoid (Condyloid) Joint

Radiocarpal (wrist) joint, atlantooccipital joint, Metacarpophalangeal joints

 

Aspect

Hinge Joints (Bicondylar Joints)

Pivot Joints (Trochoid Joints)

Movement

Predominantly uniaxial with limited rotation around a second orthogonal axis.

Uniaxial rotation around an axis.

Structure

Formed by two convex condyles that articulate with concave or flat surfaces.

Involves an osseous pivot rotating within an osteoligamentous ring, or vice versa.

Examples
  • Knee Joint- Condyles may be within a single fibrous capsule.
  • Temporomandibular joint- In separate capsules that work together.]
  • Humeroulnar joint in the elbow.
  • Superior radioulnar joint- The head of the radius rotates within the annular ligament and ulnar radial notch.
  • Dens of the axis (C2 vertebra) project into altas.
  • C1 and C2 joint that allows the head to move back and forth.

Images

Incorrect Options:

Syndesmosis (option A): A fibrous joint with bones connected by ligaments or interosseous membranes (e.g., distal tibiofibular joint).

Synarthrosis (option B): A non-movable joint, typically seen in skull sutures. Costotransverse joints allow movement, making this option incorrect.

Synchondrosis (option C): A cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage (e.g., first costochondral joint). Costotransverse joints are not primarily cartilaginous.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Purkinje cells

Explanation:

  • Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the Purkinje layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have extensive dendritic trees that branch into the molecular layer and receive synaptic inputs from parallel fibers (granule cells).
  • These cells serve as the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex, sending inhibitory signals (GABAergic) to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The cerebellar cortex consists of the following three distinct layers:

Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

Purkinje cell layer

Granular layer

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.

Among the five types of intrinsic neurons (Basket cells, Stellate cells, Purkinje cells, Granule cells and Golgi cells)- All are inhibitory except granule cells.

 


Incorrect Options:

Basket cells (option B): Small inhibitory interneurons in the molecular layer of the cerebellum. Form synapses on the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, but are not flask-shaped.

Golgi cells (option C): Inhibitory interneurons found in the granule layer. Provide feedback inhibition to granule cells but do not have the distinctive flask shape of Purkinje cells.

Granule cells (option D): The smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum, found in the granule cell layer. They excite Purkinje cells via parallel fibers but are not flask-shaped.

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pharyngeal pouch

Explanation:

  • The given barium swallow film shows a characteristic radiological finding known as a Pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum.
  • It is an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa through a weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall (Killian's dehiscence).

Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis(Chronic bad breathe)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:

 
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

Aortic aneurysm (Option A) is a dilatation or bulge in the aorta, which is the main artery that carries blood from the heart. It is visualised via CT scan or angiography but not barium swallow.

Carotid body tumour (Option C) is a rare, slow-growing tumour that arises from the carotid body, which is located near the carotid bifurcation. They are better diagnosed using CT or MRI but not by using a barium swallow.

Esophageal carcinoma (Option D) presents with narrowing or strictures in the oesophagus due to tumour growth. Whereas a pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum) is a protrusion from the pharynx

questions.text: What could be the most likely reason for a patient presenting with chronic non-pitting edema in the lower extremities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lymphedema

Explanation:

  • Lymphedema refers to the accumulation of lymph fluid in the interstitial tissue, typically resulting in chronic non-pitting edema.
  • In this type of edema, when pressure is applied to the swollen area, the indentation doesn't remain.

Causes of Primary Lymphedema

Congenital Lymphedema

Lymphedema Praecox

Lymphedema Tarda

  • Age: Seen in < 1 year of age
  • Present at birth.
  • Lower limb, genitalia, and face are involved.
  • Usually, B/L and multiple limbs are involved.
  • Familial version of congenital lymphedema – known as Milroy’s disease.
  • M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases).
  • Age: 1 to 35 years.
  • M/C seen in females.
  • Usually U/L.
  • Involves calf and foot
  • Familial version of lymphedema praecox - known as Meig's disease.

 
  • Age: Usually seen in > 35 years age group
  • It is a rare disease.

 

Secondary Lymphedema

Filariasis
  • MC overall cause of lymphedema worldwide
  • MC secondary cause of lymphedema
  • Lymphoedema due to Lymphatic obstruction

Surgery
  • Axillary block dissection-
    • MC cause of secondary lymphedema in the USA
    • MC iatrogenic cause of secondary lymphedema
  • Inguinal block dissection
  • Lymphedema due to Lymphatic disruption

Infections
  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis
  • Fungal and Bacterial infections

Other causes:
  • Trauma
  • Malignancy
  • Radiotherapy

Arterial Disorders (Option B) like peripheral artery disease (PAD) generally present with claudication and other signs of ischemia, such as cold extremities, pale skin, and ulcers. Eedema is not a common finding here.

Venous Disorders (Option C) can cause oedema in the lower extremities. However, in venous disorders, the oedema is due to venous stasis, and it's generally pitting rather than non-pitting. Signs like varicose veins or venous ulcers are also present.

Coronary heart disease (Option D) mainly affects the coronary arteries and leads to symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and possibly heart attacks. While heart failure (due to CHD) can cause edema in the legs, which is usually pitting because it results from fluid retention and venous congestion due to impaired cardiac function.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in patients on warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A - Factor 2

Explanation:

Warfarin Mechanism of action:

  • The carboxylation process adds gamma carboxyglutamate residues to these factors, allowing them to bind calcium ions and participate in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pars inferior

Explanation:

  • Pars inferior: The saccule develops from the pars inferior of the otic vesicle. The pars inferior forms the saccule and the cochlea during the development of the inner ear.

 

Saculus anterior (Option A): is incorrect because the saccule does not develop from the anterior part of the otic vesicle; this part is more involved in forming the semicircular canals.

Saculus posterior (Option B): is incorrect because while the saccule is located in the posterior part of the ear, it actually develops from the pars inferior, not from the posterior segment.

Pars superior (Option C): is incorrect because the pars superior is primarily involved in the development of the semicircular canals and not the saccule.

questions.text: Identify the sign in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Popeye sign

Explanation:

  • Popeye sign refers to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle belly in the upper arm due to a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. The proximal portion of the tendon retracts, causing the muscle to bunch up in the mid-upper arm, resembling Popeye’s biceps from the cartoon character.
  • It is often seen in older adults, particularly in those with a history of repetitive overhead activity or degenerative tendon changes.

Patients typically present with:

  • Sudden pain in the shoulder
  • Audible "pop"
  • Bruising
  • Weakness in elbow flexion and supination

 

Incorrect Options:

Hill-Sachs sign (option B): A cortical depression (compression fracture) in the posterolateral humeral head, caused by anterior shoulder dislocation. Best seen on X-ray or MRI, not a visible sign like Popeye sign.

Griesinger sign (option C): Seen in lateral sinus thrombophlebitis (complication of otitis media or mastoiditis). Characterized by tenderness and swelling over the mastoid process due to venous congestion.

Rising sun sign (option D): Seen in orbital floor fractures, indicating prolapse of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus, resembling a "rising sun" on imaging.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after sustaining an RTA and injury to the lower chest. On presentation, the patient is stable, and vitals are normal. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) eFAST

Explanation:

  • eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is the next step in management for trauma patients to evaluate for free fluid (such as blood) in the abdomen or pericardium.
  • It is a rapidly available ultrasound examination done to find intraperitoneal fluid.
  • It can be used to assess the hepatorenal, splenorenal, and pelvis spaces for fluid that is considered to be blood in a trauma case.
  • If clear lung fields on the chest radiography rule out pneumothorax or hemothorax, eFAST can help detect other sources of bleeding, such as intraperitoneal haemorrhage, to guide further management.

Tube thoracostomy (Option B) is usually performed if there is evidence of a pneumothorax or hemothorax. Since the chest radiograph showed clear lung fields, there is no immediate indication for this intervention.

CECT chest & abdomen (Option C & D) is done later, not immediately, as in the primary assessment. Though this could be useful for detecting more subtle injuries, a clear chest X-ray makes this less urgent, and an eFAST is a quicker first step.

questions.text: Which of the following does not represent a characteristic of tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ear ache

Explanation:

  • Ear ache is not typically a prominent feature of tubercular otitis media.
  • Characteristics of Tubercular otitis media.
    • This condition is a chronic middle ear infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
    • It presents with symptoms like pale granulation tissue, multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane, and sometimes a mild, non-foul-smelling ear discharge.
    • Unlike acute otitis media or other chronic forms, tubercular otitis media usually does not cause severe pain in the ear, making ear ache an uncommon complaint.

 

Multiple perforations (Option B): is correct because tubercular otitis media often results in multiple tympanic membrane perforations due to the chronic and destructive nature of the infection.

Pale granulation (Option C): is correct because pale, non-purulent granulation tissue is a characteristic feature of tubercular otitis media, often seen around the perforations.

Non-foul smelling ear discharge (Option D): is correct because tubercular otitis media does not produce a foul-smelling discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image?

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

Explanation:

  • The flap given is DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator Flap), which involves harvesting tissue from the lower abdomen without taking the muscle.
  • The flap relies on the deep inferior epigastric artery for blood supply, making it a muscle-sparing option for breast reconstruction or other soft tissue reconstructions.
  • It is the best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness.

Breast Reconstruction Flaps

Flaps

Clinical Correlation

Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle Flap (TRAM)
  • Free flap involves using tissue from the abdomen, including both skin and muscle (Option A ruled out)
  • Most commonly used flap but not the best flap
  • It is based on inferior epigastric vessels
  • Disadvantage: causes weakness in infra umbilical region

Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator flap (DIEP)
  • Flap which uses skin and fat from lower abdomen, but spares abdominal muscles
  • Best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness

Latissimus Dorsi Flap
  • Flap, which uses Latissimus dorsi muscle, skin and fat
  • It is a type of subcutaneous flap based on thoracodorsal vessels.

Pedicled TRAM based on the superior epigastric artery (Option A): A pedicled TRAM flap involves using the skin, muscle, fat and blood vessels, but the image does not depict a Pedicled TRAM flap; the image actually shows a DIEP flap.

Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels (Option D) The image does not depict lower abdominal fat based on inferior epigastric vessels; the image actually shows a DIEP flap.

questions.text: Where is the location of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option B - Optic tract

Explanation:

Lesion Location

Visual Field Defect

Pupillary Reflex

Congruity

Optic Tract (Option B)

Homonymous hemianopia

RAPD

Incongruous (defect may not match)

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)

Homonymous hemianopia

Normal

Incongruous (less congruous)

Optic Radiation

(Option C ruled out)

Inferior or superior homonymous quadrantanopia or hemianopia

Normal

Incongruous

Visual Cortex

Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

Normal

Congruous

(more consistent)
  • Pupillary reflexes are normal beyond the optic tract because pupillary fibres leave the optic tract before reaching LGB.
  • Wernicke's pupil is a type of RAPD where the abnormal pupillary response is associated with homonymous hemianopia.

 

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve (Option A ruled out)

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Anopia

Optic Chiasma (Option D ruled out)

 

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia)

questions.text: Which is the condition where surgery is done to partially or completely occlude one nostril?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrophic rhinitis

Explanation:

  • Atrophic rhinitis: Surgery is sometimes performed in atrophic rhinitis to partially or completely occlude one nostril.
  • In this condition, the nasal mucosa becomes thin and atrophic, leading to dry, crusting nasal passages and an impaired mucociliary clearance.
  • Surgical interventions, such as septal surgery or turbinate reduction, may be necessary to manage the symptoms and help prevent further damage to the nasal structures.

Atrophic Rhinitis:

  • Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by the thinning and atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones.
  • It results in symptoms like dry nasal passages, crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and in some cases, nasal obstruction.
  • In advanced cases, surgical procedures may be done to improve nasal patency or to occlude the nostril to reduce airflow and symptoms.
  • This procedure aims to decrease the discomfort caused by excessive dryness or other symptoms.

 

Vasomotor rhinitis (Option A): is incorrect because vasomotor rhinitis involves nasal congestion triggered by environmental factors, but it does not require surgery to occlude the nostril.

Invasive aspergillosis (Option C): is incorrect because invasive aspergillosis is a fungal infection that affects the sinuses and can cause symptoms like nasal obstruction and discharge, but surgery is not typically done to occlude a nostril in this case.

Allergic rhinitis (Option D): is incorrect because allergic rhinitis is caused by immune reactions to allergens and is primarily managed with medications like antihistamines or intranasal steroids, not surgery to occlude a nostril.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

Explanation:

The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist, best seen when the thumb is extended. It is bounded laterally by the tendons of:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

Boundaries of the Anatomical Snuff Box:

  1. Lateral (Radial) Boundary:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
  2. Medial (Ulnar) Boundary:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
  3. Floor:
    • Scaphoid & Trapezium bones
    • Radial artery passes through
  4. Roof:
    • Skin & Superficial branch of the radial nerve

Contents

  • Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture, as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. This type of fracture is common and can have complications due to poor blood supply.

Incorrect Options:

Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis (option B): EPL forms the medial boundary, not lateral. Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is not involved in the snuff box boundaries.

Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis (option C): EPL is the medial boundary, while EPB is lateral. The second lateral tendon (APL) is missing.

Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis (option D): Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is not part of the snuff box.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Explanation:

The patient's age, male predominance, along with MRCP findings of (beading) multiple irregular stricturing and dilatations of the bile duct, suggest Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

PSC is characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments.

Demographics
  • It commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years.
  • Has a male predominance of 2:1.

Pathogenesis
  • It suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies and T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, as well as associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis.
  • A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury.
  • Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component.
  • Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens.
  • Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are

Clinical features
  • Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.
  • Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur.
  • Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years.

Characteristic findings
  • ERCP/MRCP shows the beaded appearance of bile ducts
  • Biopsy,
    • Early features:
      • Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation
      • Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation
    • Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome"

Associated conditions

Ulcerative colitis, risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

Complication

Lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is about 20%.

Caroli disease (Option B) is a rare congenital condition characterised by cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. On MRCP, it shows diffuse bile duct dilation with saccular and fusiform features, along with a peripheral funnel-shaped sign. Unlike PSC, Caroli disease typically involves only the intrahepatic ducts, without extrahepatic duct involvement.

Oriental cholangitis (Option C) is seen in Asian populations and is often related to hepatolithiasis and biliary tract infections. It doesn’t normally show the beaded appearance on MRCP, which is more characteristic of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary biliary carcinoma (Option D) is also known as Cholangiocarcinoma and presents with obstructive jaundice, but it doesn’t usually cause recurrent fever and chills as cholangitis does. On MRCP, it shows focal or diffuse bile duct strictures or mass lesions rather than the beaded appearance.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg; there is no sign of bleeding. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Addisonian crisis

Explanation:

  • The most likely cause of the patient's lethargy, fatigue, and hypotension (with no sign of bleeding) is an Addisonian crisis (also known as an adrenal crisis) due to adrenal insufficiency after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • It occurs when there is a sudden, severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • It leads to hypotension, electrolyte imbalances, and symptoms like lethargy and fatigue.
  • It is managed by IV hydrocortisone.

SIADH (Option B) results in hyponatremia due to excessive ADH secretion, but it does not explain the low blood pressure and fatigue in this patient, as the Addisonian crisis does.

Diabetes insipidus (Option C) involves a deficiency of ADH or kidney resistance to it, leading to excessive urination and thirst. It would not typically present with the hypotension and lethargy seen in this patient.

Cerebral salt wasting disease (Option D) can potentially cause increased urinary loss of sodium, hyponatremia and hypovolemia due to CNS conditions, while adrenal crisis shows low sodium alongside other symptoms related to low cortisol and aldosterone levels, requiring immediate hormone replacement therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the hand. The joints involved were proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and first carpometacarpal joint. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints were spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis

Explanation:

  • Involvement of PIP and DIP joint with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is suggestive of Osteoarthritis.

 

Joint involvement in Arthritic diseases:

Disease

Joint involved & characteristics

Joint spared

Osteoarthritis
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee
  • Asymmetrical involvement
  • Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints

Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved
  • Symmetrical involvement seen
  • Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint

Psoriatic arthritis
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP)
  • Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans
  • Skin and nail involvement +
  • Ray pattern distribution of joints seen

 

Pseudogout (Option D): Usually large joints of elderly people are affected, most commonly Knee is involved. Accumulation of Calcium pyrophosphate crystals is seen.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adult ovary

Explanation:

  • Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as part of oogenesis. In females, during fetal development, primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis. These oocytes remain in this arrested state until puberty, when they resume meiosis. Meiosis continues during ovulation, leading to the formation of a secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II until fertilization.


Incorrect Options:

Adrenal (option A): This is incorrect because meiosis does not occur in the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands are involved in hormone production, not gametogenesis.

Prepubertal testis (option C): This is incorrect because meiosis in males begins at puberty, not before. In the prepubertal testis, germ cells undergo mitosis, not meiosis.

Hypothalamus (option D): This is incorrect because the hypothalamus is part of the brain that regulates various physiological processes, including hormone release. It does not participate in meiosis.

questions.text: Which fibre is responsible for High-frequency vibration, pressure sensation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option A: Pacinian corpuscles

Explanation:

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Pacinian Corpuscle
(Option A)

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Meissner Corpuscle
(Option C ruled out)

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Nonhairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Merkel’s Disc (Option D ruled out)

Disc-shaped expansion made up of Merkel cells and Aβ-afferent nerve endings
  • Detect continuous touch and pressure,
  • Transmit strong initial signal and weaker sustained signal,
  • Localize touch sensations (Two point discrimination),
  • Determine texture

Underneath the epithelium of the skin

Free Nerve Ending (Option B ruled out)

Unencapsulated nerve endings

Detect touch and pressure

Found everywhere in skin

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Superior cerebellar artery (SCA)

Explanation:

  • The SCA supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. Thrombosis of this artery leads to cerebellar ataxia, incoordination, dysmetria, and sometimes vertigo due to cerebellar dysfunction. The symptoms primarily affect balance, limb coordination, and gait stability.

Midbrain Blood Supply:

  • Anterior-Medial Supply: branches of the Basilar artery
  • Anterior-Lateral Supply: branches of the Posterior Choroidal arteries and Quadrigeminal artery from the Posterior Cerebral Artery
  • Posterior Supply: Quadrigeminal Artery and Superior Cerebellar Artery

Incorrect Options:

Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) (option A): Incorrect because PCA infarcts primarily affect the occipital lobe, leading to visual deficits (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) rather than ataxia.

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) (option B): Incorrect because MCA occlusion leads to contralateral motor and sensory deficits (especially in the face and upper limb) and aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved), but not significant ataxia.

Internal carotid artery (ICA) (option C): Incorrect because ICA occlusion affects multiple territories, mainly causing hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and aphasia rather than isolated cerebellar ataxia.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TLD badge

Explanation:

  • Personal monitoring of radiation exposure is primarily done using thermoluminescent dosimeters (TLD badges).
  • These devices measure the cumulative radiation dose received by an individual over time.
  • The TLD contains a material (usually lithium fluoride) that absorbs radiation and emits light when heated, which is proportional to the amount of radiation exposure.

 

TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure.

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals:

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide

Principle

 

Collimators (Option B): are devices used in imaging techniques like radiography, CT scans, and gamma cameras to shape and limit the radiation beam. They help in directing the radiation to a specific area of interest and reducing unnecessary radiation exposure to surrounding tissues.

Linear accelerator (Option C): a device used in radiation therapy to deliver high-energy X-rays or electron beams to treat cancer.

Grid (Option D): is a device used in radiography to reduce scattered radiation and improve image quality. It is placed between the patient and the image receptor.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old male who is a long-term smoker and experiences pain in both thighs and buttocks while walking approximately 500 meters?

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

Explanation:

  • Given the bilateral claudication affecting the thighs and buttocks, along with the patient’s smoking history, the most probable diagnosis is arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement.
  • The muscle group affected in claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease.
  • Aortoiliac disease typically presents with bilateral symptoms such as pain in the buttocks, thighs, and sometimes the calves, which worsens with exertion.
  • The pain is due to claudication caused by reduced blood flow to the lower extremities due to atherosclerosis or stenosis, commonly associated with chronic smoking.

Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery (Option A) generally causes pain in the calf, not the thighs or buttocks, and it usually affects one leg, not both. Therefore, the bilateral nature of the pain makes this diagnosis less likely.

Femoral venous insufficiency (Option C) presents with swelling & varicose veins rather than claudication pain. The pain described here is intermittent and related to exertion, which is more typical of arterial disease, not venous insufficiency.

Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery (Option D) would lead to pain in the thigh (and possibly one leg), not typically in both the thigh and buttock. Also, the pattern of bilateral pain favours the involvement of aortoiliac vessels.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A - Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

Explanation:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS):

  • It is primarily caused by a deficiency in surfactant.

  • Surfactant is produced by Type II pneumocytes.

  • Surfactant production begins by 20-24 weeks and matures by 35-37 weeks.

  • Surfactant is a mixture of phospholipids, proteins, and ions.

  • Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions are the most important components. (Option A)

  • They are primarily responsible for reducing surface tension by partially dissolving in the fluid lining the alveolar surface while the rest spreads over the water's surface in the alveoli.

Phospholipids

Location

Function

Synthesis

Significance

Phosphatidylserine

(Option B ruled out)

Inner leaflet of the plasma membrane

  • Involved in apoptosis.

  • It flips to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as a signal for phagocytes to engulf the dying cell.

Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

Plays a role in blood clotting by facilitating the binding of clotting factors.

Supports neuronal function.

 

Phosphatidylethanolamine

(Option C ruled out)

 

All cellular membranes

  • Important for membrane fusion and the structural integrity of cellular membranes.

  • Serves as a precursor for the synthesis of phosphatidylserine.

Synthesized in the ER via the cytidine diphosphate-ethanolamine (CDP-ethanolamine) pathway or by decarboxylation of phosphatidylserine in the mitochondria.
  • Plays a role in lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics.
  • Deficiencies can impact cellular functions and are associated with various neurological disorders.

Phosphatidylinositol

(Option D ruled out)

 

plasma membrane and intracellular membranes

  • Involved in cell signaling pathways, particularly through the production of secondary messengers

  • Plays a role in membrane trafficking and cytoskeletal organization.

Produced in the ER and Golgi apparatus from CDP-DAG and inositol.
  • Crucial for the function of insulin signaling and other receptor-mediated signal transduction pathways.
  • Defects in phosphatidylinositol metabolism are linked to various diseases, including diabetes and cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with hypertension, chest pain, and cramping of the legs. A chest radiograph was taken which revealed the condition as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coarctation of aorta

Explanation:

  • The presence of the Figure of 3 sign and rib notching on X-ray, along with symptoms of hypertension and chest pain, indicates coarctation of the aorta. These findings suggest narrowed aorta leading to collateral circulation and rib erosion, confirming the diagnosis.
  • Figure of 3 sign: This sign indicates a contour abnormality of the aorta commonly associated with coarctation of the aorta. It is characterized by a distinctive "3" shape formed by the aorta and adjacent structures on the X-ray.

Inferior rib notching:

 

Radiographic Features of Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA)

Plain Radiograph Findings

  • Figure of 3 Sign
    • Contour abnormality of the aorta, indicative of coarctation.
  • Inferior Rib Notching (Roesler Sign)
    • Erosion of the inferior margins of ribs (usually 4th–8th) by dilated intercostal collateral vessels.
    • Seen in long-standing cases (70% of older children/adults).
    • Rare in infancy or children <5 years.
  • Collateral Pathways
    • Increased subclavian artery flow promotes collateral formation via:
      • Internal thoracic arteries
      • Anterior and posterior intercostal arteries
  • Rib Notching Patterns
    • Bilateral Rib Notching:
      • Coarctation distal to both subclavian arteries.
    • Unilateral Right Rib Notching:
      • Coarctation between the brachiocephalic trunk and left subclavian artery, or
      • Right-sided aortic arch with an aberrant left subclavian artery.
    • Unilateral Left Rib Notching:
      • Aberrant right subclavian artery arising post-coarctation, with collaterals on the left.

 

Essential hypertension (Option B): refers to high blood pressure without a known underlying cause. It is typically a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other identifiable causes of hypertension should be ruled out. In this case, the chest radiograph findings strongly suggest a specific underlying cause rather than essential hypertension.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C): refers to a localized dilation or ballooning of the aorta. While it can lead to hypertension in some cases, the characteristic radiographic finding for aortic aneurysm would be an enlarged, bulging segment of the aorta rather than rib notching.

Aorta-arteritis (Option D): Aorta-arteritis, such as Takayasu arteritis, refers to inflammation and narrowing of the large arteries, including the aorta. While it can cause hypertension, the specific radiographic finding associated with aorta-arteritis would be wall thickening or narrowing of the involved vessels rather than rib notching.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for the identification of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

Explanation:

  • The inferior belly of omohyoid muscle is not used for identifying the facial nerve trunk because it is located in the lower neck and does not have any anatomical relation to the facial nerve. The facial nerve exits the stylomastoid foramen and is identified in the parotid region, where it divides into its branches.

Origin:

  • The facial nerve arises from the pons, a part of the brainstem, at the pontomedullary junction.

Pathway:

  • After its origin, the facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).
  • It then travels through the facial canal within the temporal bone.

 

Key Structures Along Its Course

Geniculate Ganglion:

  • Located within the facial canal, this is a sensory ganglion where the nerve fibers for taste (from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue) and some general sensory fibers synapse.

Branches within the Facial Canal:

  • Greater Petrosal Nerve: Arises from the geniculate ganglion, carrying parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland and nasal mucosa.
