  • Chorda Tympani: This branch arises after the geniculate ganglion and carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.

 

Exit from the Skull

Stylomastoid Foramen:

  • The facial nerve exits the skull here, located between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone.

 

Extracranial part of facial nerve:

 

Entry into Parotid Gland
  • The main trunk enters on the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland.

Division of Nerve
  • Divides within the gland, behind and superficial to the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery (ECA).

Temporofacial vs. Cervicofacial Trunks
  • Temporofacial trunk: Contains more axons but fewer fascicles.
  • Cervicofacial trunk: Contains more fascicles but fewer axons.

Formation of Parotid Plexus
  • The trunks branch further to form the parotid plexus (pes anserinus) from which the terminal branches arise.

Terminal Branches
  • Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

 

Incorrect Options:

Retrograde dissection from distal branch (option A): In cases where the main trunk is difficult to locate, tracing a distal branch backward helps in identifying the facial nerve trunk.

Tragal pointer (option B): The tragal pointer (cartilaginous structure of the external auditory canal) is an important surgical landmark, located about 1 cm anterior and inferior to the stylomastoid foramen, where the facial nerve trunk emerges.

Posterior belly of digastric (option D): The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another key landmark. The facial nerve trunk is located just superior to this muscle at its attachment to the mastoid process.

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option B: Heparan sulfate

Explanation:

  • The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is Heparan sulfate (type of glycosaminoglycan (GAG)).
  • Heparan sulfate has negative charges that repel negatively charged proteins, contributing to the selective filtration of molecules based on their charge.

Fibronectin (Option A): Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that functions as an extracellular matrix protein. It is primarily located in the mesangial matrix. This option is incorrect.

Collagen Type IV (Option E) and Entactin (Option D): The GBM (glomerular basement membrane) is an extracellular matrix composed of four major macromolecules: laminin, type IV collagen, nidogen/entactin, and heparan sulfate proteoglycan, the major one in the GBM is heparan sulfate. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: The appearance of USG at saphenofemoral junction, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein is called as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mickey Mouse sign

Explanation:

  • The appearance of the ultrasound (USG) at the saphenofemoral junction, showing the common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein, is referred to as the Mickey Mouse sign.
  • In the Mickey Mouse sign, the common femoral vein represents the face of Mickey Mouse, and the common femoral artery and great saphenous vein represent the ears. This visual resemblance to the iconic Disney character gives rise to the term "Mickey Mouse sign."

 

 

Radiological Sign

Description

Associated Pathology

Classic Mickey Mouse Sign

Refers to the appearance of bilateral cranial nerve (CN) VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Mickey Mouse's head.

Acoustic neuroma

Reverse Mickey Mouse Sign

The reverse of the classic Mickey Mouse sign, where bilateral CN V and CN VI enhancement resemble Mickey Mouse's head.

Trigeminal schwannoma

Minnie Mouse Sign

Refers to unilateral CN VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Minnie Mouse's head.

Facial nerve schwannoma or hemangioma

Mickey Mouse Ears Sign

Describes bilateral globus pallidus hyperintensity on brain MRI, resembling the shape of Mickey Mouse's ears.

Wilson’s disease or Carbon monoxide poisoning

Mickey Mouse Glove Sign

Characterized by symmetric calcification of basal ganglia structures on brain CT, resembling a Mickey Mouse glove.

Fahr’s syndrome or Wilson’s disease

 

String sign (Option B): is a term used in other medical imaging modalities, such as barium studies or endoscopy, to describe a thin, elongated appearance of a narrowed or strictured segment of the gastrointestinal tract.

Tillaux sign (Option C): is a radiological finding observed in Salter-Harris III fractures of the distal tibia. It refers to the lateral displacement of the epiphysis in relation to the tibial metaphysis.

Stamers sign (Option D): Stamers sign is not a recognized medical term or radiological finding in the context of the saphenofemoral junction or ultrasound imaging.

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents?

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A- Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

Explanation:

  • The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction, which is transmitted through the closed tricuspid valve.

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

a wave

  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option B ruled out)

  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.

  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave

  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve. (Option A)

x descent

  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave

  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)

  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent

  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the term for the additional row of eyelashes located behind the grey line?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distichiasis

Explanation:

  • The case is of distichiasis - extra eyelash row

 

Eyelash rubbing the cornea can happen in:

  • Trichiasis - Inward misdirection of lashes with the normal position of the lid margin (Option A ruled out)
  • Pseudotrichiasis - Inward turning of lashes along with the lid margin
  • Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash (Option B)

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Photophobia
  • Irritation
  • Pain
  • Lacrimation
  • Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded)
  • Conjunctival congestion

Complications
  • Recurrent corneal abrasions
  • Superficial corneal opacities
  • Corneal vascularization
  • Non-healing corneal ulcer

Treatment
  • Epilation
  • Electrolysis
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction

Tylosis (Option C) is a genetic condition characterized by thickening of the lid margin.

Madarosis (Option D) refers to the loss or absence of eyelashes and/or eyebrows

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was hyperthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, chemosis and hyperthyroidism is suggestive of Grave’s ophthalmology

 

Thyroid Eye Disease Clinical Features :

Clinical Features

Details

Lid Signs

Dalrymple's Sign

Upper lid retraction causing a staring appearance (90% of cases).

Von Graefe's Sign

Lid lag when the globe moves downward (50% of cases).

Enroth's Sign

Puffy, oedematous swelling of the eyelids.

Gifford's Sign

Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid.

Stellwag's Sign

Infrequent blinking.

Joffroy's Sign

Poor forehead wrinkling on looking up.

Kocher’s sign

Increased lid retraction with visual fixation (staring look)

Conjunctival Signs

Deep Injection

Pronounced redness.

Chemosis

Swelling of the conjunctiva.

Pupillary Signs

Less significant; may show unequal dilatation of pupils.

Ocular Motility Defects

Mobius's Sign

Convergence weakness.

Restrictive Myopathy

Limited movement in the direction opposite to the affected muscle.

Exophthalmos

Both eyes are often affected with possible unilateral proptosis.

 

Orbital pseudotumor (Option A) It is characterized by congestive proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and optic nerve dysfunction and generally present as a unilateral condition in adults.

Orbital lymphoma (Option C) It is characterized by discomfort, bulging eye, diplopia, and visible mass and can be unilateral or bilateral..

Orbital cellulitis (Option D) It is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children and is characterized by unilateral, painful proptosis and fever.

questions.text: Which maternal antibodies do not confer substantial immunity in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Polio

Explanation:

In polio, maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity to the neonate. This is because the transfer of polio-specific antibodies from the mother to the fetus is limited and the protection offered by these antibodies against polio infection is not as robust.

Poliovirus (Family: Picornaviridae)

  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route
  • Incubation Period: 8-12 days from exposure to the onset of symptoms.
  • It has three serotypes: PV1, PV2, and PV3
  • Pathogenesis: The virus spreads from the intestinal tract to the central nervous system (CNS), potentially causing aseptic meningitis and poliomyelitis.
  • Poliomyelitis often leads to flaccid paralysis because it primarily affects the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord, which are responsible for motor control resulting in muscle weakness and atrophy.
  • Reflexes may be diminished or absent due to the disruption of the motor neurons.
  • Types of Poliovirus Infections:

Inapparent Infection

90-95% of cases; asymptomatic

Abortive Poliomyelitis

Mild, flu-like symptoms with full recovery

Nonparalytic Poliomyelitis

More severe symptoms, including neck stiffness and pain, with a good prognosis

Paralytic Poliomyelitis

Includes spinal, bulbar, and polio encephalitis forms, presenting with various degrees of paralysis
  • Diagnosis:
    • Consider polio in any unimmunised child with acute flaccid paralysis, particularly in areas with past or current polio cases.
    • Isolation of poliovirus from stool specimens collected 24-48 hours apart.
  • Management: Supportive care is primary; ventilatory support may be necessary for severe respiratory involvement.
  • Prevention (Vaccination):
    • Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV): Live attenuated vaccine administered orally that induces both systemic & mucosal immunity with a risk of vaccine-associated polio.
    • Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV): Killed virus vaccine. Given via injection that provides systemic immunity without the risk of vaccine-derived polio.

Maternal antibodies formed from Tdap vaccination during pregnancy will provide immunity against tetanus (Option A), diphtheria (Option C), and pertussis in the newborn. Administering the Tdap vaccine earlier, between the 27th and 36th week of gestation, maximizes the transfer of passive antibodies to the infant.

Maternal antibodies generally protect infants less than 6 months from measles (Option D).

questions.text: The purpose of the photostress test is to distinguish between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Macula and optic nerve disease

Explanation:

  • The photostress test is used to differentiate between macular and optic nerve disease. In this test, a bright light is shone into the eye to bleach the photoreceptors, and the recovery time for visual acuity is measured. A prolonged recovery time indicates macular dysfunction, while optic nerve diseases typically do not affect the photostress recovery time.

 

Cataract and glaucoma (Option B) These conditions affect different structures (cataract affects the lens, and glaucoma affects the optic nerve). The photostress test does not assess the lens or intraocular pressure-related damage.

Lens and cornea (Option C) The photostress test is unrelated to refractive or structural abnormalities of the lens and cornea.

Retina and vitreous pathologies (Option D) While the photostress test involves the retina, it is specific for evaluating macular function, not general retinal issues or vitreous pathologies (e.g., retinal detachment or vitreous hemorrhage).

questions.text: Why is blood stored in citrate-phosphate-dextrose (CPD) preferred over acid-citrate-dextrose (ACD) for hypoxic patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The fall in 2,3-DPG is less

Explanation:

2,3-DPG (2,3-diphosphoglycerate) is important for facilitating oxygen release from haemoglobin to tissues. CPD helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG during blood storage compared to ACD, which is crucial for better oxygen delivery to tissues.

  • 2,3-DPG is a molecule that binds to haemoglobin, promoting the release of oxygen to tissues.
  • During blood storage, 2,3-DPG levels gradually decrease.
  • A reduction in 2,3-DPG leads to a leftward shift in the oxygen dissociation curve, which decreases oxygen release to tissues.
  • This can be harmful to hypoxic patients, as they already have compromised oxygen delivery

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate course of action for the care of child Ajay, the 3-year-old brother of Anuj, who resides in the same household and received diphtheria vaccination approximately 16 months ago, while Anuj is currently undergoing treatment for diphtheria in the ward?

choices.text: Nothing, as the child is already exposed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Erythromycin only

Explanation:

In situations where there is a known case of diphtheria in the household, it is recommended to administer erythromycin to individuals who have been in close contact with the infected person. Since Ajay, the younger sibling, has not developed symptoms but has been exposed, administering erythromycin alone is appropriate to prevent the development of the infection.

Diphtheria - Management of contacts

Asymptomatic Case Contacts
  • Includes household members and close contacts.
  • Monitored for 7 days for symptoms.
  • Prophylaxis: IM benzathine penicillin G (600,000 units for <6 years, 1,200,000 units for ≥6 years) or 10-day oral erythromycin (40- 50 mg/kg/day, max 2 g/day).
  • Assess and update immunization status.
  • Booster Dose: Administer the diphtheria toxoid vaccine to individuals who have not received a booster within the past 5 years.
  • Vaccinate children who have not yet received their 4th dose of diphtheria toxoid.
  • Incomplete or Uncertain Immunization: For those who have received fewer than 3 doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an uncertain immunization status, provide the vaccine according to the primary immunization schedule with an age-appropriate preparation

Asymptomatic Carriers
  • Receive 10-14 days of antimicrobial prophylaxis (oral erythromycin).
  • Administer diphtheria toxoid vaccine if no booster has been given in the past year.
  • Droplet precautions for respiratory carriers; contact precautions for cutaneous carriers.
  • Precautions continue until two negative cultures (24 hours apart) post-treatment.
  • Antitoxin is not recommended for asymptomatic carriers.

Follow-up & Repeat Cultures
  • Repeat cultures for cases and carriers 2 weeks post treatment.
  • If positive, repeat a 10 day erythromycin course and further cultures.
  • Complete eradication is not guaranteed after one course of antibiotics.

Casual Contacts
  • Routine investigation is not recommended due to low carriage rates.

Hospital-Acquired Transmission
  • Rare; only those with direct contact with respiratory/oral secretions need management as contacts.

While one booster dose (Option A) of the diphtheria vaccine is generally recommended as part of routine immunization schedules, it is not the next best step in this case. As the child is 3 years old, he would have received the 4th dose (1st booster dose) of diphtheria vaccine between 16- 24 months of age. Since he has received a booster dose in the last 5 years, only Erythromycin is needed in this patient.

Nothing as the child is already exposed (Option B): Even though the younger sibling has received vaccination against diphtheria 16 months ago, it does not ensure complete protection or eliminate the risk of infection. Vaccination provides immunity, but it may not be 100% effective in preventing infection. Therefore, appropriate measures should be taken to minimize the risk of transmission and potential illness.

Administering both erythromycin and diphtheria toxoid (Option C) is not the recommended next step in this case. In the case of the younger sibling who has not developed symptoms, administration of erythromycin alone is sufficient as a preventive measure.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old patient with diabetes, a squint was observed. The secondary deviation was higher than the primary deviation during examination. The forced duction test yielded negative results. Which type of squint is expected to be predominant in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paralytic squint

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of secondary deviation was higher than the primary deviation during examination and forced duction test yielding negative results is suggestive of paralytic squint

 

Squint/Strabismus: Misalignment of the visual axis. This condition is also called Heterotropia.

  • Classification: It is divided into latent squint (phorias) and manifest (tropia).
  • Latent squint - classification
    • Hyperphoria
    • Exophoria
    • Esophoria
  • Manifest squint - classification
    • Esotropia/Exotropia/Hypertropia
    • Concomitant/Incomitant squint
      • Concomitant: Esotropia/Exotropia
      • Incomitant:
        1. Paralytic (paralysis of the muscles)
        2. Restrictive squint (fibrosis of the muscles)
        3. A-V pattern or pattern squint
        4. Ocular motility defects

 

Concomitant squint (Option A):

  • It's a type of manifest squint in which the angle of deviation remains equal in all the 9 gazes; there is no associated limitation of ocular movements .
  • Primary deviation is equal to secondary deviation.
  • Primary deviation is the amount of deviation in a squinted eye.
  • Secondary deviation: It is the amount of deviation in the normal eye (behind the cover).
  • Concomitant squint commonly occurs during early childhood or can be congenital (congenital squint).
  • Eye movements are normal and no double vision (diplopia).
  • Amblyopia develops later (negative adaptation).
  • Abnormal retinal correspondence also plays a role. It is a positive adaptation.

 

Incomitant squint (Option B): This condition is just the opposite of concomitant squints, where the degree of squint varies in different aspects.

  • Secondary deviation is higher than primary deviation in paralytic squint.
  • In contrast to concomitant squints, there is a late presentation.
  • There is palsy of other muscles, which causes limited ocular movements (ocular movements are restricted).
  • Diplopia is also a very important feature of inconcomitant squints.

 

Paralytic squint (Option C): Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint in which ocular deviation results from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles.

  • History of diplopia and confusion
  • Secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation.
  • Ocular movements are restricted towards the action of paralyzed muscle.
  • Head is turned towards the action of paralyzed muscle.

 

Pseudo-strabismus (Option D): Pseudostrabismus is a condition when the eyes are well aligned but appear to be misaligned.

  • Causes of Pseudo-esotropia:
    • Epicanthal folds
    • High myopia (high negative angle kappa)
  • Causes of Pseudo-Exotropia:
    • Telecanthus or hypertelorism
    • High hypermetropia (high positive angle kappa)

 

Restrictive squint (Option B)occurs when there is a limited range of movement of the affected eye due to restrictions in extraocular muscle function or mechanical factors (e.g., orbital trauma or thyroid eye disease) and would yield a positive forced duction test.

questions.text: Where is the location of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Optic tract

Explanation:

Abnormal Pupillary Reactions

Reaction

Description

Causes

Amaurotic light reflex

 

Absence of direct light reflex on the affected side and an absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side.

Optic and retinal lesions on the affected side

Efferent pathway defect

Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. Near reflex is also absent on the affected side.
  • Parasympatholytic drugs (e.g. atropine, homatropine)
  • Internal ophthalmoplegia
  • Third-nerve paralysis.

Marcus Gunn pupil or RAPD

 
  • The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception.
  • It is the first sign of optic nerve disorder.
  • Tested by a swinging flashlight test.

Incomplete optic nerve lesions (Optic neuritis) (Option A) and severe retinal diseases (Retinopathy, CRVO)

Adie’s Pupil

 
  • Reaction to light is absent, and the near reflex is very slow and tonic.
  • It is usually unilateral, associated with absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women.
  • It shows pupillary constriction to 0.125% Pilocarpine due to denervation supersensitivity.

Postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP)

 

Reaction to near reflex is present, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e. there is light near dissociation.

Neurosyphilis

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil

Light reflex is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side.

Optic tract lesion (Option B)

Optic radiation (Option C) Lesions in the optic radiation primarily cause visual field defects but do not typically result in pupillary abnormalities because these fibers are past the pupillary reflex arc.

Optic chiasma (Option D) Lesions in the optic chiasma result in bitemporal hemianopia and do not produce Wernicke's hemianopic pupil.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 4-year-old boy who has muscle weakness, difficulty climbing stairs, and getting up from the floor, with a muscle biopsy showing small muscle fibrils and absence of dystrophin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Duchenne muscular dystrophy

 

Explanation:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It is caused by mutations in the DMD gene that encodes the protein dystrophin.
  • Symptoms: Children with DMD typically show signs of muscle weakness, difficulty climbing stairs, and getting up from the floor.
  • Diagnosis: The clinical presentation, along with the muscle biopsy showing absence of dystrophin, confirms the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

 

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) vs Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD):

 

Aspect

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD)

Type of Mutation

Frameshift mutations leading to a disrupted reading frame

In frame mutations that preserve the reading frame

Dystrophin Protein
  • Dystrophin deficient
  • Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal)
  • Abnormal dystrophin
  • Partially functional (20–90% of normal)

Inheritance Pattern

X-linked recessive

Age of onset

Early childhood (Before 5 years)

Later childhood (After 5-7 years)

Clinical Severity

Severe, early onset, rapid progression

Milder, later onset, slower progression

Nonambulatory by

9-10.5 years of age

> 15 years of age

Additional Symptoms

Early onset of myalgia, rhabdomyolysis, and respiratory distress

None or milder

 

Becker Muscular Dystrophy (Option A) is also caused by mutations in the DMD gene but typically results in partially functional dystrophin. Symptoms are similar to DMD but milder and with later onset. Muscle biopsy would show reduced but not absent dystrophin.

 

Myotonic dystrophy (Option C) is a different genetic disorder caused by mutations in the DMPK or CNBP genes. It involves myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles), cataracts, and cardiac abnormalities and muscle biopsy would not show absence of dystrophin.

 

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) (Option D) involves a group of disorders affecting the voluntary muscles, particularly around the hips and shoulders. It typically shows a different pattern of muscle involvement and genetic mutations, and muscle biopsy would not show the absence of dystrophin but might show other abnormalities.

questions.text:
The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called what?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Metaplasia

Explanation:

  • Metaplasia refers to the reversible change in which one type of adult cell is replaced by another type. In this case, the columnar epithelium of the respiratory tract is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium, often as a result of chronic irritation, such as smoking.

Metaplasia:

  • Metaplasia is a reversible change in which another cell type replaces one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal).
  • Metaplasia is a change in the phenotype of differentiated cells, often in response to chronic irritation that makes cells better able to withstand stress; usually induced by altered differentiation pathway of tissue stem cells, may result in reduced functions or increased propensity for malignant transformation.
  • Barrett's oesophagus is characterised by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower oesophagus with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells & is considered an adaptive response to chronic exposure to gastric acid and bile reflux in the setting of GERD.
  • The presence of Barrett's oesophagus increases the risk of developing oesophagal adenocarcinoma.
  • Transformation of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium: In the respiratory tract, in response to chronic irritation, such as smoking, the columnar epithelium undergoes metaplasia to squamous epithelium, leading to a condition known as squamous metaplasia.
  • Conversion of glandular epithelium to squamous epithelium: This type of metaplasia can be seen in the cervix, where the normal glandular epithelium undergoes metaplasia to the squamous epithelium in response to chronic inflammation or irritation, leading to a condition known as cervical squamous metaplasia.
  • Substitution of mesenchymal cells with epithelial cells: An example of this can be seen in osseous metaplasia, where mesenchymal cells differentiate into bone-forming osteoblasts, leading to the formation of ectopic bone within soft tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Dysplasia (Option A) refers to the abnormal development or growth of cells or tissues. It is characterised by disordered cell structures and is considered a precursor to cancer.

Hypertrophy (Option B) is the increase in the size of cells, leading to the enlargement of an organ or tissue. It typically occurs in response to increased functional demand or external stimulation.

Atrophy (Option C) is the reduction in the size or number of cells, leading to the shrinkage of an organ or tissue. It can result from factors such as disuse, loss of nerve supply, or inadequate blood flow.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Isomorphic phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The above image depicts Pustular psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales.
  • Isomorphic phenomenon: The isomorphic phenomenon is the correct finding associated with the image. In individuals with psoriasis, new psoriatic lesions can appear at sites of skin trauma, such as scratches, cuts, or other forms of injury.

Koebner's Phenomenon

  • Psoriatic lesions develop along the lines of trauma.
  • Isomorphic response
  • All or none phenomenon

Category

Examples

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Psoriasis, Lichen planus, Vitiligo

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Warts, Molluscum

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

Darier disease, Erythema multiforme

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Pemphigus vulgaris, Lupus erythematosus

 

Incorrect Options:

Meyerson phenomenon (Option B): The Meyerson phenomenon refers to the development of psoriatic lesions after light tapping or pressure on a psoriatic plaque.

Gottron's papule (Option C): Gottron's papule appear as flat-topped, violaceous eruptions overlying the joints of the fingers and elbows.

Nikolsky's sign (Option D): Nikolsky's sign refers to the ability to induce blistering or detachment of the superficial skin layers by lateral pressure or rubbing (positive Nikolsky's sign). This sign is not relevant to plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: Premature ageing in Werner syndrome is due to:

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Defect in DNA helicase

Explanation:

  • Werner syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive disorder, is characterised by premature ageing and accelerated development of age-related diseases.
  • It results from mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a DNA helicase involved in DNA repair and maintenance of genomic stability.
  • Chromosomal damage accumulates rapidly due to the defective enzyme.
  • This damage mimics normal ageing at a faster rate, leading to premature ageing.
  • Similar conditions like Bloom syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia also involve mutations in genes responsible for DNA repair.
  • These disorders result in genetic instability and accelerated ageing due to impaired DNA repair mechanisms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Increased telomerase activity (Option A) is typically seen in some cancers, where it allows cells to maintain telomere length and avoid senescence.

Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity (Option C) and Decreased telomerase activity (Option D): In Werner syndrome, telomere shortening occurs due to DNA repair defects rather than telomere maintenance problems. Telomerase activity is not significantly altered.

questions.text: Which of the morpholine drugs listed below is used as a nail lacquer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Amorolfine

Explanation:

  • Amorolfine is an antifungal medication that belongs to the class of drugs known as morpholines. It is commonly used as a topical nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections of the nails, known as onychomycosis.
  • Amorolfine works by inhibiting the growth of fungi, including dermatophytes and yeasts, which are responsible for causing nail infections.
  • Morpholines are a class of organic compounds that contain a morpholine ring structure, which is a saturated heterocycle consisting of a six-membered ring with one oxygen atom and one nitrogen atom. These compounds have diverse applications in the field of pharmaceuticals due to their unique chemical properties.

 

Incorrect Options:

Oxiconazole (Option B): Oxiconazole is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. It is an antifungal medication, but it belongs to a different class of drugs called imidazoles. Oxiconazole is available in various formulations, including creams and lotions, and is used for the treatment of various fungal skin infections.

Ciclopirox olamine (Option C): Ciclopirox olamine is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. Although it is an antifungal medication, it belongs to a different class of drugs called hydroxypyridones. Ciclopirox olamine is available as a nail lacquer and is used for the treatment of fungal infections of the nails, including onychomycosis.

Tioconazole (Option D): Tioconazole is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. It is an antifungal medication that belongs to the class of drugs called imidazoles. Tioconazole is commonly used for the treatment of vaginal yeast infections and is available in various formulations, including creams and ointments.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. A biopsy of the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Myxoid liposarcoma

  • The presence of a retroperitoneal mass with the molecular finding of t(12;16) translocation & image showing abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and few immature adipocytes, is highly suggestive of Myxoid liposarcoma.
  • Liposarcoma, malignant tumours of adipose tissue, is the most common type of sarcoma in adults. These tumours typically arise in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and retroperitoneum, commonly affecting individuals in their sixth and seventh decades of life.
  • Pathogenesis: The three subtypes of liposarcoma—well-differentiated, myxoid, and pleomorphic—have distinct genetic abnormalities:
    • Well-differentiated liposarcomas exhibit amplifications in the chromosome region 12q13–q15, which includes the p53 inhibitor MDM2.
    • Myxoid liposarcomas are characterised by a fusion gene caused by a t(12;16) translocation, which arrests adipocyte differentiation, leading to uncontrolled proliferation of primitive cells.
    • Pleomorphic liposarcomas display complex karyotypes without consistent genetic abnormalities.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Well-differentiated liposarcomas are composed primarily of mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells.
    • Myxoid liposarcomas are characterised by a rich basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries, and primitive cells at different stages of adipocyte differentiation, resembling fetal fat.
    • Pleomorphic liposarcomas feature sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei intermixed with varying numbers of immature adipocytes, called lipoblasts.

Lipomas (Option B) are benign tumours made up of mature adipose tissue. They are typically well-defined and do not show the cellular atypia or genetic abnormalities associated with liposarcomas.

Spindle Lipoma (Option C) is a benign variant of lipoma characterised by spindle-shaped cells within the fatty tissue. It lacks the genetic mutations seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

Polymorphic Lipoma (Option D), also referred to as pleomorphic lipoma, is a benign lipomatous tumour made of mature adipose tissue containing various cell types. It does not exhibit the specific t(12;16) translocation found in myxoid liposarcoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass shows cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colloid carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Colloid carcinoma, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is characterised by malignant cells surrounded by mucin pools.

Mucinous or Colloid Carcinoma:

  • A subtype of infiltrating ductal carcinoma.
  • Location: Upper outer quadrant (most common).
  • Clinical findings:
    • Soft to firm lump due to mucilage.
    • It may be mistaken for a benign tumour.
  • Histopathology:
    • Gross: Soft, rubbery texture with pale gelatinous/jelly consistency.
    • Microscopy: Tumour cells arranged in clusters or islands with pools of mucin extracellularly and may be intracellularly (called signet ring cell).
    • FNAC: Chicken wire blood vessels.

Gross pathology (upper left) of biopsies of mucinous carcinoma shows gelatinous areas (which are transparent compared to normal yellow fatty tissue). Histopathology shows clusters or nests of tumour cells floating in pools of extracellular mucin.
  • Excellent prognosis.

 

Papillary carcinoma (Option B) is defined by the presence of papillary structures within the tumor. The tumour cells typically show elongated nuclei with nuclear grooves and intranuclear pseudo inclusions, which are distinct features not seen in colloid carcinoma.

Medullary carcinoma (Option C) is a type of invasive breast carcinoma that presents with sheets of poorly differentiated tumour cells. These cells have large, pleomorphic nuclei and prominent nucleoli, which is different from the mucin-filled appearance in colloid carcinoma.

Lobular carcinoma (Option D) originates from the lobular units of the breast and is characterised by tumour cells infiltrating in a single-file pattern, known as the Indian file pattern. The cells may exhibit signet ring morphology but do not form mucin pools, as seen in colloid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 g/dl and MCV = 101 FL. A peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Chronic alcoholism

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with macrocytic anemia (MCV = 101 fL) and peripheral smear findings of macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils, which strongly indicate megaloblastic anemia. This condition is most commonly caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, often due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption, or chronic alcohol use.
  • Chronic alcohol consumption is a well-known cause of macrocytic anemia, either due to direct toxic effects on hematopoiesis or through the development of folate deficiency, a key cause of megaloblastic anemia.

Lead poisoning (Option A) typically causes microcytic anemia due to interference with heme synthesis.

Iron deficiency anemia (Option B) is characterised by microcytic, hypochromic anaemia resulting from reduced haemoglobin production.

Hemolytic anemia (Option C) may cause mild macrocytosis due to increased reticulocyte production; hypersegmented neutrophils are not seen. The hallmark findings of hemolysis (e.g., jaundice, reticulocytosis) are absent in this case.

questions.text: How is thrombosis initiated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endothelial injury

Explanation:

  • Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury, which exposes underlying collagen and pro-coagulant factors, leading to platelet activation and adhesion. This triggers the coagulation cascade, resulting in thrombus formation.
  • Endothelial injury is considered the primary event that starts the sequence leading to thrombosis.

Virchow’s triad is a concept used to explain the three primary factors that contribute to the development of thrombosis

  • Endothelial Injury: Damage to the inner lining of blood vessels (endothelium) can lead to the exposure of underlying tissues, such as collagen and tissue factor, which activate the clotting process. Conditions like atherosclerosis, trauma, or inflammation can cause endothelial injury.
  • Abnormal Blood Flow (Stasis or Turbulence): Disruptions in normal blood flow, such as slow or stagnant blood flow (stasis) or turbulent flow, can promote clot formation. This is commonly seen in conditions like atrial fibrillation, prolonged immobility, or varicose veins.
  • Hypercoagulability: An increased tendency of the blood to clot, which can be due to genetic factors (such as factor V Leiden mutation), acquired conditions (such as cancer or pregnancy), or certain medications that contribute to thrombosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Juvenile polyp

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and HPE image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts & glands are suggestive of Juvenile polyp.

Juvenile Polyps:

  • Occurrence: Common in children under 5 years old; can be sporadic or syndromic.
  • Size & Appearance: Typically less than 3 cm, pedunculated, smooth-surfaced, reddish with cystic spaces.
  • Histology: Dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris, mixed inflammatory infiltrates, and sometimes attenuated muscularis mucosae.
  • Pathogenesis: Linked to mucosal hyperplasia; mutations in SMAD4 and BMPR1A (TGF-β pathway).
  • Dysplasia: Rare in sporadic polyps but present in juvenile polyposis syndrome.
  • Complications: Juvenile polyposis syndrome can lead to colonic adenocarcinoma (30-50% risk by age 45).

Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (Option A) is an autosomal dominant condition characterised by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract. While rectal polyps may occur in this syndrome, the histopathological image seen in this case is more indicative of juvenile polyps.

Villous Adenoma (Option B) are adenomatous polyps commonly seen in adults, characterised by finger-like projections with abundant mucin production.

Tubular Adenoma (Option D) are common adenomatous polyps found in adults, characterized by glandular structures with tubular architecture.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Minimal change disease

Explanation:

  • Effacement of podocyte foot processes refers to the flattening or loss of the foot processes of podocytes, specialized cells located in the kidney's glomerulus. This structural change is a hallmark of minimal change disease (also called minimal change nephrotic syndrome).
  • It presents with severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and lipiduria. While the glomeruli appear normal under light microscopy, the characteristic finding of podocyte foot process effacement can only be observed under electron microscopy.
  • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (2-6 years) and responds well to corticosteroid therapy.

Steroid-resistant glomerulonephritis (Option A) does not typically show effacement of podocyte foot processes. Instead, it may show more severe glomerular damage.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) (Option C) is marked by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is not typically associated with podocyte effacement.

Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option D) is associated with sclerosis and fibrosis in the glomeruli, and effacement of podocyte foot processes is not a characteristic finding.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with ADPKD was prescribed Tolvaptan, and after a few weeks, he presented with dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - V2 receptor antagonism

Explanation:

The most likely cause of the patient's dry mouth and increased thirst after taking Tolvaptan is V2 receptor antagonism.

Tolvaptan

It is a medication that belongs to a class of drugs known as vasopressin receptor antagonists.

MOA

Blocks vasopressin receptors, specifically targeting the V2 receptors

  • V2 receptors are located in the renal collecting ducts
  • Blockade of V2 receptors reduces water reabsorption and promotes the excretion of free water, leading to increased urine output.

Uses

  • Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)
  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)
  • Hyponatremia

Side effects
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Dehydration
  • Dry mouth
  • Hypersensitivity reactions

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity
  • Concurrent use of CYP3A inhibitors - Ketoconazole, Clarithromycin

Precautions

  • Monitor serum sodium levels - adjust dose accordingly
  • Use with caution in patients with hepatic diseases

questions.text: Based on the graph given below shows the relationship between the log dose and the response of Drugs A, B and C. Which of the following has the highest potency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A

Explanation:

Drug A has the maximum potency of the three drugs.

  • Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
  • Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.
  • Both are independent of each other.
    • Efficacious drugs can have high or low potency
    • Potent drugs can have high or low efficacy
  • The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
    • Thus, order of potency: Drug A > B > C
    • The left shift of the graph indicates an increase in potency.
  • The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy
    • Thus, order of efficacy: Drug A = B > C

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Diphenylmethane

Explanation:

  • Diphenylmethane derivatives are antihistaminic agents (not a prokinetic) used to treat allergies.

Prokinetic

Prokinetic agents are medications that enhance gastrointestinal motility and promote the movement of food through the gastrointestinal tract.

Drugs

5-HT4 agonist - stimulates 5-HT4 in the GIT, which causes increased release of Acetylcholine and enhances GIT motility

  • Naronapride
  • Cisapride
  • Prucalopride

Dopamine antagonist - blocks dopamine receptors in the GIT, which reduces the inhibitory effects of dopamine on the GIT motility.

  • Metocloprimde
  • Domperidone

Motilin agonist - Mimics the action of motilin, which promotes GIT motility

  • Erythromycin (Off-label)
  • Camicinal

Miscellaneous

  • Sincalide - C-terminal octapeptide of CCK
  • Relamorelin - Ghrelin agonist

Uses
  • Gastrointestinal reflux disease
  • Gastroparesis
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Postoperative ileus

Adverse effects

  • Gastrointestinal disturbance (Diarrhoea, Vomiting, abdominal cramps)
  • Headache
  • Dizziness
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms with Dopamine antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Amiodarone

Explanation:

  • Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.
  • It is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that is associated with the development or exacerbation of interstitial lung disease, a condition characterised by inflammation and scarring of lung tissue.
  • Side effects of amiodarone:
    • Pulmonary fibrosis
    • Hypotension
    • Torsades de pointes
    • Corneal microdeposits
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Neuropathy
    • Photosensitivity
    • Thyroid dysfunction

Drugs associated with Lung disorders:

Drugs

Lung disorders

Amniodarone

 

 

Pulmonary fibrosis

Bleomycin

Busulfan

Nitrofurantoin

Rarely associated with chronic pulmonary fibrosis

Cyclophosphamide

 

Interstitial pneumonitis, which can lead to pulmonary fibrosis

Methotrexate

Sotalol (Option B) is a class III antiarrhythmic that primarily blocks potassium channels. It does not have significant pulmonary toxicity.

Quinidine (Option C) is a class I antiarrhythmic, and it is not associated with pulmonary toxicity and is therefore not contraindicated in ILD.

Lignocaine (Option D) is a class Ib antiarrhythmic which is mainly used for ventricular arrhythmias and is not associated with pulmonary toxicity.
